Summary

â€œComâ€”â€ Her voice cracks, and she clears her throat. â€œCome in!â€

â€œNice save,â€ Agatha whispers sarcastically.

â€œShut up,â€ the girl snaps, whipping her head around to shoot Agatha a glare that could kill, hissing through her teeth.

Then, the door creaks open slowly, the sound dragging out in the thick silence. Every second feels like an eternity to Agatha, her heart pounding in her chest as she holds her breath, staring at the door. The anticipation is unbearable, the tension in the air palpable.

And then, she sees her.

Rio.

itâ€™s not just for work, and it isnâ€™t for play

A ghost? Really? Now that was low. It felt as if Agatha Harkness had been brought into this world to personally spite Death herself. She treated Rio as a pathetic pawn in one of her countless games. Three centuries of knowing Agatha Harkness. Three centuries of heartbreak, grief, sorrow, betrayal.. Emotions Rio never thought herself capable of feeling. Yet now, those feelings consume her, each one heavier than the last, more overwhelming than anything she has ever known. And right now, they seem to taint every other emotion she had ever felt, scars ripped open at their seams, leaving her bloody and raw.

Â 

You know the saying, â€œFool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, shame on me.â€ Well, for Rio, when it comes to Agatha Harkness, itâ€™s more like, â€œFool me 836,258 times and Rio will still refuse to feel shameâ€ - even if it slapped her right in the face (which, of course, it has.. more times than she cares to count).

Â 

Itâ€™s a choice, one she makes willingly, time and time again. To play as a pawn in Agathaâ€™s twisted games, knowing full well that Agatha was always up to something that would, without a doubt, ruin Rio. It is the very definition of insanity. Yet, to know Agatha Harkness is to love her. So, call Rio crazy, because there is no universe in which she would ever choose otherwise- eternity be damned. In every life time, in every universe, she would do it all over again. Even if it meant being punched in the gut a million times by Agatha, to then be hit by a bus and dragged through three centuries while Agatha is driving said bus. But hey, three centuries? Thatâ€™s a very short time when youâ€™ve been around since the universeâ€™s very existence.

Â 

Agatha never wants to see Rioâ€™s face again, sheâ€™s made that abundantly clear. Rio canâ€™t control much, but she can control this. If Agatha wants to play pretend as a mother to some random abomination she hasnâ€™t even known for five minutes, far be it from Rio to stop her. After all, the sacred balance has been restored (a loophole that makes Rio seethe).

Â 

Despite everything in the green witch telling her otherwise, this time she will give Agatha what she wants.

Â 

-

Â 

Billy and Agatha were somewhere in the Midwest at a record store after another dead end in Billyâ€™s â€œI wAnT tO fiND mY bRoThERâ€™ quest. They were browsing while trying to kill time, when the front door chimes.

Â 

Agatha barely registers it. It wasnâ€™t like anyone could see her, except Teen. She was still adjusting to her new existence as a fresh faced ghost. She had only just begun to make physical contact with inanimate objects, but her attempts so far have been nothing short of pathetic. Awkward and frustrating, each failure a stark reminder of how powerless she feels.

Â 

But..

Â 

She can feel her purple returning, slowly making its way back to her, a familiar sensation. Though it had taken a few wrong turns along the way, delaying its arrival time, but no need to worry, it will be home soon.

Â 

Teen doesnâ€™t seem to mind Agathaâ€™s lack of power; in fact he almost seems satisfied by her predicament.

Â 

He has developed a growing ego, fueled by his new found abilities and Agathaâ€™s obvious lack there of. It wasnâ€™t a good look. Nothing ever good came from cockiness. But she let it slide. Heâ€™d learn soon enough. For now, sheâ€™d lt him enjoy his delusional superiority complex.

Â 

â€œI love that album.â€ Teen says excitedly. Agatha looks up.

Â 

A young woman, maybe in her early 20s, dark brown hair, fair skin, light colored eyes, a bluish green with specks of brown. She stands a few feet away from Teen, her gaze snaps up from the album she was scanning.

Â 

Agatha saunters over and glances down at the album the girl is holding: The Rise and Fall of a Midwest Princess. She scoffs, â€œFitting.â€

Â 

Teen throws a quick glance at Agatha, then back to the brunette, making sure sheâ€™s oblivious to the spooky presence hovering nearby.

Â 

The younger woman looks up at him, smiling. Agatha rolls her eyes. â€œDuuuuuh,â€ the older brunette drags out, the sarcasm thick in her voice.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s so good! I canâ€™t stop listening to it,â€™ The girl says, her eyes returning to the album in her hands, a small smile tugging at her lips.

Â 

â€œHave you heard Subway? Itâ€™s an unreleased track, but she performs it at every festival she plays at.â€

Â 

The girlâ€™s eyes light up at his question, her lips curling into a playful grin, her tongue presses into her cheek.

Â 

Agatha stills.

Â 

It almost reminds her of- no.

Â 

Sheâ€™s not opening that can of worms. Agatha chooses peace, and sheâ€™s not about to ruin it with thoughts of her relentless exâ€¦.

Â 

An ex who hasnâ€™t been very relentless for the last nine months. But whoâ€™s counting? Certainly not Agatha.. though she does wonder.

Â 

Rioâ€™s too smart for her not to have figured it out by now. Itâ€™s not like Agatha was quiet about it. Since when is Agatha Harkness ever quiet about anything? Still, she expected hell to freeze over the second Rio uncovered that her dead ex was far from being completely dead.

Â 

In all fairness, Rio really hates ghosts. Agatha knows this, and she pretends not to be bothered by the fact that this cat-and-mouse game theyâ€™ve played for the last three centuries seems to be over- if Rioâ€™s complete and utter silence for the last NINE MONTHS is any indication.

Â 

Lady Death has gone AWOL.

Â 

Was Agathaâ€™s â€˜I donâ€™t want to see your faceâ€™ speech a little much? Maybe. Did dying and coming back as a ghost, and fully knowing how much the green witch despised ghosts add a nice, cruel little cherry on top? Probably. But Agatha never believed Rio would just sit idly by while she existed as one of the biggest banes to Deathâ€™s existence.

Â 

Agatha had been certain Rio would come after them, paranoid even, constantly looking over shoulder, always on the defensive, expecting the green witch to show up at any moment. Sheâ€™d even warned Teen about the impending wrath they would face once Rio discovered her loophole. But one month turned into two, then three four and fiveâ€¦ and still, nothing.

Â 

After the six month mark, Billy grew tired of Agathaâ€™s fear-mongering and spat, â€œHave you ever considered that she wants nothing to do with you anymore? Canâ€™t say I blame her.â€ Disgust written all over his face.

Â 

In that moment, Agatha wanted nothing more than to wrap her hands around the kidâ€™s neck and squeeze the life right out of his annoying little eyes. She tried, of course she tried but ultimately failed miserably. Billy only laughed at her helplessness.

Â 

And no, Agatha never once considered that Rio wouldnâ€™t want anything to do with her. But here they were, nine months in to Agatha and Billyâ€™s big adventure and still? Nothing. Nada. Zip.

Â 

Not a single sign of her ex lover. Agatha feigned relief.

Â 

She has no one to run from anymore, no one to make her life hell. Now, her life was quiet and maybe just a teeny bit less vibrant without Death stalking her every move. She took this newfound peace as a gift. This is what she wanted, right?

Â 

Peace had always been a stranger to Agatha. It was something sheâ€™d never known, her mother had seen to that. And then, there was Rio. For a while, Rio had been her one exception, offering a fleeting peace, despite her role as Death. That peace had been shattered when she lost Nicky, the son she had killed for, the son she had sacrificed so much to keep alive. And yet, even after everything, when he died, Agatha couldnâ€™t bring herself to face him in death.

Â 

Now, with Rio wanting nothing to do with her and Nicky still beyond reach, Agatha sat with the quiet. Wondering if this peace was even real, or if it was just a reminder of the hollow absence of everything sheâ€™d lost.

Â 

Agatha wouldnâ€™t deny that mentoring Billy had helped. It served as a distraction, a small, fleeting moment to make up for centuries of emptiness that she had tried, always unsuccessfully, to fill.

Â 

â€œAnd in four months if this feeling ainâ€™t goneâ€¦â€ Agathaâ€™s thoughts are interrupted as the young woman begins to sing, and Billy eagerly joins in on the next verse. â€œThen fuck this city, Iâ€™m moving to Saskatchewan!â€

Â 

They both burst into laughter, their joy infectious. Agatha groans, loud and exasperated.

Â 

â€œCan we go now? This conversation is putting me to sleep.â€

Â 

Billy ignores her and continues chatting with the girl.

Â 

After a few more agonizing minutes, listening to the two of them rave aboutâ€¦ â€œgay popâ€ ? Agathaâ€™s patience finally snaps. Frustrated, she strides over, positioning herself between Billy and the girl, and attempts (repeatedly) to knock a stack of records off the table. After several aggressive swings and a string of muttered expletives, she finally delivers a sharp, â€œHI-YAH!â€ She manages to topple the pile.

Â 

The young woman jumps back, startled, giving Billy a puzzled look. Perhaps sensing his lack of reaction, she mutters, â€œWeird.â€

Â 

She crouches down to begin gathering the scattered vinyls, while Billy shoots Agatha an irritated glance before scrambling down offering his help.

Â 

Once they have finished cleaning up Agathaâ€™s mess, the girl stands, glancing at Billy, â€œI never got your name.â€

Â 

â€œShe knows youâ€™re gay right?â€

Â 

Teen ignores her.

Â 

â€œBilly!â€ He smiles.

Â 

â€œWell, Billy, it was really nice to meet youâ€¦â€

Â 

â€œThank god,â€ Agatha mutters.

Â 

â€œBut I need to borrow your familiar.â€ The young womanâ€™s gaze fills with mischief as she steps toward Agatha, extending her arm to grab the collar of Agathaâ€™s dress.

Â 

Before Agatha can react, the girl makes contact.

Â 

â€œHEY!â€ Agatha yells, but itâ€™s too late. Sheâ€™s already being yanked through a vortex.

They tumble through the portal, landing with a jarring thud on the hard floor. Somehow, Agatha ends up sprawled on top of this nameless girl (she doesnâ€™t care enough to learn it.)

Â 

The girlâ€™s, head thuds lightly against the floor, and she groans, pressing a hand to the back of her head.

Â 

As Agatha rises to her feet, she halts abruptly when she comes face to face with a mirror hanging on the wall just a few feet away. Her own reflection stares back at her, eyes unsteady and wide with disbelief. She freezes.

Â 

It canâ€™t be.

Â 

Agatha hesitates, then slowly closes the distance to the mirror. Her breath catches as she takes in the image staring back at her. Itâ€™s her, but not as she remembers. Gone is her translucent, phantom form.

Â 

She looksâ€¦ alive.

Â 

Her hair, once a dull gray, has returned to its deep brown, save for a single streak of silver. Her clothes are unfamiliar: a rusty tan linen suit paired with a white striped collared shirt.

Â 

â€œWhat?â€ she whispers, her voice trembling.

Â 

Spinning around, she scans the room with frantic eyes, searching for something, anything solid, something she can touch. The girl is forgotten, her sole focus now on testing the impossible. Her gaze lands on a desk across the room, cluttered with books, journals, and scattered papers.

Â 

Bingo.

Â 

The girl stands now, brushing herself off with a quiet huff. Agathaâ€™s focus set solely on the desk, she doesnâ€™t spare the young woman a glance, as Agathaâ€™s strides are heavy and determined, her mind consumed with testing her theory.

Â 

Without so much as a thought, she brushes past the young woman, Agathaâ€™s shoulder knocking into the girlâ€™s along the way.

Â 

The young brunette grunts, â€œWatch where youâ€™re going, dude,â€ she grumbles. Her body (and now, a bit of her ego) feels bruised from Agathaâ€™s unnecessary roughness as she rubs her shoulder, trying to soothe the ache.

Â 

â€œGet used to it, Young Adult.Â Youâ€™re lucky I didnâ€™t throw you through a wall,â€ she flings out, eyes locked on to the prize in front of her.

Â 

The girl froze, her eyebrows shooting up, she squares her shoulders and shoots: â€œYoung Adult?..â€¦. Teen?â€¦â€¦ For a nearly 400 year old witch, your nicknames really lack depth.â€

Â 

Agatha doesnâ€™t respond. Her focus narrows as she reaches the desk, slamming open hands onto its surface. Her flat palms curl into tight fists, the loose papers beneath her fingers crumple under her grip. She freezes, curling her fingers tighter as the realization hits her.

Â 

Her eyes widen in shock. â€œWhat?â€ she breathes, the word barely audible. Then louder, â€œWHAT?â€

Â 

Spinning around, she stares at Y/A (Young Adult is a mouthful, she thinks), Agathaâ€™s expression filled with a mix of disbelief and demand.

Â 

â€œI know this all seems a bit confusing, but maybe next time we use our big girl words to communicate that, instead of jumping straight to destroying my shitâ€ Y/A mumbles, brows furrowed, as she steps toward the desk and quickly gets to work unwrinkling the papers Agatha crumpled.

Â 

Agatha looks at her, mouth agape, dumbfounded.

Â 

She had heard whispers of resurrection spells. A dark, forbidden magic, a taboo even among witches. It required vast, almost unimaginable power and, more often than not, a sacrifice. It seemed straightforward enough, but the real danger was in the catastrophic consequences that would follow. It was unlike becoming a ghost or finding an empty vessel to occupy. No, it was something far darker, a perversion of the natural order. A force so corrupt, that even the book of the damned warned against its chaos.

Â 

Yet here she stood, knowing no incantation had been spoken, no obvious sacrifice made. They werenâ€™t even where Agatha had been originally laid to rest.

Â 

And the biggest indicator, no Rio.

Â 

Letâ€™s be real: if a resurrection spell and Agatha Harknessâ€™s name were ever mentioned in the same breath, Rio would definitely show up, flesh and bone, to deal with it. Even a fleeting thought of resurrecting Agatha Harkness would be enough for Rio to intervene. No witch who dared would get far enough to raise a finger, let alone speak the beginnings of the spell. And Agatha was no fool. She knew Rio had likely tamper-proofed her burial site, ensuring no one could disturb the rest Death herself so carefully prepared for her ex lover.

Â 

Agatha pretends it doesnâ€™t sting. The thought that even after her death, Rio had to take measures to protect herself from Agathaâ€™s disloyalty.

Â 

Rio was more than just the ferryman of souls; she was the keeper of the balance. No one would violate the sacred cycle of life and death. No witch had ever successfully cast a resurrection spell simply because Death had no tolerance for such deviance. She always intervened before any real damage could be done. She was, for all intents and purposes, the ultimate buzzkill, all work and no play when potential resurrection was involved.

Â

Â

Agatha immediately recognizes it was designed for a reptile. Inside, the air appears thick and humid, the lush interior filled with life. Twisting branches and sprawling vines reach from the floor to the ceiling, resembling a miniature rainforest. As Agathaâ€™s eyes examine the enclosure further, she notices faint carvings etched into the wood of nearly every branch. Runes, she realizes, filing the information away for later. Above the enclosure door, a worn gold plaque displays the name BrucieÂ in elegant cursive, a little tarnished but still legible.

Â 

Y/A turns back toward Agatha, cradling a stunning green tree python in her arms. The serpent, about four feet long, has a slender, muscular body and a broad, triangular head. Its piercing red eyes gleam with an almost otherworldly intelligence. â€œDo you want to hold her?â€ the girl asks, offering the vibrant creature with a faint, knowing smile.

Â 

â€œNo, I donâ€™t want to hold her,â€ Agatha snaps, her tone dripping with mockery as she steps back. Her piercing blue eyes lock onto the girl. â€œTell me who you are and what youâ€™ve done to me,â€ she demands, her voice hard.

Â 

The girl smiles slyly, cradling the snake closer. â€œYou like it, right? Personally, I think youâ€™ve never looked better.â€

Â 

â€œThat doesnâ€™t answer my question. Try again,â€ she snaps, her voice loud and unyielding.

Â 

â€œIâ€™m Sage,â€ her green eyes briefly flick to the side. When she looks back at Agatha, the playful smile on her lips fades into a downright shit eating grin. â€œI give to the undeserving.â€

Â 

Agatha freezes, her mind spinning. The audacity of the girl using her own words against her sends a fresh surge of fury through her. Agatha folds her arms tightly across her chest, her stance rigid.

Â

Â 

Sage doesnâ€™t flinch. Instead, that same infuriating, shit eating grin stretches wider across her face. She nods enthusiastically, her tongue pressing smugly against her cheek. She rocks up onto her tiptoes for a fleeting moment before settling back down, as if struggling to contain her excitement. The girl looks like she might combust at the anticipation of poking the bear.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s gaze shifts to the snake still curled in Y/Aâ€™s arms. It slithers up her chest, moving gracefully to the back of her neck, its head tucking into the hollow where her neck meets her left shoulder. Â 

Agathaâ€™s shoulders sag, a strange, inexplicable comfort settling over her. It almost feels as though she, not the girl, were the one being cuddled by the snake.Â 

Â 

Brucie. Stupid name.

Â 

â€œBrucie has that effect on people,â€ the girl says sweetly, her finger gently stroking the snakeâ€™s head. â€œShe can be very comforting. Isnâ€™t that right, Brucie? Sorry the mean lady doesnâ€™t want to hold you.â€

Â 

â€œStop talking.â€ Agatha pinches the bridge of her nose, fighting back an exasperated sigh. She turns sharply, distancing herself from this Sage person. She needs a moment to regroup, to clear her head, to try and make sense of this mess. The child, with her cryptic words and maddening attitude, isnâ€™t helping.

Â 

She takes a moment to absorb her surroundings. The room is bathed in a shadowy green, with dark colored walls. Plants in various shades decorate the room. Books of all kinds -about history, science, magic, and more- are scattered haphazardly across nearly every available surface their pages well worn from frequent use.

Â 

It is as if the room itself was breathing. Itâ€™s all soâ€¦ unsettlingly familiar.

Â 

Organized chaos, Agatha thinks.

Â 

A bed is shoved into one corner, its mismatched linens half hidden by a pile of neatly folded clothes. A desk sits nearby, just a few feet away. Above it is a window, one Agatha hadnâ€™t noticed earlier, too distracted by everything else around her. She walks over to it, hoping it might offer some clue as to where she is.

Â 

She peers out, only to be met with vast fields and dense forest stretching endlessly.

Â 

Well then, no answers there.

Â 

Her gaze shifts back to the desk, itâ€™s carefully constructed disarray. She scans the organized clutter, searching for something, anything, that might provide a clue. It stops her.

Â 

â€œThatâ€™s my collection of graphic smut Iâ€™ve written over the years, so if you value your blue eyeballs, Iâ€™d suggest leaving it alone,â€ Sage says, her tone suddenly serious for the first time. â€œNosiness doesnâ€™t suit you,â€ she adds with a casual shrug, her grip on Agathaâ€™s wrist still steady.

Â 

Agatha wrenches her hand free, her glare sharp enough to cut. â€œI want answers. Now!â€ she demands through gritted teeth.

â€œWell, maybe if youâ€™d ask nicel-â€

â€œYouâ€™ve exhausted my patience. Now, talk! â€ Agatha growls, slamming her fist against the desk with a force that reverberates through the room.

Â 

Brucie reacts instantly, letting out a sharp hiss, her crimson eyes narrowing in warning, mouth bearing fangs like twin blades.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s eyes widen and she jerks back unintentionally putting some distance between the two. The snake visibly relaxes and coils tighter around the younger woman.

â€œFine, geez. Just let meâ€¦â€ The girl sighs dramatically, untangling the snake from her neck and lowering it gently to the floor. They both watch as it slithers away through the gap beneath the door.

Â

â€œRelax,â€ Sage drawls, rolling her eyes. â€œPull the stick out of your ass and learn to take a joke. As for how youâ€™re here, youâ€™reâ€¦ reanimated?â€ Perhaps struggling to find the right word. â€œEssentially, youâ€™re not alive, but you have a physical presence.â€

Â 

Agathaâ€™s eye twitches, her wrath barely contained. She has to keep herself from snapping- sheâ€™s finally getting some kind of answers, and she doesnâ€™t want to blow it.

Â 

â€œWhich,â€ the girl continues, ignoring Agathaâ€™s rising tension, â€œyou were bound to figure out eventually. Â 

The phrase hits Agatha like a punch to the gut- another one of her own lines, twisted and thrown back at her. But itâ€™s the last thing the girl says that truly grabs her attention.

Â 

â€œAnother question, Madam President of the Agatha Harkness fan club?â€

â€œShoot.â€

Â 

â€œYou a green witch?â€ Agatha asks, holding her breath. The thought of Rio lingers at the back of her mind.

Â 

Agatha scoffs. â€œFigures.â€ Resurrection was a taboo subject, but green witches, especially, had egos about it- like they were too good to even consider bringing someone back. Same old bullshit about the sacred balance.

Â 

She was about to press further when a door downstairs slams shut. Followed by loud tumbles and muffled yelps.

Â 

For the first time since their encounter, Agatha sees panic flash across the girlâ€™s face. Agathaâ€™s own heart races. â€œWho is that?â€ she demands, hearing footsteps begin to echo up the stairs.

Â 

The girl holds up a hand, her voice low but firm. â€œNow, youâ€™re gonna listen to me, and listen well. She wonâ€™t be able to see you, so donâ€™t do anything stupid.â€

Â 

Agatha purses her lips, crossing her arms, ready to protest.

Â 

â€œAgatha, Iâ€™m being serious. Itâ€™s in your best interest to shut up so I can focus.â€ Agatha chews on the inside of her cheek, looking out the window but quickly glancing back to Sage. She relents, giving a slight nod.

Â 

Sage mutters something in Latin, her voice low and steady. She extends a hand toward Agatha, her thumb brushing lightly against her forehead. For a brief moment, the air around them seems to shimmer before Agatha disappears completely, as if swallowed by the space itself.

Â 

The world is no longer noticing her, though she can still see everything around. A ghostly familiarity that unsettles her deeply.

Â 

A knock on the door echoes through the eerily silent room.

Â 

Sage turns, â€œCom- â€ Her voice cracks, and she clears her throat. â€œCome in!â€

Â 

â€œNice save,â€ Agatha whispers sarcastically.

Â 

â€œShut up,â€ the girl snaps, whipping her head around to shoot Agatha a glare that could kill, hissing through her teeth.

Â

Â 

And then, she sees her.

Rio.Â

the little death

Rio.

Â 

But they arenâ€™t face to face. Her back is to them as she slowly pushes the door open with her left hand, retreating into the room in cautious, deliberate steps. Her cloak conceals her frame, its edges sweeping the floor. The hood is down, her dark hair visible, but her face remains unseen.

Â 

Agatha doesnâ€™t need to see her face. She knows. Sheâ€™s always known. Every detail of Rio, the way she moves, the energy she carries.. It all feels like a memory burned into her soul.

Â 

Her breath catches, and her body freezes in place, refusing to obey.

Â 

Run, Â her instincts scream, but she canâ€™t.

Â 

She doesnâ€™t know if she wants to run toward Rio or away from her. She wants to fight, to demand answers, to scream. How could you walk away from me? The memory of their final kiss sears into her mind, it sends a shiver down her spine.

Â 

â€œPetal,â€ Rio drawls, her voice a low, dangerous rasp. She doesnâ€™t turn, still stepping backward into the room. A broom juts out in her right hand, held at armâ€™s length as though sheâ€™s warding off some invisible plague, the broom trembling with her panic.

Â 

â€œYeah?â€ Sage swallows hard, her tone wary, betraying a flicker of unease.

Â 

Rio steps further into the room. Bite marks trail up her left arm, fresh and bleeding, her grip on the doorknob white knuckled.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s gaze darts to the end of the broom. Just beyond the doorway, Brucie, sits tightly coiled, her vibrant green scales gleaming in the dim light. At the sound of Rioâ€™s voice, the snake jolts toward her, hissing violently.

Â 

Rio yelps, her voice shaking with fear, â€œTake her. Take her now!â€ Her words rush out in desperate panic.

Â 

â€œOkay, okay,â€ Sage mutters, making her way toward the angry snake. The moment Brucie spots her, the snakeâ€™s tense body visibly relaxes. Â

Â

Â

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t like people. She preferred solitude. Always had. Was she mentoring the young green witch? Â

Petal.Â

Â

Â

Agatha lets out a frustrated yell, her voice echoing in the empty space. She throws her arms down, willing her purple magic to spark, to flare, to do something, but nothing comes. Â

Â 

Agatha doesnâ€™t know anymore. The fiery satisfaction she once felt when her words sliced through Rio has dulled into a hollow ache. Â

Â 

So it begins.

out of death, life

Chapter Notes

I know I replied to a few comments saying this chapter would be out Monday or Tuesday but I decided to split this into two parts sooo hereâ€™s part one :)) hope ya like it

Agatha and Sage stood in the void of green nothingness. The air was still, thick with a power that felt alive. It was exactly how Rio had described her realm. Beneath their feet stretched a cobblestone path, glistening faintly as though wet, though there was no water, no rain, no sky to speak of. Ahead of them, a figure cloaked in black stood motionless, its back turned.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s chest tightened. Something about the figure was magnetic, a pull she couldnâ€™t resist. Her feet moved instinctively. The closer she drew, the heavier the air became.

Â 

â€œWait.â€

Â 

Sageâ€™s hand shot out, grasping Agathaâ€™s wrist with surprising strength. Agatha stopped mid step, her heart pounding. She turned her head, brow furrowed, and found Sageâ€™s face set in an expression of calm determination that felt out of place for someone so young.

Â 

â€œWhat are you doing?â€ Agatha hissed.

Â 

â€œNot yet,â€ Sage replied. Her voice was soft, but her grip didnâ€™t loosen.

Â 

Agatha frowned and glanced back at the figure, who hadnâ€™t moved an inch. A tangle of emotions churned in her chest, curiosity, dread, and an undeniable sense of familiarity.

Â 

â€œI think I should let you, you know, walk this road alone,â€ Sage said softly, her tone almost apologetic. â€œBut Iâ€™ll meet you at the end when youâ€™re ready, okay?â€

Â 

Agatha blinked, thrown by the sudden shift. â€œWhat are you talking about? Why would you leave me now?â€

Â 

Sage gave a small shrug, â€œBecause this is something you need to do without me. And, honestlyâ€¦â€ She hesitated, her green eyes flicking to the figure ahead, â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™d be much help if I came along.â€

Â 

Agathaâ€™s jaw tightened. She wanted to argue, to demand an explanation for this cryptic nonsense, but she knew Sage was right. There was a weight in the air, a burden that wasnâ€™t Sageâ€™s to carry or to interfere with. Whatever lay at the end of the path was Agathaâ€™s and Agathaâ€™s alone.

Â 

Still, Agatha couldnâ€™t shake the unease curling in her chest. â€œAnd what if Iâ€™m not ready?â€

Â 

Sageâ€™s lips twitched, the faintest hint of her usual confidence returning. â€œThen Iâ€™ll wait longer.â€ A beat of silence and Sage continues, â€œBut you have to promise me when itâ€™s over, youâ€™ll act like the centuries-old adult you are. No fighting, no mean words, no stupid decisions. Nothing. Justâ€¦ try to handle it with some dignity, okay?â€

Â 

Agatha huffed a breathless laugh despite herself, â€œNo promises.â€

Â 

â€œI wouldnâ€™t expect anything less.â€ Sage smiles.

Â 

Agatha walks the path ahead and recognizes the figure immediately. Itâ€™s Rio. Sheâ€™s wearing that dress. The one Agatha remembers so vividly from centuries ago.

Â 

Once, she had loved it. It was beautiful, a vibrant green that seemed to radiate life. It reminded her of a time when Rio, despite her role as Death, had still held onto pieces of herself that felt alive. She looked so young.

Â 

But now, Agatha canâ€™t stomach the sight of it.

Â 

Itâ€™s the same dress Rio wore when she appeared at Nickyâ€™s birth, when she stood silently in the corner, watching with that knowing expression. Itâ€™s the same dress Agatha imagines Rio wore the night she came to take Nicky away, like a thief in the dark, denying Agatha a chance to say goodbye.

Â 

Yet, this dress is different. Its vibrant green is gone, replaced by a mournful black that clings to Rio. It reeks of grief, of loss, of regret. Rioâ€™s cheeks are streaked with dried tears, her face hollow with the weight of something unbearable.

Â 

This must be after she walked Nicky into the afterlife.

Â 

Rioâ€™s head is bowed, her gaze fixed on something below. Agatha instinctively follows her line of sight, and her breath catches.

Â 

An infant lies nestled in a basket, surrounded by a bed of flowers that seem to bloom and curl protectively around it. The childâ€™s tiny chest rises and falls with soft, steady breaths, and Agatha feels her heart twist in a way she isnâ€™t prepared for.

Â 

She glances back at Rio, searching her face for an explanation, but itâ€™s unreadable, a mask of indifference, though the tear stains on her cheeks betray her.

Â 

â€œMy realm is no place for a child,â€ Rio mutters. She makes a small clicking noise with her tongue, as if to startle the infant away. â€œSo scram.â€

Â 

The babyâ€™s response is immediate. Instead of fear, a high-pitched giggle escapes its lips. Tiny hands reach up toward Rio, fingers curling and uncurling as if asking to be held.

Â 

Rio steps back, her fingers twitching in the air as though trying to shoo the child away. â€œGo on now, run along,â€ she says, her voice softer now, her hands making quick dismissive gestures.

Â 

The child only giggles again, her laughter bubbling up like sunlight piercing through the shadows of Rioâ€™s realm.

Â 

Rio groans, the sound low and frustrated. Itâ€™s obvious now, this child isnâ€™t going to magically sprout legs and walk away. She exhales sharply, glancing around the endless expanse of her realm, as if expecting someone, anyone, to explain this absurdity. But thereâ€™s nothing. Just her, the void, and the infant.

Â 

This was uncharted territory. No one had ever stepped foot in her realm uninvited. No living soul had even tried . And yet, here this child was, arriving seemingly out of nowhere, mere moments after sheâ€™d walked her son into the afterlife. The irony wasnâ€™t lost on Rio.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t lost on Agatha either as she watches all of this unfold.

Â 

Slowly, almost reluctantly, Rio kneels beside the basket. Her movements are hesitant, her usual confidence tempered by something quieter, more vulnerable. She reaches out, hands trembling, and gently lifts the child from the cradle of flowers.

Â 

Agatha stood frozen, watching the scene. The woman who commanded life and death with unwavering confidence now lookedâ€¦ unsure.

Â 

The moment the baby rests in her arms, Rio inhales sharply, a look of wonder and fear, as though the universe itself had whispered a truth only she could understand.

Â 

â€œOut of death,â€ Rio whispers, her voice barely audible, â€œlife.â€

Â 

Agathaâ€™s heart twisted painfully. The way she cradled the infant, her touch so tender and careful. This was a side of Rio Agatha hadnâ€™t allowed herself to imagine, let alone witness. Agatha had made sure of that when she banished Rio from her and Nickyâ€™s life.

Â 

Rioâ€™s whisper hung in the air, faint but heavy with meaning. Agathaâ€™s stomach churned. She wanted to look away, but she couldnâ€™t. Her mind was a whirlwind of emotions she couldnâ€™t untangle. Shock, bitterness, confusion, and jealousy.

Â 

Why is she so gentle now? The thought stabbed at her. Where was this tenderness when me and Nicky needed it?

Â 

The memory shifted slightly, the light around the scene dimming as Rio adjusted the child in her arms. Agathaâ€™s eyes lingered on Rioâ€™s face, searching for answers in the her tear streaked cheeks and haunted eyes. She knows, Agatha thought. She knows exactly what this means.

Â 

A wave of anger surged within her. How dare Rio act like she could give life? After all the destruction sheâ€™d wrought, after taking Nicky, after taking everything â€¦

Â 

But the anger didnâ€™t stay. It dissolved too quickly, leaving behind a heavy ache she didnâ€™t want to name. Agatha clenched her fists, her nails digging nto her palms as she forced herself to keep watching.

Â 

Rio shifted the child slightly in her arms, her expression hardening as if steeling herself. Slowly, she let her face change. Rioâ€™s heartbroken beauty replaced by the haunting face of Death. Her hollow eyes seemed to darken, her features skeletal, a grim reflection of the being she truly was.

Â 

Rio held the child out slightly, almost as if to push her away. It was a silent question, a desperate plea: This is the mother you chose?

Â 

â€Iâ€™m a monster,â€ Rio whispered, her voice breaking as she cradled the infant tightly against her chest once more.

Â 

The infant giggled, its tiny hand reaching up for Deathâ€™s face. Agathaâ€™s throat tightened as she watched Rio lean closer, her expression softening in a way that felt unbearable. This wasnâ€™t the Rio she knew. This was something else entirely.

Â 

And it hurt far more than Agatha expected.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s heart broke for Rio. For the first time, she saw it clearly. The weight Rio carried, the doubt etched into every movement. Agatha had made her feel this way, hadnâ€™t she? Like she wasnâ€™t worthy of being a mother, like all she ever did was take.

Â 

Rioâ€™s face shifted back to its usual form, her features softening into something painfully human. She exhaled, a sound that started as a laugh but broke halfway through. Â

Â

Â

It looked like the kind of place where life could truly thrive, a place made for laughter, growth, and safety.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s breath hitched. She recognized it immediately. This was the dream Rio had once shared with her, a vision of the life they had planned for Nicholas before everything fell apart.

Â

Their daughter.

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha knew there would be time later. Time to be angry, to grieve, to feel the desperate ache that was already threatening to consume her. But not now. Not here. Right now, all she wanted was to watch. To witness the life Rio had built with their child.

Â 

Her emotions could wait. For now, she would let herself watch. Later, she could break.

Â 

Agatha caught a glimpse of Rio passing the stairs, her steps purposeful as she disappeared into a hallway ahead. Without hesitation, Agatha followed, her curiosity outweighing her reservations. She watched as Rio turned left into what she presumed to be a bedroom.

Â

Â 

Rioâ€™s bedroom was sparse, but every detail carried meaning. The bed was modest, accompanied by a single nightstand. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

added a little bit of spice;)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha stared at the living room ceiling, the stillness of the house mocking the chaos inside her. Four emotionally exhausting days, and her mind still hadnâ€™t settled. Sage had given her an out, a chance to leave and walk away from this mess.

Â 

For the life of her, Agatha couldnâ€™t take it.

Â 

She didnâ€™t want to take it. As much as it hurt to be here, to face everything sheâ€™d left behind, she couldnâ€™t bring herself to leave. Agatha blames it on the fact that she couldnâ€™t make that choice under the weight of Sageâ€™s unrelenting green gaze.

Â 

Not in front of her.

Â 

If there was one thing Agatha had mastered, it was the art of detachment. It had been her survival skill, her constant shield. She did what she had to do, always, never sparing a thought for anyoneâ€™s feelings or the consequences left in her wake.

Â 

But Sage complicated that.

Â 

Whether Agatha liked it or not, Sage was her daughter. Seeing Rio through Sageâ€™s memories, seeing her as a mother, seeing her first steps, her first word. It was a weight Agatha hadnâ€™t anticipated. That knowledge alone shackled her, leaving her unable to make a clean break while Sage stood there, watching.

Â 

So yes, Agatha would have left. Absolutely. But what she wouldnâ€™t do was abandon Sage right in front of her face. Not like that. Never like that.

Â 

As if Sage could hear the wheels turning in Agathaâ€™s mind, a portal opened in the middle of the room. It shimmered faintly, the same portal Sage had shown her earlier that day, the one that led to the record store.

Â 

Agatha scrambled to her feet, her sweatshirt rumpled and plaid pajama pants slightly twisted with the suddenness of her movements.

Â 

Sage was giving her another out. A chance to leave in the dead of night. No prying eyes, no distractions, nothing holding her back. It was a clean break. An escape.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s feet carried her toward the portal almost on instinct, her body moving before her mind had caught up. She stopped just short of it, the light from the swirling magic casting shadows across her face.

Â 

And with one long, deflated sigh, Agatha turned and walked away from the portal.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t dare let her mind linger on the decision. It was done. A decision she and she alone had made. A line drawn in the sand, one she had no intention of crossing. She didnâ€™t want to.

Â 

Her feet moved without thought, her body drawn by something deeper than reason. By the time she realized where sheâ€™d gone, she was standing in front of Rioâ€™s door. A soft, dim light seeped through the thin crack, spilling into the dark hallway.

Â 

Rio was awake.

Â

Â 

â€œUnbelievable,â€ she muttered to no one but herself. She didnâ€™t know whether to scream, laugh, or cry. Maybe all three. All she did know was that Rio had once again left her teetering on the edge of madness, and maybe that was the point.

Â 

Agatha got up and dressed, the familiar ache of rejection settling in her chest. She tried to shake it off, but she couldnâ€™t ignore the sting. Rio hadnâ€™t waited to watch her. Â

Agatha stared at her, her chest tightening as Rio continued.

Â 

â€œShe sees him every night.â€

Â 

And honestly, that was maybe one of the worst answers Agatha could have received. Now she had to face the truth she had been avoiding. Not only had she kept Nicky from Rio, but even Sage had gotten to know him in a way Rio never could.

Â 

Rio had nothing. No memories to hold onto, no moments to cherish, no chance to love their son as a mother should. Agatha had made sure of that. Worse still, she had made Rio watch from a distance as she raised him. Agatha had drawn the line, keeping Rio on the other side, forced to witness fleeting glimpses of a life she would never be a part of.

Â 

Now, as the weight of it all came crashing down on her, Agatha couldnâ€™t hide from the truth any longer. She hadnâ€™t just taken Nicky from Rio.

Â 

She had taken everything, and there was no way to undo it.

Â 

Maybe I am evil.

Â 

Even with all this darkness consuming her, even with the weight of guilt and regret pressing down on her, there was a small light at the end of the tunnel. A small flicker of peace that threatened to claw its way through the storm inside her.

Nicky wasnâ€™t alone. He was at peace. He had his sister.

Â

Oh.

Â 

So thatâ€™s what it felt like. To have the title of mother stripped away as though it meant nothing. Words Agatha herself had thrown at Rio countless times, used to rip another piece of her away, to tarnish her, to remind her of what she wasnâ€™t allowed to have.

Â 

Agatha sat for a moment longer, then dragged herself to her feet, her body feeling as weighed down as her mind. She wandered toward the willow tree across the garden, not entirely sure why.

Â 

The memorial beneath the tree caught her attention immediately. The etched words were faded but unmistakably cared for. Â 

Agatha lowered herself to the ground, her legs folding beneath her. Eventually, she lay back, staring up through the branches of the tree as they swayed gently in the breeze. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Rioâ€™s hands were steady as she lathered the soap into Agathaâ€™s hair, her fingers working through the tangles with practiced care. The water cascaded over both of them, soaking Rioâ€™s clothes as she worked, but she didnâ€™t seem to care.

Â 

Agatha closed her eyes, her breathing unsteady. Rioâ€™s touch wasnâ€™t hurried or cold; it was tender in a way that felt overwhelming. It wasnâ€™t about intimacy or passion.

Â 

It was about care.

Â 

Once the water was off, Rio stepped out first, grabbing a towel and wrapping it around Agathaâ€™s shoulders. She dried her off, careful and methodical, before helping her into clean pajamas. Â 

Rio didnâ€™t speak, but her hands moved with the same care Agatha was beginning to associate with her. The rhythmic strokes of the brush felt oddly comforting, soothing in a way Agatha hadnâ€™t expected. She didnâ€™t protest, letting herself sink into the quiet intimacy of the moment.

Â

Â 

â€œMilfs who get drunk and scream at each other,â€ Rio said casually, her voice a little lighter. â€œTrash reality TV always makes everything better.â€

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t help the scoff that escaped her. For a brief moment, the corner of her mouth twitched upward. She didnâ€™t say anything, though, as her attention shifted to the screen.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t Agathaâ€™s kind of distraction, but it worked. The noise in her mind quieted. She didnâ€™t admit it out loud, but the show, and Rio beside her, made her feel a little better.

Â 

And Rio, lying next to her, didnâ€™t mention it either. They didnâ€™t need to.



â€”

Â 

If Agatha woke before the sun. The dim light of the early morning barely touched the room, and for a moment, she simply lay there, her gaze drifting over the familiar shadows. She turned her head slightly, only to see Rio stirring, slipping out of bed.

Â 

If Rio moved quietly, her steps soft as she disappeared into the bathroom. Agatha stayed still, her heart oddly steady in her chest as she listened to the faint sound of water running. When Rio returned, her movements were fluid as always, but when their eyes met, Rio faltered.

Â 

It was clear she hadnâ€™t expected Agatha to be awake. The surprise in her expression was brief, replaced quickly by a neutral calm, but it was enough to tell Agatha she wasnâ€™t the only one feeling uncertain.

Â 

And if Rio left the bedroom without a word, her steps purposeful but not hurried. Agatha hesitated for only a moment before following, not bothering to change out of her sleep clothes. The cool morning air hit her skin as she stepped outside, finding Rio standing across the garden beneath the willow tree, her back to Agatha.Â 

Â 

If Rio turned slowly, her eyes meeting Agathaâ€™s with a silent question, prodding gently, Are you sure?

Â 

Agatha gave a single nod, her voice only a whisper, â€œShow me.â€

Â 

If Rio held her gaze for a long moment before nodding in return. She turned, gesturing for Agatha to follow as she led the way to the stone memorial beneath the willow. Her movements were precise, her presence calm and steady as she began to show Agatha the care it required.

Â 

If Rioâ€™s words were soft, barely above a whisper, guiding Agatha through the motions. Rio showed her how to clear the grass, how to brush the dirt away without disturbing the stone, and how to make the space feel whole again. There was no rush, only a quiet, deliberate rhythm to her actions, as if each movement carried weight and purpose.

Â 

If Rio led Agatha to the patch of white lilies growing in the garden, she knelt, carefully selecting six blooms to trim. She placed them in Agathaâ€™s hands without a word, her gaze lingering for a moment before she stood again.

Â 

If they made their way back to the memorial, and for the first time, Agatha found herself kneeling beside Rio in front of the stone.

Â 

If Rio handed her a small braid of twine: one purple, one green, and one black seamlessly woven together. Her words remained soft as she guided Agatha through the process of tying it around the bouquet. The instructions were gentle, her tone steady in a way that made the moment feel sacred.

Â 

If when the bouquet was ready, Agathaâ€™s fingers trembled as she reached forward, placing it in the same spot sheâ€™d seen it before. The gesture felt heavier than sheâ€™d expected, the silence around them wrapping her in its quiet embrace.

Â 

If any of that had happened, it was no oneâ€™s business but Agathaâ€™s own.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Another week had passed in Rioâ€™s realm. Sage still hadnâ€™t returned from the surface, which left Agatha feeling torn. Some days she relished the quiet, grateful for the lack of interruptions. Other days, the stillness gnawed at her nerves, and sheâ€™d catch herself fidgeting, chewing the inside of her cheek. Her patience wore thin as she poked and prodded Rio for answers.

Â 

But Rio, unbothered as always, never had an answer. Never worried. Never seemed to wonder what their girl (practically flung out into the world like a newborn, wobbling and naive, with no one there to catch her if she falls) had been doing all this time.

Â 

Rio only ever offered a shrug, her hands perpetually occupied, â€œSheâ€™ll be fine.â€

Â 

Leaving Agatha in utter disbelief, every time.

Â 

Their days together fluctuated wildly. Some mornings were peppered with lazy conversations that came easy, as though the years of tension between them had dissolved. Other times, Rio seemed to make it her personal mission to see how far she could push Agatha before her temper flared.

Â 

It was always over the most trivial things, never serious, but maddening all the same. If Rio had lived another life as an author, her best-selling work would undoubtedly be titled:Â  Poking the Bear: A Beginnerâ€™s Manual.

Â 

One example: The Tea Incident.

Â 

Agatha leaned against the counter, her sharp eyes tracking Rioâ€™s every move like a hawk about to swoop. Her thumbnail hovered near her mouth, a nervous habit she hadnâ€™t quite shaken, as she watched Rio fumble around the stove.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re steeping it too long,â€ Agatha said, breaking the silence, â€œYouâ€™ll burn the leaves.â€

Â 

Rioâ€™s hand froze mid-stir, and her head snapped up. â€œI didnâ€™t realize you were a tea expert,â€ she said, deadpan, though the slight lift of her brow betrayed her amusement.

Â 

Lie.

Â 

That was a lie, and they both knew it. This was an argument older than either of them cared to admit.Â  Rio had always been shit at making tea, and Agatha, the perfectionist that she is, had long since mastered it.

Â 

â€œAnd I didnâ€™t realize you enjoyed drinking dirt water,â€ Agatha shot back without missing a beat.

Â 

With an exaggerated clatter, Rio dropped the spoon into the pot and spun to face her. She threw her hands up dramatically, her voice dripping with mock sincerity.

Â 

â€œOh, forgive me, Your Highness,â€ Rio said, pressing a hand to her chest like she was delivering a heartfelt apology. â€œQueen of All Things Proper. Care to bless me with your divine technique?â€ She gestured grandly to the pot, stepping aside like a performer leaving the stage.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t hesitate. She stepped forward, shoving Rio aside with zero ceremony. â€œItâ€™s not my fault you lack basic skills.â€

Â 

Rio, unbothered, leaned back against the counter, her grin beginning to break through.Â  It was only a matter of time before her stupid tongue pressed into her stupid cheek. â€œItâ€™s tea, Agatha, not brain surgery.â€

Â 

â€œWatching you make tea is like losing brain cells in real time,â€ Agatha fired back, expertly taking over the task with practiced ease.

Â 

Rio tilted her head. And there it is. That smug expression settling in place as she pressed her tongue into her cheek. â€œYouâ€™re awfully bold for someone standing this close to a pot of hot water.â€

Â 

â€œThreatening me wonâ€™t change the fact that youâ€™re incompetent,â€ Agatha said primly, but the corner of her mouth twitched.

Â 

They never knew what each new day would bring during Sageâ€™s absence. It was always different, unpredictable, yet somehow they both found themselves silently looking forward to whatever the next day would hold.

Â 

Though two things remained the same each day.

Â 

Every morning, just before dawn, Rio would nudge Agatha awake. Theyâ€™d wordlessly rise and tend to Nickyâ€™s memorial. Rioâ€™s soft instructions from their first time doing this together no longer needed repeating; Agatha had memorized every detail. Some mornings they worked side by side, the quiet broken only by the sounds of their task. Other mornings, Rio would leave her to it, giving Agatha space to breathe in the absence of chaos. And then, routinely, theyâ€™d move on, as if those moments had never happened.

Â 

Every night ended the same way, too. Agatha no longer slept on the couch. Instead, she found herself in bed with Rio.

Â 

Always in silence, always at a distance.

Â 

Rioâ€™s intentions were clear: to keep her close but never too close. Whatever intimacy had sparked between them before seemed to have been extinguished the day Rio had refused her a kiss. No lingering touches. No hungry eyes. Just silence.

Â 

Some nights, Agatha accepted it without complaint, understanding the unspoken boundaries Rio was trying to hold. Other nights, it tore at her, the distance so tangible it made her skin prickle. Sheâ€™d fight the urge to demand something, anything, from Rio. A kiss, a touch, even the brush of a pinky against hers. But Rio gave her nothing, and Agatha was left in the dark, trying to be okay with it.

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t dwell on it, refused to. It would ruin her.

Â 

One morning, Rio let Agatha help with her massive, sprawling garden. Agatha wasnâ€™t exactly skilled, but Rio, an endless source of knowledge on botany, showed her the ropes. Agatha wasnâ€™t the most attentive student, her patience often frayed by Rioâ€™s unrelenting corrections, but there was something about the rhythm of planting and pruning that she didnâ€™t mind.

Â 

Another day, Agatha stumbled upon the study, hidden behind two large sliding doors. Sunlight streamed through oversized windows, illuminating walls covered in ceiling to floor bookshelves, each shelf packed to capacity. The desk in the center was covered in a chaotic sprawl of books and papers. It didnâ€™t take long for Agatha to realize this room was frequented by both Rio and Sage.

Â 

Though, judging by the state of disarray, it was mainly used by Sage. The organized chaos bore a striking resemblance to the state of Sageâ€™s bedroom.

Â 

While surveying the room, Agathaâ€™s attention was caught by a large glass enclosure. Empty. When she noticed it, Rio casually explained that Petunia, her tarantula, often roamed the garden freely.

Â 

Each day felt different, unfamiliar, but somehow grounding in its own strange way.

Â 

One particular day, after a morning coffee made by Rio, not tea.

Â 

Thank god.

Â 

Agatha found herself in Rioâ€™s bedroom with an overwhelming urge to snoop. And snoop she did.

Â 

Most of it was uninteresting, little glimpses of Rioâ€™s life that didnâ€™t reveal much. But then her eyes landed on the bedside table. Her heart skipped.

Â 

Every so often, Agatha would catch Rio sketching in that damn notebook, the one she always kept close. Agatha would never willingly admit to being nosy, but here she was, ripping the drawer open. Her fingers reached for the sketchbook, but something else caught her eye. Tucked into a corner, nearly hidden, were two rings on a string.

Â 

One was carved from bone, its surface smooth and worn, the inside etched in delicate cursive: In You, I Begin.

Â 

The other was dark wood, faintly polished, its inscription reading: In Death, I Remain.

Â 

Agatha froze, her breath catching in her throat.

Â 

Rio hadnâ€™t wanted rings. That had been entirely Agathaâ€™s idea. They meant something to Agatha at one point. They were symbols of a love that could withstand the weight of time. And Rio, who would have moved mountains for her, had made them anyway.

Â 

She could remember Rioâ€™s hands, rough and careful, spending weeks crafting them. Dozens of prototypes discarded until Rio finally got it right. The words, too, were plucked from their spoken commitment, vows Agatha barely remembers now.

Â 

And yet, Rio had kept them.

Â 

The wood ring had been Agathaâ€™s. She had worn it the first day of Nickyâ€™s life, a small, private gesture to keep them all close. She thought it might bring Rio comfort, as if wearing it was a gift. But by the next day, sheâ€™d gotten rid of it. She didnâ€™t even remember how or where, only that she couldnâ€™t endure it. It was too much. Too heavy. Too painful.

Â 

Now, here they were, resting quietly in the corner of a drawer.

Â 

Agatha picked them up, cradling them in her hand. She expected the touch to burn, to hurt, and it did. But not in the way she thought it would. There was no hatred there, only regret. A soft ache that settled into her chest like an old bruise. It hurt, but it wasnâ€™t suffocating.

Â 

She held the rings a moment longer before tucking them back into the drawer, her fingers lingering over the smooth surface of the bone. And then, quietly, she closed it.

Â 

Agatha left Rioâ€™s bedroom, her mind still a little hazy, and wandered toward the study. She swept her gaze across the towering bookshelves, overwhelmed by the sheer number of books lining the walls. The abundance of knowledge, so carefully collected, made her head spin. On a whim, she plucked a book at random from the shelf, not even glancing at the title, and headed straight to the backyard.

Â 

She planted herself in her usual seat at the table, the one where she often sat to watch Rio from a distance. But today, watching from afar was not enough.

Â

She did not bother muting her irritation, grumbling under her breath about the length of the walk and cursing the effort it took to move the chair. By the time she reached the pond, she was out of breath and muttering a stream of inappropriate language.

Â 

With dramatic flair, Agatha plopped the chair down with a heavy thump, the sound scraping against the stones as she planted herself directly across from where Rio knelt. The green witch was carefully cleaning natural debris from the waterâ€™s surface.

Â

Â

Or maybe, proving someone else (definitely Agatha) wrong. Every inch of this garden was Rioâ€™s quiet rebellion, her way of showing that Death could do more than take. She could create life, nurture it, and make it beautiful. The garden stood as the perfect complement to the ultimate proof: the daughter she has raised so successfully.

Â

A quiet huff of laughter escaped her as she shook her head slightly, as if trying to make sense of the situation. Â

Â 

The book was a literary nonfiction about the sea, filled with poetic reflections on tides, marine life, and the mysteries of the deep.

The color of her hair was lighter here, and her entire appearance seemed eerily human. Her energy, once daunting and otherworldly, now breathed life.

She dragged her eyes away from the TV, landing them on Agatha. Her face remained neutral, the question seemingly not fazing her.

Â 

She said nothing, only shrugged and returned her attention to the TV, her expression unchanged as she resumed scrolling.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t press for an answer. She was fine with the silence. After all, she was a smart woman. Sheâ€™d already somewhat pieced together the answer herself. Maybe she just wanted Rio to say it. Or maybe, deep down, she wanted Rio to know that she had noticed. That she was watching and lingering, just as Rio always had been.

Â 

Still, the question lingered in her mind. Was this change in Rioâ€™s appearance a personal choice, an intentional step toward appearing more human, despite her existence as a cosmic entity? Or was it this place itself. Once a vast, endless green void now brimming with life that had subtly transformed Rio? Perhaps it wasnâ€™t a choice at all, but a natural consequence of this world overflowing with so much vitality that even Death herself couldnâ€™t help but appear more human, a little less cosmic, than she had since the beginning of time.

Â 

Agatha pulls her thoughts away from the memory and turns back to her book.

Â 

Everything seemed normal, dangerously close to peaceful, until Agatha caught a shift in Rioâ€™s posture. She froze in place, hands pausing in the process of picking vegetables. Slowly, Rio leaned back, resting back on to her calves, as her hands lie gently on top of her thighs. Her shoulders slumped, the usual calm on her face melting into something heavier, something fragile. Her brows furrowed as she stared at the ground, her expression weighted with quiet heartbreak.

Â 

Agatha jerked upright, planting her feet firmly on the ground. Her grip on the arms of her chair turned iron clad, knuckles white with tension. The sudden movement sent Petunia scurrying away, but Agatha didnâ€™t notice.

Â 

â€œWhat?â€ Her voice cut sharply through the air, loud and demanding.

Â 

Rioâ€™s gaze rose slowly to meet hers. Her brown eyes, filled with sorrow, locked onto Agathaâ€™s.

Â 

â€œI have to go.â€

Â 

The words hit harder than Agatha was expecting. She knew what Rio meant. She was being called in to work, and somehow, Agatha had let herself forget that this was still part of Rioâ€™s life. Anger flared hot and unrelenting in her chest. How could she have been so stupid?

Â 

Rio stood, stepping carefully over the line of vegetables and moving closer to her. Agatha mirrored her, rising from the chair.

Â 

â€œNo.â€

Â 

â€œAgatha.â€ Rioâ€™s voice was soft, her tone carrying the faintest hint of a warning.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s fists clenched at her sides, nails biting into her palms. Her face twisted as she fought to keep her emotions in check. The questions came unbidden, clawing at her mind , ready to break free at any moment. What was so significant that Rio needed to step in? Or worse, what was so terrible that Rio had chosen to handle it herself?

Â 

â€œWhat happened?â€ Agatha blurted out, her voice a rush of desperation. Her eyes searched Rioâ€™s face for answers, for any sign that this was something minor. It was never minor. But Rioâ€™s expression didnâ€™t falter. There was only sorrow.

Â 

Still, the name slipped from Agathaâ€™s lips, unbidden and trembling. â€œSage? Is sheâ€¦ sheâ€™s okay?â€

Â 

The words carried no accusation, no bitterness. Only a raw, pleading need for reassurance. Agatha hoped Rio could see how hard she was trying, how much she was holding herself back. She wanted to scream, to grab Rio by the collar of her shirt and demand, â€˜ Donâ€™t you dare do this to me again.â€™

Â 

I donâ€™t even know her yet, the thought screaming at Agatha.

Â 

But Rio didnâ€™t flinch. Her eyes softened, holding a quiet understanding that caught Agatha off guard.

Â 

â€œSheâ€™s fine.â€ Rioâ€™s voice did not waver andÂ  it was infuriatingly neutral. Itâ€™s the tone she always used when she was beginning to slip into her role as Death, and Agatha hated it. She gritted her teeth, swallowing back the urge to grab her and beg her not to change.

Â 

Not yet.

Â 

â€œYou donâ€™t know that,â€ Agatha said, her voice biting, though the anger faded at the edges.

Â 

â€œBelieve me. I do.â€ Rioâ€™s reply was quiet but firm, her eyes locked onto Agathaâ€™s as if anchoring herself there. The weight in her gaze felt like the only thing keeping Rio grounded, drowning in the endless sea of Agathaâ€™s blue eyes.

Â 

â€œPromise me,â€ Agatha whispered, the words barely audible but heavy with demand.

Â 

Rioâ€™s shoulders sank, and her gaze faltered.â€œIâ€¦â€ Her voice cracked, quiet and fragile, before growing steadier. â€œI would feel it. I know I would.â€ She pressed a hand to her chest, absentmindedly rubbing at the spot with a heavy palm, seeming to try and reassure herself. Remind herself. â€œBut I canâ€™t promise that.â€

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t scream, didnâ€™t shout, didnâ€™t push for a promise Rio couldnâ€™t make. She had learned that lesson the hard way. Instead, she reached into the pocket of her pants and grasped her brooch, squeezing it tightly in her hand. Agatha inhaled deeply, letting the shaky breath out through her nose.

Â 

She nodded once.

Â 

Taking a slight angled step back, so she could let Rio go. But Rio didnâ€™t move. She stood there, lingering still so close to Agatha. Her brown eyes softened, and for a moment, it looked like she wanted to kiss her before she went.

Â 

Agatha would have let her. She wanted her to.

Â 

They both wanted it. To pour everything into the otherâ€™s mouth, to taste every last inch of each other before Rio left. Before Rio might once again stoke the fire Agatha had torn herself apart to calm. The fire that had raged within her for centuries, consuming everything in its path. For the first time in so long, it had finally quelled some. But now it felt like they were only seconds, moments, or days away from reigniting it completely. Flames that, once caught, would burn out of control and never be extinguished.

Â 

But Rio didnâ€™t kiss Agatha. The absence of it might have shattered her, if not for the piercing gaze of Rioâ€™s brown eyes. They held something unspoken, a quiet assurance that she wasnâ€™t leaving forever,Â  that she would not return bearing the weight of their daughterâ€™s soul guided to the afterlife. They had time. For now, they all still had time.

Â 

But it could not be a promise.

Â 

Agatha unwillingly tore her eyes away from Rioâ€™s and stepped aside, out of the green witchâ€™s path entirely. Her gaze dropped to the cobblestone below, unable to watch her go just yet. All she caught was the passing sight of Rioâ€™s dirt-covered white shoes as they moved steadily down the gardenâ€™s path.

Â 

Once out of her direct line of sight, Agathaâ€™s head turned to the right, her eyes trailing Rio as she walked away. With every step, Rio stood taller, her strides growing more confident, more deliberate. Agatha felt her stomach twist as she watched the transformation. Gone was her Rio, the one in the familiar navy crewneck and gray shorts, with dirt smudged across her legs and hands, her hair that natural, earthy brown Agatha never got to see on the surface.

Â 

In her place was Death. The long, two toned black cloak flowed behind her, trailing like shadows in her wake. It hung softly off her shoulders, revealing that sinfully beautiful top that exposed more and more skin the longer Agatha looked. Her hair was now pitch black and Deathâ€™s crown rested atop her head. Death pulled the hood over herself with practiced ease.

Â 

The only parts of Death still visible were the tips of her three fingers, sharp with clip-on metal nails. Her right hand gripped her dagger tightly. In her left hand, she loosely held a single lily between her fingers, its stark white petals trembling slightly in the breeze.

Â 

A green portal suddenly tore through the air in front of her. Without hesitation, Death strode toward it, her movements fluid and sure. She didnâ€™t stop to look back, didnâ€™t throw Agatha one last glance. Agatha knew she wouldnâ€™t. Rio would never taint the fragile peace they had just begun to rebuild with the face of Death. She wouldnâ€™t allow it.

Â 

In the blink of an eye, Lady Death was gone, and the portal vanished with her, leaving only the faintest trace of green light behind.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Agatha spent the first hour pacing the length of the living room, her steps quick and uneven, her arms crossed tightly over her chest. Every few minutes, her eyes darted to the clock on the wall, the minutes dragging by at a maddeningly slow pace. Thereâ€™s really no sense of time here but Rio did everything possible to give balance to a daughter who had defied its existence.

Â 

Her thoughts spun out of control, latching onto worst case scenarios. She imagined Rio returning sickly and hollowâ€¦ Worse, returning with a weight impossible for either of them to bear. The idea made her stomach twist, and she had to stop, pressing the heels of her palms against her eyes hoping to steady herself.

Â 

Eventually, she forced herself to sit, plopping onto the couch with a huff and snatching the remote from the table. Agatha needed a distraction, something mindless, and landed on The Real Housewives of New York City . She told herself it was just background noise, but thirty minutes later, she found herself yelling at the TV, her outrage at petty arguments momentarily replacing her worry. It worked until she caught herself gripping the remote too tightly, her knuckles white, the stress sneaking back in as an unwelcome guest.

Â 

By the fourth hour, Agatha was on her feet again, pacing from one end of the room to the other. She stayed away from Rioâ€™s bedroom, unwilling to step inside the space where the green witchâ€™s presence still lingered. It felt too intimate, too much like an admission of how desperately she wanted Rio back. Instead, she planted herself in the living room, pacing, stopping only to stare out the window as though expecting to see Rio stride through the garden at any moment. Her mind cycled endlessly between imagining what Rio might be doing and reprimanding herself for the sheer absurdity of her own restlessness.

Â 

At one point, Agatha sat down again, Housewives still playing on the screen, but her attention was scattered. Her fingers itched for something to do, so she picked Sageâ€™s book just to open. Immediately it was too much.Â  She snaps it closed and her are thoughts wandering to Rio again. She caught herself mid thought, hissing under her breath at her own impatience. â€œEight hours,â€ she muttered. â€œItâ€™s been eight damn hours.â€ But the weight in her chest felt far heavier than that, as if time itself had stretched into something excruciating.

Â 

And so, the cycle continued- pacing, yelling at the TV, not reading Sageâ€™s book, sitting in restless silence. All while the clock ticked endlessly on, mocking her. Waiting for Rio and perhaps Sage was agony.

Â 

Two and a half hours later, Agatha stalled mid pace behind the couch in the living room, her breath hitching as she heard the front door creak open. The sound froze her in place. Seeing either of the two women walk through that door would be a relief, but she couldnâ€™t shake the heavy weight in her chest.

Â 

Rio had never promised it wasnâ€™t Sage.

Â 

The moment felt endless as the door clicked shut. When Rio stepped into the foyer, Agathaâ€™s breath caught in her throat.

Â 

Only two things were different from when she last saw her. Rio wore the same outfit as before she left, the same streaks of dirt smudging her legs and hands. But her hair was down, black and long as ever, the sun kissed shorter brown completely gone. Her eyes were sunken, dark circles stark against her tanned skin, and her cheeks were hollow, carved with exhaustion. She looked like a shell of herself, hollow and drained.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s mouth fell open slightly, her heart twisting at the sight. The stark change in Rioâ€™s appearance stunned and wrenched her all at once. Before she could even form the thought, Rio answered the question burning in her mind.

Â 

â€œSheâ€™s okay,â€ Rio said, her voice low, a little scratchy.

Â 

The words hit Agatha like a wave, and the tension she had been carrying for hours drained from her body. She physically deflated, her shoulders sinking as some of the weight lifted. But the relief was fleeting, eclipsed by the sight of Rio standing there, looking utterly broken.

Â 

It was fucking heartbreaking.

Â 

Without another word, Rio turned and headed to the bedroom. Agatha stood frozen, her eyes following her until she disappeared down the hall. She heard the shower turn on moments later and stayed rooted in place, unsure of what to do. Did Rio need her space? Did she want to be left alone? Agatha chose to wait, sitting on the couch with the TV playing softly in the background, her mind focused entirely on the green witch behind that closed door.

Â 

When the shower turned off, Agatha strained to listen for Rioâ€™s quiet footsteps moving through her bedroom as she got ready for bed. She was on edge, hoping the sound of the door opening would follow. Then, like the universe had answered her silent prayers, she heard it.

Â 

Rio stepped out, her bare feet padding softly down the hall toward the living room. She was dressed in a a silk tank top and matching sleep shorts, her hair still damp.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s mouth waters at the sight.

Â 

Folded clothes were neatly tucked in her arms. Her face still looked sunken, her under eyes dark, but there was a slight shift in her energy, a faint crack of light breaking through the heaviness.

Â 

Agatha tracked Rioâ€™s every move as she came to a stop beside the couch, her presence grounding in its quiet simplicity. Rio looked down at Agatha where she sat, setting the folded pajamas on the cushion beside her, almost like an offering. Then, she extended a hand.

Â 

Agatha looks up at Rio like sheâ€™s an angel sent to take her to heaven, and the irony isnâ€™t lost on her.


This was so fucking humiliating. A real knock to the ego.

Â 

Agatha isnâ€™t the one in control here. She isnâ€™t reclaiming her power or standing tall. Sheâ€™s surrendering everything to Rio. Completely.

Â 

The tension in the room wraps around them, thick and intimate, and Agatha is a melting puddle at the center of it. What unsettles her most is how freeing it feels.

Â 

Surrendering like this, which has literally never happened in the history of them , doesnâ€™t feel like losing. It feels like breathing. Like Agathaâ€™s been deprived of oxygen her entire life and didnâ€™t even realize it until now. Until this moment, in death, with Rio standing before her, she finally feels the air rush in.

Â 

Agatha mentally curses herself for always being so damn ironic.

Â 

Her hand moves on instinct, sliding into Rioâ€™s cold one without hesitation. Sheâ€™s already halfway there, her body acting before her mind can catch up, her fingers curling into Rioâ€™s the moment they shift downward.

Â 

Rio gives a slight tug to signal Agatha to stand, and Agatha complies without a second thought, rising from the couch with zero hesitation. The moment she stands, Rioâ€™s hand drops away, leaving Agatha nearly whimpering at the loss. Her chin dips instinctively, searching for Rioâ€™s eyes.

Â 

Those eyes are hungry and dark, nearly black, dive into her without restraint, like plunging into an endless ocean of blue. A flicker of hazel seeps through, betraying the smallest falter in Rioâ€™s composure, as if the sheer intensity of their gaze had momentarily unsettled her.

Â 

Agatha realizes that Rio needs this as much, if not more, than she does. This isnâ€™t about power. Itâ€™s about Rio regaining a piece of herself. Whatever had shaken her in those hours she was away, this was her way of grounding herself, of proving she hadnâ€™t lost everything she was. She still had control, still had strength, still had Agatha. For once, Agatha wasnâ€™t just willing but eager to let Rio take. To give her the space to rebuild, to feel whole again, even if just for a moment.

Â 

Then, Agatha feels Rioâ€™s hands at her waist, gentle but firm, adjusting her so she stands directly in front of her, no longer slightly adjacent. In one swift motion, Rio untucks Agathaâ€™s blouse from her pants, her fingers brushing the fabric before retreating. Agatha feels the absence acutely, her breath catching in her throat as Rioâ€™s gaze, practically dripping with filth, locks onto her.

Â 

All Agatha can do is stand and await further instruction, entirely at Rioâ€™s mercy.

Â 

Rioâ€™s hands move next, reaching up to begin unbuttoning Agathaâ€™s blouse. Each movement is slow, deliberate, and methodical, her steady hands working with a precision that leaves Agatha speechless. Years of tending gardens, planting, and crafting have paid off. Rioâ€™s hands are one of Agathaâ€™s favorite things about her. Theyâ€™re always moving, always steady, always purposeful. They itch to create, to touch, just as Agathaâ€™s own hands itch to take, and take, and take some more.

Â 

When Rio finishes with the last button, she pushes the blouse off Agathaâ€™s shoulders in one fluid motion, never once touching her skin. The fabric slides down Agathaâ€™s arms and pools at her feet, the ghost of Rioâ€™s presence more unbearable than any contact.

Â 

Itâ€™s brutal. Agatha feels like sheâ€™s practically on the verge of tears from the sheer desperation clawing at her chest. The tension fills the space between them, thick and electric, leaving Agatha completely at Rioâ€™s control.

Â 

Rioâ€™s gaze immediately locked onto the delicate white lace of the push up bra laid out with her clothes that morning with matching underwear, both carefully chosen. Her hands hovered next, hesitating at the button of Agathaâ€™s pants. Agatha barely noticed the cold, fleeting brush of Rioâ€™s fingers; it was clear she was making an effort not to let their skin meet.

Â 

Frustrated by the distance, Agatha tilted her hips forward, silently urging Rio to bridge the gap. But just as Agatha moved, Rio was quicker. Her hand darting back the moment Agatha tried. The button came undone, but the zipper remained untouched, leaving Agatha teetering on the edge of impatience.

Â 

Suddenly, Rio speaks, her tone firm yet disarmingly sweet. â€œTurn around.â€

Â 

Agatha hesitates, but only for a heartbeat. The hesitation isnâ€™t defiance; itâ€™s the reluctance of an addict unwilling to tear her gaze from what she craves most, Rioâ€™s face. The moment passes, and she gives in, letting Rioâ€™s words guide her.

Â

That simple response made Sageâ€™s face light up like a Christmas tree. It wasnâ€™t an outright no from Agatha Harkness, and for Sage, that was enough.

Â 

â€œCheckmate,â€ Agatha said, her tone casual.

Â 

â€œFuck,â€ Sage muttered under her breath.

Â 

Agatha pretended not to notice that Sage had let her win.

Chapter End Notes

i had the first half of this chapter written for the last two days. but the conversation between sage and agatha, i shit you not chat, TOOK ME ALL DAY TO WRITE! my brain is literally fried so if it seems a little messy i apologize.

a long time ago, my hs freshman english teacher read my paper and told me, â€œthis is good, but you need to invest in a thesaurus.â€ and i have thought ab it everyday since i began writing this lmaoâ€¦.. i fear sheâ€™s still right thoughâ€¦.

ALSO im just a girl, please be kind. i appreciate all the kudos and comments more than you know and i promise to get to them at some point (probably tomorrow)

whatever she wants

The weeks leading up to Sageâ€™s birthday. Had been interesting to say the least, everyday different than the last.

Â 

Rio and Agatha were in the garden, and Rio was droning on about the delicate art of planting azaleas. She spoke with the kind of enthusiasm that only Rio could muster, her hands moving expertly through the soil as she explained every step. Agatha, crouched awkwardly nearby, had no idea why sheâ€™d agreed to this.

Â 

Well, she did know, but she wasnâ€™t about to admit that to herself, much less to Rio.

Â 

It definitely wasnâ€™t because of the kiss theyâ€™d shared a few days ago. No, the two of them hadnâ€™t been acting like lovesick fools since then, stealing glances, brushing hands, sharing secret smiles like they were caught in some ridiculous romantic comedy.

Â 

Of course not.

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t even begin to unpack the flower situation.

Â 

It began with an aster. â€œFor patience,â€ Rio had said with a knowing smile as she set it on the table. Agatha had scoffed, muttered something sarcastic, but kept it anyway. The next day it was a camellia. â€œFor courage.â€ By the third day, Agatha had stopped pretending to be annoyed.

Â 

Now every morning, Rio brought a new flower, each a different meaning. Agatha grumbled and teased, but the growing collection on her windowsill told a different story.

Â 

She was being wooed and she would never admit it, but it was working.

Â

She didnâ€™t trust herself not to act like a reckless hormonal teenager chasing after a crush, or worse, to sabotage the fragile progress sheâ€™d made with both Rio and Sage.

Â 

When Agatha brought it up that night after Sage came home, she couldnâ€™t stomach the sad look in Rioâ€™s eyes. Rio thought sheâ€™d done something wrong. But Agatha quickly explained herself, and that sadness shifted into a quiet understanding.

Â 

Agatha had spent so long running, so long alone, that she didnâ€™t know how to just be . To live without chasing chaos, without creating it, without letting it consume her. Sheâ€™d never stayed still for this long (excluding that one scarlet colored incident when her mind hadnâ€™t exactly been her own for three years). And this calm, this steadinessâ€¦ it was strange. Â

Â

Â 

â€œNo, Iâ€™m not,â€ Agatha shot back, a little too quickly.

Â 

Rio turned her head away from the plant, her hands pausing in the soil. Her eyes traced Agatha slowly, moving from head to knees before traveling back up to meet her gaze. The faintest smirk tugged at her lips as she gave a small nod and said, â€œOkay.â€

Â 

Rio went back to tending the azalea, her hands moving, methodically, as if nothing had just happened. Agatha, on the other hand, felt like she was about to burst. Â

Â 

â€œAnd if I am staring?â€ Agatha said suddenly.

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t stop herself from rolling her eyes. What were they? Children? She didnâ€™t need to say it out loud. The context was painfully obvious. In what world would Agatha Harkness, of all people, be kneeling in the dirt learning how to plant a flower?

Â 

â€œSomething on your mind?â€ Rioâ€™s voice broke through her thoughts, stoic as always. She wasnâ€™t looking at Agatha, her attention fixed on the azalea.

Â

Â 

This made Rio finally pause and look up, her brows furrowing slightly as she sat back on her heels. Her brown eyes widened just enough to show her confusion as she watched Agatha practically attack the soil.

Â 

â€œYou sure?â€

Â 

Agatha stopped digging, her chest tightening as she glanced at Rio. â€œWhat do you want me to say, Rio?â€ she snapped.

Â 

The tension in the air thickened as she stilled, mimicking Rioâ€™s movements and sitting back on her heels. Her fingers gripped the trowel tightly, her knuckles whitening as she struggled to contain the frustration boiling under her skin.

Â
