Â 

Agatha clenched her jaw, her fingers tightening even more around the trowel as she tried to come up with a response that wouldnâ€™t betray the storm brewing inside her. Rioâ€™s steady gaze wasnâ€™t helping, it never did. That calm, unshakable presence was maddening, especially when Agatha felt anything but calm.

â€œWhatever you say, Agatha.â€ The disappointment in Rioâ€™s voice was subtle, but it still made Agathaâ€™s stomach twist. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s head snapped up, her eyes meeting Rioâ€™s in surprise. â€œHypothetically?â€ she asked, her voice softer now, the tension in her chest easing just slightly.

Â

Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s shoulders straightened, a flicker of her usual confidence returning. Â 

Rio raised an eyebrow, her smile widening slightly as she leaned back, â€œWellâ€¦â€ she drawled, letting the moment hang for just a second longer than necessary. â€œHypothetically, a lady doesnâ€™t kiss and tell. Â 

Agathaâ€™s breath caught for a brief moment, but her smirk only grew, her confidence solidifying. â€œGood to know,â€ she murmured, leaning in just slightly, her voice and eyes dropping to something softer. â€œIâ€™m gonna kiss you, now. Not hypothetically.â€

Â 

â€œPlease,â€ Rio whispered, her voice barely audible, her eyes fixed on Agathaâ€™s lips.

Â 

And then Agatha closed the gap, her lips meeting Rioâ€™s in a kiss that was soft but firm, like every moment had been leading to this one. Rio responded instantly, her lips warm and unhurried, matching Agathaâ€™s tenderness.

Â

Â 

Agatha blinked, a flicker of surprise crossing her face before it was replaced by a confident grin. â€œOh, I will,â€ she promised, her voice low and full of intent.

Â

Â 

The air between them shifted, lighter but still humming with unspoken promises.

Â 

Agatha lay in her bed, staring at the ceiling. It had been a few days since her unexpected date in the garden with Rio, and yet the memory still lingered, casting a lightness over her days that she had not felt in longer than she could remember.

Â 

It was a strange predicament to spend what felt like a trillion years grieving not just her son but also the love of her life, only to find herself here. She had spent so long running, never stopping, hoping that if enough time passed she might forget. Forget the pain, the love, the ache of everything she had lost.

Â 

But who was she kidding? That was no way to live.

Â 

Not that she regretted it. If she was being honest, some of those years had been fun. Agatha smirked faintly at the thought. Some people deserved the wrath she had unleashed on them. And if it kept her from falling apart, even just a little, who could blame her?

Â 

Still, as she stared at the ceiling, the weight of her choices pressed on her. Running had kept her alive, but it had not made her whole. And now, with Rio back in her life and Sage being Sage, she could not help but wonder if she had finally found something worth staying still for.

Did Agatha want to get her purple back? Absolutely, she did. If she could, she would. It wasnâ€™t just magic- it was her. A part of her identity, her power, her essence. The loss of it felt like losing a piece of herself, and if she had the chance to reclaim it, she wouldnâ€™t hesitate.



But if someone were to ask what sheâ€™d do with it, Agatha wouldnâ€™t have an answer. She could go back to the surface, wreak havoc, massacre a few people, and fall into the same endless cycle. She wouldnâ€™t mind it. In fact, it might even be fun for a while. But for whatever stupid, infuriating reason, she didnâ€™t crave it anymore. The hunger that once clawed at her from the inside, gnawing at her ribs and demanding more, had gone quiet.

Â 

She wondered if it would come back with just a taste. Would the chaos inside her wake up, roaring for more? Or was it gone for good?

Â 

She didnâ€™t know.

Â 

What she did know was that whenever the thought of power crept into her mind, it was when she was around Sage. She found herself wishing she could show Sage, wondering what the girl would think of her at her peak. Sage was brilliant. Insanely brilliant. Agatha could sense it now more than ever, this quiet, coiled strength beneath Sageâ€™s sharp wit and sarcastic remarks. It was there, waiting, and Agatha wasnâ€™t sure if Sage even realized how strong she truly was.

Â 

She knew the girlâ€™s magic, its unique color burned into her memory. It wasnâ€™t fully black, though that was its base. It shimmered just enough to almost appear gray, but there was more to it than that. Agatha couldnâ€™t quite explain it, but the best way to describe it was this: if green and purple were locked in a constant battle, their energies intertwining and fighting for dominance, creating something entirely new in their struggle. It wasnâ€™t just a color, it was alive, shifting, almost breathing.

Â 

It was beautiful, unlike anything Agatha had ever seen, and impossible to define. It had a depth and complexity that felt like it held secrets, just out of reach. It was Sageâ€™s magic, and it suited her perfectly.

Â 

Agatha hardly ever saw Sage practice magic. There were the occasional portals and the weather shifting with her moods, but nothing that hinted at the raw force Agatha could feel simmering beneath the surface. It made her itch to see it, that hidden power unleashed, like a tickle deep in her ribcage that she couldnâ€™t shake.

Â 

But it wasnâ€™t for siphoning purposes, not this time. Agatha had no interest in seeking Sageâ€™s magic for herself. She wanted to see her daughter in action, to see her be a witch. She wanted to be proud of her, to know that this extraordinary force of nature had come from her.

Â 

Rio knew it too. She could sense Sageâ€™s power in a way that made her proud. She would brag about Sageâ€™s intellect, recounting memories of teaching her practical magic as a child. Rio would share how Sage needed no more than a single explanation to understand a spell, though it often took a few tries to master it.

Â 

Agatha loved hearing these stories. Every word was like a glimpse into moments she had missed, moments she could never get back. Rio was unknowingly giving her a gift- a chance to imagine what it might have been like if she had been there. And, in a strange way, it was enough. Enough to make her feel like she belonged here, that she had a place in their lives, even if it was still unsteady.

Â 

But doubt always crept in, dragging guilt along with it. Nicky.

Â 

Agatha had known, from Rioâ€™s words weeks ago, that Sage saw him when she slept. But she couldnâ€™t bring herself to ask Sage about it. She couldnâ€™t ask what he was like, what he looked like, if he was happy. Was he truly at peace? Did peace even mean anything? Or was there something more, something after the afterlife?

Â 

These thoughts were too big, too heavy for her to hold. They churned in the back of her mind, questions she wasnâ€™t ready to face, not yet.

Â 

One day, maybe she would be ready to speak his name, to ask the questions clawing at her heart. But not yet. Not today. Today she would sit with the quiet joy Rioâ€™s stories brought her, let herself pretend that was enough. For now, it had to be.

Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s gaze swept over the garden. It wasnâ€™t just beautiful, it was balanced. A mixture of nature and intention. For all her jagged edges, Rio had poured so much softness into this space, and it showed.

Â

Rio was lounging against the headboard, dressed in an old t-shirt with a faded graphic of Audrey II from Little Shop of Horrors and a pair of worn sweatpants. Â

Â

â€œCan you tell me what that flower symbolizes?â€ Rio asked, her voice an only a whisper. The question felt deliberate, as though she needed confirmation. Like she had to be sure this wasnâ€™t just some random flower Agatha had plucked without thought.

Â 

Rio exhaled, a shaky and uneven breath. â€œOkay,â€ she whispered.

Â 

â€œIs that all youâ€™re going to say?â€ Agathaâ€™s voice cracked between frustration and desperation.

Â 

Rio looked down at her hands, her fingers fidgeting in her lap. â€œWhat do you want me to say, Agatha? That I regret everything? That I carry it every day, every hour, until I canâ€™t breathe?â€ She exhaled sharply, shaking her head. â€œBecause I do. I always have.â€

Â 

Though the words were whispered, they might as well have been shouted into an endless forest, echoing hundreds of years of brutal sorrow and being on the receiving end of unforgiving silence.

Â 

Oh.

Â 

Agatha hadnâ€™t prepared for this. She had offered what was meant to be a symbol of her regret, an apology. But Rio didnâ€™t see it that way. She didnâ€™t see it as a gesture of remorse, not as Agatha taking a step toward mending what had been broken. Rio saw it as something else entirely.

Â 

A pattern repeating itself.

Â 

The flower wasnâ€™t a bridge, it was a reminder. A thread woven into the same old tapestry of their history, where every hurt lingered unresolved, and every apology carried the shadow of justification. Agathaâ€™s careless words to Sage had torn at wounds neither of them dared to admit were still there. Centuries of pain buried, but never healed.

Â 

It was about the way Agatha had always bent their story to fit her own truth. Every argument, every disagreement, even before Nicky, had followed the same cycle. Agatha would twist the narrative, finding ways to make herself the victim or the righteous one, leaving Rio to bear the blame. It was never just one fight but the magnitude of them all.

Â 

And now, the flower felt like more of the same. Not an apology, but an expectation: that Rio would carry the weight of Agathaâ€™s guilt, her regret, her need for absolution. That Rio would be the one to make peace.

Â 

Iâ€¦â€ Agatha started, but the words caught in her throat. She swallowed hard, â€œI didnâ€™t mean-â€ She tried again, her voice trembling. â€œI-â€

Â 

Her words crumbled, a facade she spent centuries perfecting had completely shattered, as the sting of tears pricked her eyes.

Â 

Agatha swallowed hard, her fists clenched tightly in her lap, careful not to crush the flower in her grasp. It felt like she was waging a war within herself to summon the courage to speak. What finally gave her strength wasnâ€™t some sudden burst of determination. It was the look in Rioâ€™s eyes.

Â 

They were filled with a heartbreak so deep it was suffocating, sore, and undeniable. Agatha felt it like a dagger to her chest. She was completely shattered by it, couldnâ€™t handle the knowledge that she was the one who had caused it. She wouldnâ€™t be that person anymore.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s hands moved to tie the bouquet, her fingers deft from weeks of practice, but today they trembled uncontrollably. She clenched her teeth, trying to steady herself, but the twine slipped once, then twice. She froze, her frustration intensifying.

Â 

Sage shifted closer, her hand reaching out to rest gently atop Agathaâ€™s quivering ones. Agatha paused. Â

Â

Â 

Agatha froze, her fingers lingering on the stone. The words were from The Book Thief, a story narrated by Death itself. Hearing Sage speak them was a truth carving its place in Agathaâ€™s heart, refusing to leave.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha remained kneeling, her eyes locked on the engraved lyrics and the braided twine. The heaviness in her chest wasnâ€™t as piercing as it had been, but it didnâ€™t feel any easier to carry. Â 

After a while, Agatha returned to the house. As she stepped through the door, the sky seemed to shift. Heavy clouds rolled back in, relentless as ever. Sageâ€™s footsteps grew closer before the door creaked open. When it did, Agatha was met with a look in Sageâ€™s green eyes that struck her. It was far less vibrant than usual, distant, even. Â 

Outside, the sky was still heavy with clouds, but the sun made an attempt to push through, its rays faint but insistent. Agatha and Sage settled into their familiar game. They hadnâ€™t exchanged a single word. Sage won every round, but Agatha barely noticed. Her attention was drawn upward, to the battle unfolding in the sky. Â 

As the hours passed and the morning gave way to afternoon, Agatha noticed the change in Sage. It wasnâ€™t just grief; it was deeper. Â 

Agathaâ€™s heart tightened as she looked between the two conflicting forces above-sun and clouds at war- and then back to Sage.

Â 

The realization hit Agatha hard and severe.

Â 

Sage wasnâ€™t just sad. She was fighting. Fighting her sadness and her guilt as a child born from death. Sage was battling to bring light into a day heavy with grief and shadows, sacrificing her own peace, her own tranquility, just to offer Agatha a fleeting moment of warmth.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s chest ached at the thought. Sage wasnâ€™t just offering her a distraction. She was trying to give Agatha some peace, sacrificing her own in the process. The clouds have been relentless, the sunâ€™s light trying to persevere. With everything she had, Sage was trying to bring light to Agathaâ€™s darkest day.

Â 

For whatever reason, these people- despite her past mistakes, despite the ways she had hurt them or the cruel words sheâ€™d thrown- had chosen her. They sacrificed their own peace, stood by her through every storm she created, and still every day, they chose Agatha. It was always a choice made without hesitation.

Â 

How ironic it was that in death, she had experienced more life than she ever had on the surface.

Â 

The thought filled her lungs with so much air, she couldnâ€™t find it in herself to feel guilty about the weight of anything else.

Â 

Agatha caught Rioâ€™s gaze across the garden and tilted her head toward the patio, gesturing to the chair beside them. Â 

Rio sat quietly at first, observing the game of chess unfolding between them. After a few rounds, Rio leaned forward, frowning at a move Agatha had made. Without asking, she nudged the piece back and moved another in its place.

Â 

â€œThatâ€™s not how it works,â€ Agatha said, narrowing her eyes.

Â 

â€œIt is now,â€ Rio replied, unapologetic.

Â 

The silence that had settled over the garden broke with small comments and suggestions. Rio and Agatha became a team, united in their attempt to beat Sage. Â 

Sageâ€™s eyes looked lighter, her face filling out with every passing moment. Â She looked more like herself than she had all day.Â 

Â 

During one particularly tense game, Rio leaned back in her chair, arms crossed, brimming with confidence. â€œWeâ€™re gonna win.â€

Â 

â€œYouâ€™ve said that three times already,â€ Agatha replied dryly, not looking up.

Â 

â€œThis time, I mean it,â€ Rio said. â€œAnd Iâ€™m so sure of it, Iâ€™m willing to bet on it.â€

Â 

That perked Sageâ€™s interest immediately. Her wicked smirk spread slowly across her face, her tongue pressing into her cheek as she leaned forward, resting her elbows on the table. The excitement radiating from her was almost palpable.

Â 

Before Sage could speak, Agatha cut her off, her gaze darting to Rio. â€œOf all the expressions she couldâ€™ve inherited from you, it had to be that one.â€ She gestured toward Sageâ€™s smirk. â€œThe one that always pissed me off the most.â€

Â 

Rio held her hands up in mock innocence, her lips pressed tightly together as if to stifle a grin, fighting the urge to mirror the expression. Despite her effort, Agatha could see the faint outline of her tongue pressing against the inside of her cheek.

Agatha ignored it and tilted her head slightly, her eyes narrowing as she fixed them on Sage. â€œSo, whatâ€™s your wager?â€ she asked, her voice edged with challenge.

Â 

Sageâ€™s grin spread instantly. Without missing a beat, she replied, â€œLetâ€™s make it a true Daily Double, Alex.â€

Â 

Rio groaned, leaning back in her chair, â€œIf you think sheâ€™s insufferable during chess, try watching an episode of Jeopardy with her.â€

Â 

â€œIâ€™d rather sit in a locked room with my mother.â€

Â 

â€œSame,â€ Rio muttered, the corners of her lips twitching.

Â 

Sage ignored them entirely, her attention still fixed on Agatha. â€œIf I win, I want to see the ocean. Specifically, I want to go whale watching.â€

Â 

Agathaâ€™s head shot up, and she bit back the groan rising in her throat. She knew exactly where this conversation was headed.

Â 

â€œI donâ€™t see the issue,â€ Rio said with a shrug.

Â 

â€œIâ€™m not done,â€ Sage added, her grin turning down right shit eating. â€œThereâ€™s a nonnegotiable: You ,â€ she pointed a finger directly at Agatha. â€œAre coming.â€ She turned to Rio, the back of her hand covering her mouth with a theatrical whisper, loud enough for Agatha to hear. â€œWe have some unfinished business with the sea.â€

Â 

Rio raised an amused eyebrow, but Sage wasnâ€™t done. â€œAll of us. Tomorrow. Family vacation!â€ She practically sang the last two words.

Â 

Agatha crossed her arms, tossing her head back with an exasperated groan. The word family poked at something inside her that made her flinch. Â 

â€œIf thatâ€™s what you want, Petal,â€ Rio said softly.

Â 

â€œHell yes!â€ Sage shouted, slamming her fists on the table with so much enthusiasm it made both Rio and Agatha jump.

Â 

â€œAll right, relax,â€ Rio said, shaking her head.

Â 

They returned to the game and of course, they lost.

Â 

Later, Rio and Agatha lay side by side in the grass beneath the willow tree. The branches swayed gently above them, their hands loosely entwined between them. No words were spoken. They didnâ€™t need to be.

Â 

By the end of the night, they were all piled in the living room, watching an episode of Jeopardy.

Â 

Rio had been right.

Â

Â 

Rioâ€™s lips quirked into a smile. â€œI ask myself that every day.â€

Agatha shoved clothes into her duffel bag with barely contained annoyance. Three days. Their trip to the ocean wasnâ€™t just a day out, but a full three day excursion. She groaned at the thought. Of course, Rio had dropped that little detail casually earlier that morning, coffee in hand.

Â 

Agatha had been propped against the headboard, Sageâ€™s book open in her lap, when Rio breezed into the guest bedroom. Without so much as a preamble, Rio perched on the edge of the bed, handed Agatha her coffee, and, with that maddening calm of hers, mentioned the extended trip. Before Agatha could even form a response, Rio leaned in, pressed a kiss to her cheek, and strolled out of the room, leaving Agatha completely dumbfounded.

Â 

Now, the bag zipped shut, Agatha hefted it over her shoulder and stepped out of the bedroom. She made her way to the living room, dropping the bag beside the couch before flopping onto the cushions with an exaggerated sigh. Crossing her arms, settling in to wait for Rio and Sage, her irritation still simmering.

Â 

Rio appeared in the living room first, duffel bag in hand, along with a purse that immediately caught Agathaâ€™s attention. Rio was not a purse person, and Agatha made a mental note to ask about it later. In her other hand was a travel cup, but it wasnâ€™t the items Rio carried that made Agatha pause.

Â 

Rio was wearing jeans and an oversized black shirt that read â€œeveryone watches womenâ€™s sports,â€ paired with a neon orange WNBA baseball cap and white sneakers that looked far cleaner than the ones she wore in her garden. Agathaâ€™s mind froze at the sight, her breath catching in her throat.

Â 

Agatha could have jumped her right then and there. She even swiped at her chin to make sure she wasnâ€™t drooling.

Â 

Rio set her duffel bag down next to Agathaâ€™s and motioned for her to move over. Agatha obliged without a word, moving to make space. Rio dropped onto the couch beside her, sitting close enough that their legs touched. She placed the purse on Agathaâ€™s lap.

Â 

That makes more sense.

Â 

Though the gesture was simple, it made Agathaâ€™s heart soar. Of course, she pretended that it didnâ€™t.

Â 

Rio adjusted her position and reached into her back pocket, struggling for a moment before pulling out a wallet. She handed it to Agatha, who didnâ€™t need to open it to know whose it was. Rio wanted her to carry it for her. Agatha rolled her eyes but said nothing, placing the wallet inside the purse before setting it on the floor at her feet.

Â 

Once she settled, Rio handed her the travel cup. Agatha accepted it, their fingers brushing briefly. The moment the cup left Rioâ€™s hand, her palm fell to rest on Agathaâ€™s thigh. It was a casual touch, clearly unintentional, but Agatha still felt the heat rising low in her belly. Trying to distract herself, she took a sip from the cup and found that it was coffee. Of course it was. Rio always knew exactly what she needed.

Â 

Rio was testing her patience. One more sweet gesture or misplaced hand, and Agatha was ready to throw caution aside entirely and pounce on her like a feral cat in heat.

Â 

â€œYou look good,â€ Agatha said, her voice calm despite the turmoil in her head. She set the cup on the coffee table, noticing that Rioâ€™s hand hadnâ€™t moved. Agatha leaned back to study her, and Rio gave a small smile in return, her brown eyes shining with a warmth that felt blinding.

Â 

Agatha crossed her arms, resisting the urge to pull Rio closer and ruin that smile. Not that she would ruin it. More likely she would trace it, taste it, maybe bite it if she were feeling particularly reckless. She bit the inside of her cheek to keep those thoughts at bay.

Â 

She needed a distraction. â€œSince when are you a fan of sports?â€ she asked, though she was aware her eyes hadnâ€™t moved from Rioâ€™s mouth.

Â 

She realized the second Rio caught her staring. The small, sweet smile twisted into something undeniably smug, and Agathaâ€™s heart skipped a beat.

Â 

Before speaking, Rio licked her bottom lip and tugged it into her mouth. The sight alone was enough to draw a soft hum from Agatha before Rio even had a chance to respond.

Â 

â€œThe day was January twenty-seventh, nineteen seventy-five,â€ Rio said, her tone carrying a teasing lilt. â€œThe first nationally televised womenâ€™s college basketball game.â€

Â 

Agatha could not have cared less about the answer. All she could think about was the way Rioâ€™s lips moved when she spoke.

Â 

Caution be damned.


Agatha grabbed Rio by the collar of her t-shirt and pulled her into a kiss that was as forceful as it was inevitable. Rio, as though anticipating it, reached up just in time to tilt her hat back, ensuring it wouldnâ€™t get in the way.

Â 

When their lips met, it was far from gentle. There was no slow buildup, no tentative exploration, only an explosion of unrestrained hunger.Â  Their mouths parted instantly, tongues colliding in a heated battle for control, each desperate to claim the other.

Â

Â

Â

â€œUhhhhh because we need to be at the dock by 12:45,â€ Sage said, her voice carrying the faintest hint of condescension. She raised her eyebrows and tilted her head ever so slightly, her lips pressing together in a way that made it abundantly clear she thought the answer was glaringly obvious.

Â

â€œIt does if you value the art of punctuality,â€ Sage quipped, her tone laced with mockery. Agatha could see the faint smirk on Sageâ€™s face starting to form. Sage folded her arms with an air of triumph like her logic was not only flawless but also painfully obvious to anyone with half a brain.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Wrong question! Agatha had asked the wrong fucking question.

Â

Â

â€œSheâ€™s yours when sheâ€™s being annoying.â€ Agatha lied.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha hesitated, torn between retreating to avoid whatever mischief Rio was up to or indulging her curiosity. Agatha didnâ€™t consider herself nosy, not really. Â 

Crossing her arms, she strolled casually toward Rio, her eyes drifting over the bookshelves as though she was simply browsing and not keeping Rio firmly in her peripheral vision. Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s face immediately twisted into a silent grimace. Lips pressed tight, teeth bared ever so slightly, it was the universal expression for yikes. She raised an eyebrow at Rio, waiting to see how far this particular masterpiece would go.

Â 

That situation had happened long ago, centuries in fact. Agatha was hazy on the exact dates, but she had always favored Massachusetts. It was where she felt her most wicked. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

The poem referred to Death as a man, but the way the woman spoke about it felt suspiciously familiar. Fruity, some would say. It sounded like Rio and Agatha couldnâ€™t ignore the possibility. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

She would occasionally lift the veil of the Darkhold, just enough for Rio to sense her. It was never enough to find her, only enough to tease, to draw Rio in and leave her grasping at nothing. Agatha relished the game, the push and pull, the way Rio would chase her only to find nothing but whispers of her presence.

Â

Â 

So, with her jaw tight and fists clenched, Agatha approached the woman. Agatha smiled and offered compliments, playing her role perfectly. The woman soaked up every word with ease.Â 

Â 

Agatha saw it, clear as day, the charm, the wit, unafraid to defy the rules of her timeâ€¦ Agatha understood how Emily Dickinson caught Rioâ€™s eye.

Â

Â 

So what did Agatha Harkness do? She befriended the woman. They talked endlessly, delving into questions that felt like staring into the abyss- existence, mortality, the nature of time. Â 

Emily Dickinson had a tendency to obsess on the shiny and new. It wouldnâ€™t take long before poems were written, verses about a brown haired, blue eyed woman who disappeared into the night. Â

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t take it anymore. Fuming, she whipped away from the shelf, aggressively readjusting the strap of her purse on her shoulder. She mumbled angrily under her breath as she stomped toward the door, her footsteps heavy with irritation.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

The transaction dragged on longer than it had any right to. The machine beeped, whirred, and blinked, taking its sweet time processing the card. Agatha stood motionless, except for the sharp, rhythmic tapping of her finger against the glass counter. The sound filled the silence, a reminder of her growing impatience. Â 

Agatha snatched them, her knuckles white as she gripped one tightly in her right hand and shoved the other into the pocket of her pants. She shoved the wallet back into her purse without a glance, spun on her heel, and stormed out of the store, the bell clanging violently in her wake.

Â 

Agatha marched back to the bookstore, her jaw clenched and her fingers twisting the stupid thing around her finger as her frustration simmered. Â 

The employee scrambled to bag the items, her hands fumbling slightly as she worked to move as quickly as possible under the weight of Agathaâ€™s unrelenting presence. Once the bag was handed to Sage, their daughter bolted for the door without hesitation, leaving Rio a few steps behind, hovering near the exit. Rio paused, her hand lifting to beckon Agatha toward the door, her expression practically pleading for this to end.

Â 

But Agatha wasnâ€™t done. That wicked smile stayed plastered on her face as she pointed at Rio with dramatic flair. â€œMy wife, buying shit for our daughter,â€ she said. Agatha started to move, but then she stopped again, throwing over her shoulder, â€œThe daughter we share.â€

Â 

Rio gave her a pointed look, but before she could usher Agatha out, Agatha turned one last time, the smile on her face sharpening into something colder. â€œOh, and a son. Whoâ€™s dead.â€ The words didnâ€™t sting as she said them; they werenâ€™t meant to. They were meant to pierce the random woman, to twist the knife of discomfort deeper. Maybe it was also a reminder to Rio, a vocal declaration that Agatha acknowledges Rio as Nickyâ€™s mother.

Â 

Rio finally moved, stepping forward to gently grab Agathaâ€™s elbow, her grip firm but careful as she guided Agatha out of the bookstore.

Â 

As they stepped onto the street, Rio leaned in close, her lips brushing against Agathaâ€™s ear as she muttered, soft and sweet, â€œYou have no idea how hard Iâ€™m going to fuck you after that stunt.â€

Â 

Agatha froze, the words stopping her in her tracks as Rioâ€™s grip tugged her back slightly. For a moment, they were face to face, their stances unwavering, neither willing to break first. Agatha leaned in, so close their noses nearly brushed, her voice dropping into a dangerous whisper. â€œLooking forward to it.â€

Â 

With that, she spun on her heel with a dramatic flip of her hair and marched toward the docks, her steps purposeful, her head high. Behind her, Rio lingered for a moment, a smirk tugging at the corners of her lips before she followed.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Three days after Nickyâ€™s birth:

Â 

Agatha had found a quiet clearing deep in the forest, a secluded place to rest for what remained of the day. Nicky slept soundly in a woven basket sheâ€™d discovered the night after his birth. She hadnâ€™t needed to guess who had left it. Inside was a single lotus flower. The sight of it had sent fury tearing through her chest. She didnâ€™t need Rio, her gestures, or her pity. She needed her son to live.

Â 

Her first instinct had been to destroy the basket, to rip it apart and grind the flower into the dirt. But she hadnâ€™t. Not because of sentiment or nostalgia, but because the basket gave her something she desperately needed. A place to lay him down, a moment to breathe when the weight of it all threatened to crush her.

Â 

When those moments came, she would sit beside him and watch. His tiny chest rose and fell in perfect rhythm, his every breath a quiet miracle. For a while, she could lose herself in him. The worldâ€™s cruelty faded; her wifeâ€™s cruelty faded. For a while, there was only him, and in those precious moments, nothing else mattered.

Â 

Then the faint crunch of leaves shattered the peace. Agatha froze, her body tensing as she turned. And there she was. Ten feet away. That green dress, once a thing of beauty, clung to her form like a ghost. Now it wasnâ€™t beautiful. Now it was a shroud, steeped in everything Agatha had come to despise.

Â 

It hurt to look at Rio. It always hurt, and no matter how much time passed, it always would. There was no seeing her without feeling the sharp edge of betrayal, the suffocating shadow of Death that clung to her like smoke.

Â 

Agatha moved without thinking, placing herself between the bassinet and Rio. Her body braced against the surge of fear and fury. Rio was not coming any closer. Not to him. Not ever.

Â 

Rio took a step forward. Agathaâ€™s chest tightened as her hand shot up. â€œStop,â€ she snapped, her voice trembling with the weight of her fear. â€œDonâ€™t take another step.â€

Â 

Rio froze. Agatha saw the hurt flash across her face, the way her lips parted as though the words had physically struck her. Disbelief settled in her eyes, as though she couldnâ€™t understand why Agatha would fear her.

Â 

How dare she?

Â 

Agathaâ€™s stomach twisted, her anger sharpening into something harder, colder. How dare she look wounded, as if she were the one who had been wronged? Agatha straightened, grounding herself in the raw fury that had kept her standing for so long. Rio had no right to be here. No right to see him. No right to pretend she cared after everything she had done.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s heart pounded in her chest, her mind a storm of rage and grief. Then Rio spoke, and it stopped her cold.

Â 

â€œI- I promiseâ€¦ I wonâ€™t get too close. I wonâ€™t touch a thingâ€¦ Yo-.. You wonâ€™t even know Iâ€™m there.â€

Â 

Agatha had prepared herself for pleading, for arguments, for the entitled insistence she had come to expect from Rio. But this wasnâ€™t that. Rioâ€™s voice was broken, trembling. There was no defiance, no demand. Only desperation.

Â 

â€œPlease,â€ she said, her voice breaking. â€œJust donâ€™t hide him from me.â€

Â 

It wasnâ€™t a request for forgiveness or a plea for another chance. It was smaller than that. Just to see him. To be near, even from a distance.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s breath hitched. She wanted to stay angry, to hold onto the fire that was keeping her alive. But the way Rio stood there- trembling, holding herself back like she was terrified to even breathe too close- struck a nerve she hadnâ€™t expected.

Â 

Rio wasnâ€™t just afraid. She was terrified. Of herself. Of what she was. Of what might happen if she got too close. The realization hit Agatha like a fucking bus. Rio wasnâ€™t the woman she had loved, the woman she had built her world around. Rio was broken. A ghost of herself, consumed by fear and regret.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s throat tightened as she looked between Rio and Nicky. For days, she had clung to the belief that shutting Rio out was the right thing, the safe thing. But now, with Rio standing there trembling at the edge of the clearing, she didnâ€™t see Death.

Â 

She saw a mother.

Â 

A mother who was desperate, shattered, and begging for even the smallest piece of what she had lost. And for a moment, Agathaâ€™s anger faltered, the edges of it softening against the raw ache in Rioâ€™s voice.

Â 

â€œI donâ€™t want to see your face.â€

Â 

-

Â 

For seven years, she allowed Rio to watch. Agatha never saw her, but she felt her presence, always lingering just beyond the edge of her awareness. Sometimes it was the faintest shift in the air, the slightest rustle of leaves where there was no wind. Other times, it was heavier, like the weight of a shadow pressing against her back. Agatha didnâ€™t acknowledge it, not even to herself. But she knew.

Â 

Rio never crossed the invisible line Agatha had drawn, never dared to get too close. Whether it was fear or respect, Agatha didnâ€™t know and didnâ€™t care. All that mattered was that Nicky was safe, untouched by Deathâ€™s hands.

Â 

Except, he looked exactly like Rio.

Â 

It was the cruelest twist of fate, a reminder that Agatha could never escape. Every time she looked at Nicky, she saw her.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t fair. How could someone so pure, so perfect, carry the face of the one person who had shattered her? Agatha had tried, desperately, to find herself in him, to see some flicker of her own reflection. But no matter how closely she searched, it was Rio staring back at her.

Â 

Agatha hated it. Hated how much it hurt. Hated that there were moments when she had to look away because it felt like she was drowning in grief all over again.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t Nickyâ€™s fault. None of it was. But it was too awful, too overwhelming, to think of him as Rioâ€™s son. A son born of Death. The idea of it sent a chill down her spine, cold and unrelenting. She would spend years telling herself that Nicky was her miracle, her reason to keep going, and he was. But the truth she buried, the truth she couldnâ€™t speak, was that he was also her greatest heartache.

Â 

Because no matter how much she tried to deny it, Rio was there. In him. In the way he moved, in the way he smiled, in the way he looked at her with those dark, searching eyes. And it tore her apart in ways she could never explain, in ways she would never let anyone see.

Â 

So Agatha clung to the only thing she could control. She would never call Rio his mother. She would never give her that. Nicky was hers, hers alone, and no one- not even Rio, standing silently in the shadows- would take that from her. Not ever.

Â 

-

Â 

Agatha watched as Sage unapologetically pushed her way past children on their walk to the docks. She was on a mission, her determination to be first in line burning with singular focus. Rio walked behind Agatha at a leisurely pace, looking entirely unconcerned as Sage bulldozed through the crowd like a force of nature.

Â

Â 

â€œWallet,â€ she demanded, holding out her hand.

Â 

Agatha scoffed, rummaging through her bag before pulling out the wallet and handing it over. Sage snatched it, paid for the tickets, and passed them to the booth attendant before the group boarded the vessel.

Â 

Inside, a small bar dominated the back wall of the cabin, surrounded by a sea of chairs neatly arranged in rows. Booths lined the edges along the windows, offering cozy spots to take in the view, while doors at either end led out to the open front deck.

Â 

Agatha immediately found the closest chair she could and sank into it with a tired sigh. Rio, meanwhile, stopped at the bar, casually chatting with the bartender. A moment later, she joined Agatha, dropping into the seat beside her and handing over a cold beer without saying a word.

Â

Â

It didnâ€™t feel like anger or sadness, but something more subdued, almost restless. The unfamiliarity of it gnawed at Agatha, stirring a quiet tension that made her hesitate to speak. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s gaze shifted between them. Rio, still as the waves seemed to move in time with her, and Sage, her fingers gripping the railing like she was tethering herself to something unseen. The rest of their time whale watching had been calm, almost serene. After the extraordinary moment of the whale breaching, there had been no more surprises just waves and the gentle grace of the whales moving through the water. It was a quieter kind of beauty, but it didnâ€™t diminish Sageâ€™s wonder in the slightest. She had soaked up every second, her enthusiasm shining as she pointed out every flick of a tail or rise of a spout on the horizon. Sage had been glowing, her joy was infectious.

Â 

Agatha, however, had barely paid attention to the whales. Her focus had been on Sage, on Rio, on the way they both fit into this moment so naturally. Sage would glance back at her and Rio every now and then, her face lit with wide, toothy smiles so full of love and excitement it almost hurt to look at. And every time, Agathaâ€™s heart soared, leaving her feeling like the softest, mushiest fool imaginable. Sageâ€™s joy wasnâ€™t just something to witness- it was something Agatha felt in her own chest, like the echoes of a song she thought sheâ€™d forgotten.

Â 

This was more than just a day at the ocean. Agatha knew that as surely as she knew her own name. This was a milestone, one of those precious moments that etched itself into a personâ€™s memory forever. It reminded her of what she had lost for so long - the chance to be present for these moments, not just as a someone observing from afar, but as a mother, a part of something whole.

Â 

Agatha had only seen parts of Sageâ€™s life through her memories, and even her time spent in Rioâ€™s realm had felt like looking through a window, close enough to see but never close enough to touch. Yet now, she was no longer on the outside. She was here, truly present, witnessing it all unfold from start to finish. There was no running, no chaos, no grief clawing at her insides.

Â 

Agatha let herself smile, soft and unguarded, because holding it back felt impossible. When her eyes drifted to Rio, she found herself stunned by what she saw. Rio wasnâ€™t watching the whales, either. Her gaze was fixed on Agatha, warm and unyielding, her brown eyes filled with so much love that it made Agathaâ€™s breath catch.

Â 

It was almost too muchâ€¦ Rio looking at her like thatâ€¦ Softâ€¦ Devoted... Like sheâ€™d carved this moment out of time just for them. It was beautiful, achingly so, and it hit Agatha with an intensity she hadnâ€™t expected.

Â 

This moment was something Agatha never thought she would have again. She had spent lifetimes believing joy like this was lost to her. But here it was, as real as the sun glinting off the water or the sound of Sageâ€™s laughter carried by the breeze. It wasnâ€™t perfect. Agathaâ€™s heart still ached for Nicky, but the ache didnâ€™t swallow her whole. Instead, it lived quietly beside the happiness, a bittersweet reminder of what she had endured and what she still had.

Â 

Love did not erase the past, but it made room for the future. Â

â€˜ It doesnâ€™t devour. It transforms. Erosion isnâ€™t just loss. Itâ€™s change. The sea reshapes everything it touches.â€™

Â 

Fuck.

Â

Â

Â

Â

On one side, the water moved in its gentle rhythm, and on the other, tall clusters of beach grass lined the edge of the sand, shifting lightly in the breeze. The world felt quiet and still, as if it belonged entirely to them.

Â

The daybed, with its L-shaped backrest, formed a cozy corner while leaving the foot and one side open to the ocean. When Agatha had woken before dawn, the air still thick with the hush of night, she had turned to Rio and murmured, â€œWalk with me? Watch the sunrise?â€

Â 

Rio had blinked sleepily at her, then nodded without hesitation. And now, as they strolled along the shore, the sun beginning its slow ascent over the horizon.

Â 

The ocean stretched endlessly before them, restless and alive. The waves rolled in stronger than before, spilling farther up the shore before retreating. The sky was a canvas of deep purples and soft golds, the horizon just beginning to burn with the first light of dawn. The air was thick with salt, warm and cool all at once, the kind of morning that felt like a secret, something intimate and untouched.

Â 

But none of that held Agathaâ€™s attention.

Â 

Rio was walking beside her, and she was struggling.

Â 

She wasnâ€™t making a sound, wasnâ€™t saying a word, but Agatha could feel it in the way Rio carried herself. There was a tension to her, not rigid, not hesitant, but charged, like she was containing something. Her arms were crossed loosely over her chest, but Agatha could see the way her fingers flexed against her skin, curling and uncurling as if she didnâ€™t know what to do with them.

Â 

Rio wanted to touch her. She wanted to reach out.

Â 

Agatha knew because she had seen this before, had felt it before, back when Rio never second guessed these things. There had been a time when touch was second nature to her. A hand at the small of her back. Fingers brushing over her wrist. A lazy tug of her shirt just to pull her closer. It had never been forced, never been something Rio had to think about. It had been instinct.

Â 

But that was before things had gotten complicated. Before space had wedged itself between them. Before restraint had become something Rio had learned to live with.

Â 

But now, after yesterday, after Agatha had slid a ring back onto her finger with intent, Rio was holding herself differently. Not distant or guarded. But like she was bracing against something she wasnâ€™t sure she was allowed to want.

Â 

Agatha could see it in the way Rio kept sneaking glances at her, in the way she inhaled just a little too deeply when their steps fell too close together. Rio wasnâ€™t hesitant. If anything, she looked keyed in, like her body was operating on some frequency she hadnâ€™t figured out how to turn off.

Â 

And Agatha fucking loved it. She could have made it easy. She could have brushed their hands together. She could have tilted her head and smirked just enough to say What are you waiting for?

Â 

But she didnâ€™t.

Â 

She let Rio want.

Â 

She let her ache for it.

Â 

The ocean surged again, spilling up the sand, curling around their ankles before slipping away.

Â 

Rio exhaled, long and deep, and finally, she let her arms fall to her sides. Her fingers twitched once. Twice. And then, barely, they brushed against Agathaâ€™s.

Â 

It lasted less than a second. But Rioâ€™s breath hitched.

Â 

Agatha smiled, tilting her head slightly as she let her fingers trail idly along the side of her thigh. â€œSomething on your mind?â€ Her voice was soft, teasing, like she was indulging a game she had already won.

Â 

Rio furrowed her brow, crossing her arms back over her chest with a huff. â€œNo.â€

Â 

Agatha almost felt bad for how much she was enjoying this. Almost.

Â 

â€œOkay.â€ Agatha smiled and nodded as she kept walking, the word light and easy, like she wasnâ€™t bothered in the slightest.

Â 

Rio stopped.

Â 

Agatha took a few more steps before realizing she was walking alone. She turned, finding Rio standing a few paces behind her, arms still crossed, lips pressed together in something that wasnâ€™t quite a pout but close enough to make Agathaâ€™s amusement deepen.

Â 

She raised an eyebrow, tilting her head slightly. â€œWhat?â€

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t answer. She just stared at Agatha, something unreadable flickering behind those deep brown eyes. For a moment, Agatha thought Rio might let it go, might shake her head and fall back into step beside her like nothing had happened, but she didnâ€™t.

Â 

She just stood there, unmoving, looking at Agatha like she had just been personally offended.

Â 

Agatha sighed through her nose, amusement flickering in her chest as she stepped back toward Rio. She stopped in front of her, waiting, but Rio only turned her chin away, gaze fixed stubbornly on the horizon like the sunrise had suddenly become the most captivating thing she had ever seen.

Â 

Agatha knew betterâ€¦ Rio was sulking.

Â 

â€œSweetheart,â€ Agatha drawled, deliberately sweetening her tone.

Â

Â 

Agatha smirked, â€œHere we go.â€

Â 

â€œI just think itâ€™s funny that some people canâ€™t even hold their wifeâ€™s hand,â€ Rio muttered.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re right,â€ Agatha said, the corners of her mouth twitching. â€œWhat kind of monster doesnâ€™t hold their wifeâ€™s hand?â€

Â 

Rio looked at her, raising an eyebrow. â€œA truly evil one.â€

Â 

Without warning, Agatha reached out and gently tugged at Rioâ€™s crossed arms, uncrossing them as though it were the simplest thing in the world.

Â 

â€œHey- !â€ Rio started to protest, but Agatha didnâ€™t let her finish. She slid her hand into Rioâ€™s, holding it firmly, but with a tenderness that made it all feel suddenly right.

Â 

Rioâ€™s breath hitched, and for a moment, neither of them moved. Then, Rio gave a soft, reluctant smile. â€œBetter,â€ she said, her tone softening.

Â 

They walked in silence, hand in hand, their steps in sync, they didnâ€™t need to say anything. The cool morning air wrapped around them as they strolled, the world feeling just a little bit smaller, a little bit more right with their fingers entwined. Everything else faded into the background, leaving only the quiet of the beach and the simple comfort of being together.

Â

Â 

The morning had unraveled slowly, and now, with the sun high overhead, the three of them had settled into the lull of the day. The ocean stretched endlessly before them, the waves rolling in and out.

Â 

Rio sat beside Agatha in a lounge chair, fingers twitching against the armrest, then stilling, then starting again. It was the same hesitance from earlier, the same quiet struggle she thought she was hiding. Agatha had given her hand earlier, had let Rio feel the shape of it again, warm and steady against her own. But still, Rio wavered.

Â 

Agatha shifted, stretching out her leg just enough that it brushed against Rioâ€™s. A small touch, a whisper of warmth against her skin. It was enough to make Rio go still, enough to make her fingers pause mid tap. Agatha let the moment settle, let Rio have what she had been aching for without making a show of it.

Â 

Agatha let her gaze drift over the water, barely listening as Sage, settled in the sand beside her, idly twisted a seashell between her fingers.

Â 

Rio had finally relaxed- or at least, she had stopped fidgeting so much. She still hadnâ€™t moved her leg away from where Agathaâ€™s brushed against it, hadnâ€™t said a word about it either. Agatha let her stay in that quiet, let her keep the closeness without pushing it.

Â 

But Sage had no such mercy.

Â 

Sage had been testing Rioâ€™s patience all morning, poking and prodding, waiting for her to break.

Â 

It started small- kicking sand too close to Rioâ€™s legs, humming just off key, nudging her chair with the edge of her foot. Sharp little comments, casual but deliberate, each one a careful press against the limits of Rioâ€™s restraint.

Â 

And Rio, for all her grumbling and heavy sighs, never truly stopped her. She let Sage push, let the game play out.

Â 

Sage, ever the instigator, sat in the sand beside Agatha, sifting lazily through shells. â€œYou know,â€ she mused, her voice carrying that telltale spark of trouble, â€œI read something the other day. Something that really stuck with me.â€

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œNo! You already talk too much!â€ Rio scoffed, already pulling her toward the water.

Â 

Agatha simply watched, stretching out her legs, content to observe the chaos unfold.

Â 

Sage wasnâ€™t really trying to escape. She could have twisted out of Rioâ€™s grip if she wanted to, could have sprinted in the opposite direction. But she didnâ€™t. She let herself be dragged across the sand, breath hitching between laughter as Rio pulled her closer and closer to the waves.

Â 

Water lapped at their feet, cool against the heat of the day. Rio grinned, adjusting her grip, shifting her stance like she was making a show of weighing her options.

Â 

â€œYou wonâ€™t do it,â€ Sage taunted, still breathless. â€œYou love me too much.â€

Â 

Rioâ€™s grin widened. â€œOh, do I?â€

Â 

And then she lifted Sage clean off the ground and dropped her straight into the ocean.

Â

Â 

â€œYou traitor, â€ she gasped.

Â 

Rio, standing knee deep in the surf, just crossed her arms. â€œOh, so now Iâ€™m a traitor?â€

Â 

Sage blinked at her, then lunged.

Â 

Rio yelped, stepping back, but Sage caught her wrist and pulled.

Â 

Rio stumbled forward, trying to regain her footing, but Sage took the opportunity to kick up as much water as possible, drenching her in one swift motion.

Â 

Agatha let herself sink deeper into her chair, the breeze shifting through her hair, the sun painting the sand in gold. She had no plans to step in, no desire to interfere.

Â 

She just wanted to watch.

Â 

Because they were hers.

Â

Â 

Now, Agatha sat out on the balcony with Sage, the two of them engaged in a game of chess. The board between them was beautifully crafted, an ocean themed set where each piece was shaped like sea creatures- knights as seahorses, rooks as coral towers, pawns as tiny shells. The board itself was a deep blue, swirling with hints of white like waves frozen in time.

Â 

Sage studied the board with sharp eyes, fingers resting against the edge of a piece, as if weighing every possible outcome.

Â 

Agatha, for her part, took the moment to simply watch her.

Â 

There was something soothing about this- just the two of them, the steady back and forth of the game, the quiet that filled the space between each move. Sage wasnâ€™t speaking much, but she didnâ€™t have to. Agatha could feel her thinking, the way she played out each scenario before even touching a piece.

Â 

Agatha moved her bishop, then leaned back, gaze flicking briefly toward the horizon. The sun had started its descent, casting streaks of gold and orange across the water, reflecting in the glassy surface of the board.

Â 

A peaceful evening.

Â 

Except, for once, it wasnâ€™t Sage who broke the peace this time.

Â 

It was Agatha.

Â 

â€œWhatâ€™s he like?â€

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t look up from the board. She only hummed, waiting for more context, her fingers lightly tapping the top of a seashell shaped pawn.

Â 

Agatha rolled her eyes, exhaling through her nose. She blamed the mushiness of this trip. The warmth of it, the love, the peace- it was too much. A crack in her carefully kept facade, making her feel open in a way she wasnâ€™t used to. Vulnerable in a way she didnâ€™t like.

Â 

But Agatha still wanted to know.

Â 

She wanted to know what her son was like.

Â 

If he still looked the same. If time had changed him. If she would even recognize him now.

Â 

â€œNickyâ€¦â€ Agatha forced out, the name unfamiliar on her tongue after so many years. It felt heavier than she expected.

Â 

She kept her gaze on Sage, watching closely, waiting for even the smallest flicker of a reaction. Shock. Surprise. Sadness. Anything. Maybe even excitement that Agatha was finally opening up about this.

Â 

But Sage didnâ€™t move. She didnâ€™t look up from the board.

Â

Â

â€œHeâ€™s fucking annoying.â€

Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œSorryâ€¦ I meant as my brother.â€ Her voice was too light, too casual, the kind of correction meant to undo what had already slipped. She cast a glance to the side, fingers drumming once against the armrest before she shrugged. â€œHeâ€™s an annoying little brother.â€

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t respond. She simply watched.

Â 

She had known Sage long enough to recognize when she was trying to control the narrative. Sage didnâ€™t stumble through conversations, didnâ€™t fumble with words, didnâ€™t let things slip unless she wanted them to. She had an almost surgical awareness of a momentâ€™s weight, knowing exactly what to say and when to say it to get the reaction she wanted. And yet, here she was, fumbling.

Â 

Because she knew what this was.

Â 

She knew how much it had taken for Agatha to ask. How unnatural it felt for her to let that crack form in the walls she had so carefully built. This wasnâ€™t just a passing curiosity. It wasnâ€™t small talk or some idle attempt to fill the silence between them. It was a step forward, a bridge between past and present, a question heavy enough that it meant something.

Â 

And rather than meeting it for what it was, Sage had done what she always did when things threatened to shift in ways she wasnâ€™t ready for- she tried to shrink it down, make it harmless, pretend it wasnâ€™t as big as it was.

Â 

Agatha let the silence stretch between them. She wasnâ€™t going to let Sage talk her way out of this. She wasnâ€™t going to let her dodge or twist it into something smaller. And from the way her fingers twitched against her knee, the way her mouth pressed into a thin line, Agatha knew Sage already regretted trying.

Â

Â 

Agatha stayed quiet, studying Sage, watching her uncomfortably sit with it.

Â 

Sage exhaled sharply through her nose, rolling her shoulders back as if physically shaking off the tension. â€œLook, itâ€™s not like we have deep, meaningful conversations,â€ she muttered, moving a piece on the board without really looking at it. â€œHe shows up when he feels like it. Â

Agatha didnâ€™t believe that for a second. If Nicky had been showing up, even in Sageâ€™s dreams, there was a reason for it. There was something tying them together, something neither of them had been willing to say outright.

Â

Â 

Nicky would have fucking loved Sage.

Â

Â 

And then there was Sage.

Â 

Sage, who was fire and sharp edges, who met the world with wit and defiance, who never let herself be soft because she had never had to be. She burned where Nicky had glowed. She challenged where he would have embraced. And he - god, he would have been obsessed with her.

Â 

Agatha could see it so clearly it almost hurt.

Â 

Agatha felt something press against her chest, an ache that had no name.

Â

Â

Agatha didnâ€™t flinch, but she felt it. Sage was right. And they both knew it.

â€œWithout herâ€¦ with him and you, but not her-â€œ Her throat tightened, the thought sinking into her like a weight she couldnâ€™t bear to carry. â€œThat doesnâ€™t sound like peace. Â 

Her fingers curled around the edge of the chessboard, grounding herself in something tangible, something real, because the alternative was letting herself spiral into the thought too deeply. She forced herself to breathe, to steady the anger rising beneath the grief.

â€œIt wouldnâ€™t be peace,â€ she said again, quieter now, but no less certain. â€œIt would be hell.â€

â€œListenâ€¦â€ Sageâ€™s voice was softer now, but it didnâ€™t waver. â€œShe wouldnâ€™t be there. She canâ€™t be.â€ The words werenâ€™t meant to be cruel, just honest, just true. â€œRio is Death. Sheâ€™s always been Death. â€œShe wouldnâ€™t want you to.â€

â€œWell, Iâ€™m not fucking ready,â€ Agatha shot back, the words coming meaner than she intended, but she didnâ€™t care. She refused to accept this, refused to let Sage speak like the decision had already been made. Like there was some inevitable road she had to walk just because time demanded it.

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t flinch. She didnâ€™t argue. She just watched Agatha for a moment, then nodded.

Â 

â€œThatâ€™s okay,â€ she said softly, her voice steady in a way that almost made Agatha angrier. â€œIâ€™m in no rush either.â€ She exhaled, tilting her head slightly as if considering something before adding, â€œIâ€™m sure Rio isnâ€™t.â€

Â

Â 

â€œYou know how my mom is,â€ Sage said, treading carefully now, her voice soft. â€œHell bent on the rules.â€

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Rio was gone, disappeared inside. Then, the first drops of rain began to fall.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Sage didnâ€™t react right away. No sharp retort, no forced indifference, no attempt to make light of what had just happened. Â

Â

â€˜Death does not pass. It endures. Without heir. Without end. But when the cycle strains against its own nature, something will rise- They will not be born of prophecy, but of failure in the original design. And the balance, if altered by what it could not predict will find a way to hold.â€™

Â 

Agathaâ€™s blood ran cold.

Â

Â 

Sage wasnâ€™t inheriting Death. That wasnâ€™t how the cycle worked. The role didnâ€™t pass down through bloodlines or prophecy. Â 

And yet, Sage had written this down like it was possible. As if the cycle could bend. As if Death could beâ€¦ retired.

Â

Â 

Agathaâ€™s hands tightened around the notebook, her breath shallow as she stared down at the evidence sprawled across the pages.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€˜The end of one. The beginning of another.â€™

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t answer.

Â 

They stood there, facing each other, two women who had never been denied by Death. She had never told them no. She had answered them, bent where they willed her, given when they reached for her. They had both taken from her before, without hesitation, without permission, and Death had always let them.

Â 

That was the undeniable truth staring them both in the face. Death had never been a force without will, never been a mantle that simply passed to the next. She had choice. She had agency. And Rio had just made hers.

Â 

She wasnâ€™t going to do it.

Â 

Not today. Not tomorrow. Not ever.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t reluctance. It wasnâ€™t something that could be worn down or reasoned with. This was absolute, final, a truth as immovable as the cycle itself. Agatha had felt it when Rio spoke. There had been no doubt, no crack, no space for argument.

Â 

And Sage, had never accounted for that.

Â 

For once, Death had told her no.

Â 

Sage looked like she was fighting a fucking meltdown. Not just at being told no, not even at her plan falling apart before it had the chance to begin, but because of every single word Rio had thrown at her. The accusations. The rejection. The sheer fury behind it all.

Â 

Sageâ€™s hands were curled into fists at her sides, shoulders locked up so tight it looked painful, breath uneven like she was struggling to keep it together, like if she let go of whatever was holding her upright, she might actually fall apart. It wasnâ€™t just frustration. It wasnâ€™t just anger. It was something far worse.

Â 

For all of Sageâ€™s sharp words, for all her calculated moves, for all her arrogance, there had always been one thing that remained certain- Rio had never turned her away. She had argued with her, yelled at her, gotten frustrated beyond reason, but she had never cast her aside. Never looked at Sage like she was nothing. Never denied her. Not like this.

Â 

And Sage, who had never once cared about permission, who had spent her life defying expectation, who had never let anything shake her before, looked shaken.

Â 

She swallowed, jaw tightening, her entire body going stiff like she could force herself not to react. Then she exhaled, the breath slow, steady, controlled.

Â 

â€œIâ€™ll see you guys at home.â€

Â 

Flat. Emotionless. Too steady to be real.

Â 

â€œSage, wait!â€ Agatha moved to grab her, her fingers barely brushing the space where her daughter had been standing before Sage stepped forward and vanished through a portal without so much as a glance back.

Â 

Agatha let out a breath, her body coiled too tight, her mind trying to catch up with what had just happened.

Â 

Then, before she could stop herself, before she could even think, the anger ripped through her like an uncontainable force.

Â 

â€œ FUCK! â€

Â 

The word tore out of her throat, raw and violent, her fingers digging into the notebook still clutched in her hands. She thought about throwing it, thought about burning it, thought about something, anything toÂ shake this feeling sitting in her chest.

Â 

Everything had just turned to shit.Â

Agatha couldnâ€™t make sense of what had just happened. Too much information had been thrown at her in the worst possible way, and she couldnâ€™t begin to process any of it. Sageâ€™s plan, whatever it had been, had fallen apart, but right now, none of that mattered. The only thing Agatha cared about was her daughter. How she was after Rio had unleashed every cruel word she could think of at their daughter.

Â 

Rio, the woman Agatha had once known as well as her own name, had raised Sage with a love so deep it had seemed effortless. She had nurtured her, cared for her, like being a mother was something written into her very bones. They were everything to each other. Before Agatha, Rio had been alone. Then Agatha had come into her life, and things had grown complicated. Then Sage had come along, and suddenly, Rio hadnâ€™t been alone anymore. Sage hadnâ€™t been alone. They had found something in each other.

Â 

And Agatha had sat there and watched Rio destroyed it.

Â 

It hadnâ€™t been an argument. That word was too small for what had happened. Sage hadnâ€™t fought back. She hadnâ€™t said a word. She had simply stood there, silent, as Rio tore into her. And that, more than anything, made Agathaâ€™s stomach twist. Sage, who never backed down from anything. Sage, whose sharp tongue and unshakable defiance had always made her impossible to ignore. Sage, who had spent her entire life contending. Yet, when it had mattered most, she had stood there and let her mother tear her apart like she was nothing.. like she deserved it.

Â 

That didnâ€™t feel like a fight. It felt like a fucking massacre.

Â 

Agatha had to be honest with herself. It was taking everything in her not to storm into that damn beach house, grab Rio by the ear, and drag her back home to face what she had done. To force her to look Sage in the eye and apologize. It was taking everything not to march inside and throw words just as cruel as the ones Rio had hurled at their daughter. To wound her the way she had wounded Sage. To tear her apart and make her feel the same unbearable sting of those words.

Â 

But Agatha wasnâ€™t that person anymore. She wouldnâ€™t hurt Rio just to make her suffer. She wouldnâ€™t lash out just because the emotions surging inside her were too twisted to sort through. She had done that before. Let fear sink its claws into her, let it twist her love into something completely unrecognizable and so, so fucking cruel. Agatha had always lit the match first, because it was easier to reduce everything to ash before the flames could reach her.

Â 

So she stood there, fists clenched at her sides, forcing herself to breathe through the chaos raging inside her. Forcing herself to stay. To sit with the anger, with the hurt, instead of unleashing it. She would not go into that house and tear into Rio the way Rio had torn into Sage.

Â 

Because no matter how much Rio deserved to be dragged back and made to face what she had done, Agatha knew more than anyone that malice wouldnâ€™t fix this. It never had.

Â 

Once Agatha was certain she could hold her tongue- could refrain from saying anything mean to her lovely, beautiful, very sweet wife (a necessary reminder to herself)- she took a breath.

Somehow, against all odds, Agatha had absolutely nothing to do with the absolute dumpster fire that had just unfolded in front of her.

A truly shocking accomplishment, well done, Agatha.Â 

Agatha made her way through the beach house and up to their room, refusing to let emotions dictate her steps. When she reached the doorway, she found Rio furiously packing- or at least attempting to. Furiously would have been the wrong word for it. There was too much control in the way her hands moved, too much precision in the way each item was folded and placed with care. Even if the clothes were dirty, even if none of this made sense, Rio would never just throw things into a bag. Order was her anchor, the one thing she could cling to when everything else slipped through her fingers.


Agatha stepped inside, crossing her arms loosely over her chest. Rioâ€™s back was turned, her posture tense, her head slightly bowed as she hovered over the half packed bag.

Â 

Before Agatha could speak, Rio did first.

Â 

â€œDid you know?â€ She didnâ€™t turn around. Didnâ€™t even glance up. Her voice was steady, but something about it felt off.

Â 

â€œNo,â€ Agatha answered truthfully.

Â 

Rio must have believed her, because she didnâ€™t argue. Didnâ€™t push back. She only nodded slightly before returning to the task in front of her, folding another shirt like it was the only thing that mattered.

Â 

Agatha hesitated. â€œSag-â€

Â 

â€œDonâ€™t.â€ Rioâ€™s voice was quiet but firm. Her hands stilled mid fold, fingers gripping the fabric a little too tightly.

Â 

â€œDonâ€™t say her-â€ Rio stopped herself, exhaling sharply. â€œI canâ€™t.â€ She swallowed hard. â€œI donâ€™t want to talk about it.â€ The words tumbled out too quickly, as if saying them any slower would force her to feel them.

Â 

Still, Rio didnâ€™t turn around. Didnâ€™t meet Agathaâ€™s eyes. She just kept folding.

Â 

Agatha rolled her eyes, inhaling deeply as she reminded herself- I didnâ€™t come here to argue. She repeated it like a silent chant, an attempt to steady herself, to not let Rioâ€™s behavior pull her into something neither of them could afford right now.

Â 

But restraint had never been Agathaâ€™s strong suit.

Â

She pushed herself backward, hands digging into the ground, legs scrambling as she crawled in reverse, desperate to put space between herself and the snake that was nowhere to be seen.

Â 

Then Agathaâ€™s back hit something.

Â 

Something solid.

Â 

Agatha froze. She looked down. Then up. Then back down.

Â 

â€œSince when do we have a fucking grill?â€ Agatha mumbled.

Â 

The hiss came before the realization.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s head snapped toward the sound, dread settling deep in her gut.

Â 

Brucie was slithering up her leg.

Â 

Agatha went completely rigid, every muscle in her body locking up as a string of desperate, unconvincing words tumbled from her mouth.

Â 

â€œHeyyyy, hey Brucieâ€¦ How ya doing?â€ Her voice wavered as she tried to casually reason with the serpent coiling around her. â€œI swear I didnâ€™t mean the belt comment. You are a very pretty snake. Stunning, actually. You donâ€™t look like a heinous colored leather belt at all. That was- that was out of line.â€

Â 

Once Brucie reached her thigh, the snake stopped.

Â 

Agatha remained still, barely breathing as she noticed a thin, loose string tied around the serpentâ€™s body with a small note attached.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s eye twitched, â€œFucking Sage.â€

Â 

Moving slowly, with the kind of caution one used around explosives, Agatha reached out. Brucieâ€™s red eyes never left her, unblinking and unreadable. Agatha carefully loosened the string and slipped the note free.

Â 

The second the string was removed, Brucie hissed, loud and sharp.

Â 

Agatha jolted back, barely stopping herself from falling over, but the snake had already slithered off, vanishing into the garden as if their encounter had never happened.

Â 

She sat there for a moment, letting her heart rate settle before unfolding the note. The message was infuriatingly simple.

Â 

â€˜Living room?â€™

Â 

Agatha sighed, letting her head thump against the grill before pushing herself off the ground. She lifted the note in the air like a victory flag and called out, â€œNo worries, it was just a note!â€

Â 

Brushing off the lingering embarrassment, she turned toward Rio, who was still standing in the exact same spot in the garden, having witnessed every humiliating second of it. Agatha narrowed her eyes.

Â 

â€œNot like I was facing imminent death or anything,â€ Agatha added, directing her sarcasm pointedly at her so-called wife.

Â 

Rio, who had been utterly dumbfounded just moments ago, finally cracked. The first laugh was quiet, but then she laughed harder, her shoulders shaking as she doubled over slightly.

Â 

Agatha huffed, crossing her arms. â€œThank you, my knight in shining armor! Your wife is saved, no thanks to you!â€

Â 

Rio only laughed harder.

Â 

Rolling her eyes, Agatha waved the note in the air again, â€œIâ€™m being summoned to the living room!â€

Â 

Rioâ€™s laughter softened, but the smile lingered, though something in her eyes seemed sad.

Â 

At least Agatha wasnâ€™t leaving her on a worse note. If nothing else, she was glad she had lightened the weight pressing on Rioâ€™s shoulders, even if just for a moment.

Â 

Agatha took a few steps toward the door before pausing, glancing back over her shoulder. â€œI love you.â€

Â 

It wasnâ€™t a reassurance. It was a reminder. Rio wasnâ€™t completely alone.

Â 

Rioâ€™s voice was softer when she responded, but there was certainty in it.

Â 

Agatha exhaled, rolling her shoulders and shaking out the tension from the morning. Maybe today wouldnâ€™t be so bad after all.

Â 

With a swift turn, Agatha flicked her hair over her shoulder and strode inside, preparing herself for whatever awaited her next.

Â 

Whatever awaited her next turned out to be reality TV.

Â 

Agatha scoffed. Sage and Rio could talk about these shows for hours, dissecting every detail with the kind of passion most reserved for ancient text. Agatha recalled one conversation in particular, an impassioned discussion about a woman named Dorinda Medley.

Â 

Rio, with absolute conviction, had declared, â€œThey could never make me hate you, Dorinda Medley.â€

Â 

Sage, without missing a beat, had thrown her hand up and shouted, â€œCLIP! CLIP! You fool!â€

Â 

Agatha hadnâ€™t understood a single word of it, but Rio had laughed like it was the funniest thing in the world, so Agatha had decided it wasnâ€™t her battle to fight.

Â 

Sage just wanted to watch TV with her.

Â 

Agatha could tell she had no interest in being around Rio but was too stubborn to sit alone. Agatha wouldnâ€™t admit it out loud, but it comforted her to know that, at the very least, Sage wanted her company.

Â 

Without a word, Sage turned on Vanderpump Rules, settling in as if this had been the plan all along.

Â 

Agatha had lost track of time by the time Sage shifted, resting her head in Agathaâ€™s lap. The sudden affection startled Agatha, but she quickly relaxed, deciding it wasnâ€™tÂ  something to question. Instead, her fingers moved absently through her daughterâ€™s hair.

Â 

Before long, Sageâ€™s breathing deepened into the steady cadence of sleep. SeÃ±or Scratchy had nestled comfortably against her legs, and Petunia- Rioâ€™s familiar, or Tootie, as Sage had insisted on calling her-rested contentedly in Sageâ€™s open palm.

Â 

Agatha eyed them both, lowering her voice to a quiet whisper, â€œTraitors.â€

Â 

Agatha had been lost in thought, her head resting against the couch, when she caught movement in her peripheral vision. She lifted her gaze and found Rio standing at the threshold of the living room, watching them.

Â 

Agatha straightened, her fingers still idly threading through Sageâ€™s hair, but she said nothing.

Â 

The look in Rioâ€™s eyes made her chest tighten.

Â 

Any other time, walking in on this scene- her wife and daughter curled together, Sage resting against Agatha like she had done it a thousand times before- Rioâ€™s heart might have swelled at the sight. It should have been something to cherish.

Â 

Instead, for the briefest moment, jealousy flickered across her face.

Â 

Agatha understood it instantly. For as long as Sage had been alive, Rio had been the only one Sage turned to for comfort. The only arms she had sought out. Now, for the first time, that had changed.

Â 

Agatha watched as Rio shoved that feeling down, burying it beneath the same quiet selflessness she always carried when it came to them. Rio wouldnâ€™t let jealousy take root, not when this was a moment that should have meant something good. Even if Rio had no place in it, she wouldnâ€™t take it from them.

Â 

Rio smiled, small and tired, though it never reached her eyes. â€œIâ€™m just going to work out in the front.â€

Â 

Agatha nodded, pretending not to notice how Sage tensed at the sound of Rioâ€™s voice. Agatha pretended not to feel the tiny shift, the way Sage tried just a little too hard to keep up the act of sleep.

Â 

Agatha prayed to whatever god she hoped wasnâ€™t Rio that her wife had not noticed.

Â 

But of course, Rio had.

Â 

Rioâ€™s gaze flickered downward, lingering just long enough for Agatha to know she had seen it. There was no reaction, no shift in expression, just the faintest tightening of her jaw before she turned and left without another word, disappearing through the foyer and out the front door.

Â 

Agatha wanted to throw herself off a building. She couldnâ€™t imagine anything feeling worse than this.

Â 

Frustration coiled tight in Agathaâ€™s chest, sharp and suffocating. Without thinking, she gave Sage a firm bop on the side of the head- not enough to hurt, but enough to make her point crystal clear.

Â 

Sage flinched, scrunching her face in exaggerated offense before cracking one eye open. She muttered something incoherent and dramatic under her breath, but she didnâ€™t bother keeping up the act. She knew she had been caught.

Â 

-

Â 

Sage had been prattling on about some book she was determined for Agatha to read, speaking with the kind of conviction that suggested it was nothing short of life changing.

Â 

Somewhere mid sentence, Sage had hopped off the couch, determined to retrieve it herself. She disappeared into the study, reemerging moments later with the book in hand, stepping past the armchair just as Rio walked by the entrance of the living room.

Â 

It was the first time Rio and Sage had even made eye contact since the day before, since the moment the person Sage had trusted most had torn her apart limb from limb.

Â 

Sage startled.

Â 

Not just a quick flinch, not something small Sage could shake off and pretend never happened, not something they could all quietly agree to ignore.

Â 

She fucking stumbled.

Â 

Sageâ€™s foot caught against the back leg of the chair, her entire body jerking backward, as if she had been shoved. It wasnâ€™t just shock- it was instinct.

Â 

For a split second, it looked as if Sageâ€™s body had reacted before her mind had time to catch up, like some deep rooted survival instinct had decided, without hesitation, that she needed to get away from Rio.

Â 

At that exact moment, lightning struck.

Â 

The sky outside flashed white, and a split second later, thunder cracked so loudly the walls trembled.

Â 

Sage had panicked. And worse than that, she had looked scared.

Â 

Agatha felt her stomach drop so violently she was half convinced she had just shit it out of her own asshole.


-

Â 

Agatha braced herself because this was going to be merciless. There would be no smooth landing, no way out unscathed. This was going to be fucking brutal.
