how does it taste?

Chapter Notes

hello gay people in my phone. i've got a few things to say before we start (don't worry this is NOT the end). buckle up it's going to be long winded...

the reason it took me so long to get this update out is because at this point i refuse to give you all so much angst without some kind of resolution at the end of a chapter. so i wanted to make sure i finished chapter 25 before posting chapter 24. which brings me to good news: chapter 25 is done. i just need to do a final read through which i'll be working on immediately after this, so it'll be up soon after. and it's a whopping 16k wordS (which is what nearly a month of working on the same two chapters gets us).

now, these chapters are both pretty angsty, so if that's not your thing, that's okay!! feel free to scroll past and get to the resolution part.

i'm finished yapping... happy reading

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Three weeks.

Â 

Three weeks of watching somethingÂ fester,Â spreading like decay through everything she loved.

Â 

Agatha couldÂ taste it,Â thick and acrid, clinging to the back of her throat like something rancid. She couldÂ smell it,Â pungent and overripe, sinking into the air, coating everything in a stench she could not escape.

Â 

It was foul. It wasÂ unrelenting.Â And it was poisoning the very roots of everything that had made Agatha feel whole.Â 

Â 

And Agatha was caught in it, standing at the center of somethingÂ rotting from the inside out,Â unsure if she could stop the decay or if she was only delaying the inevitable.

Â 

-

Day 1:

Â 

In the aftermath of SageÂ stumbling back in fearÂ at nothing more than Rioâ€™s presence, Agatha sat frozen, a captive in her own body, forced to watch something that should have been beyond corruption, now twisted into something unrecognizable.

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t look angry. She looked horrified, as if she had just witnessed an atrocity more devastating than anything she had encountered in her entire existence. Her eyes were wide with an almost paralyzing disbelief, as though the very foundation of her understanding had been shaken. It was as if Rio were staring at a reality too cruel to accept.

Â 

Agatha wanted to look away, unable to stomach the sight before her, but she couldnâ€™t tear her eyes from her wife. Rio stood rigid, holding herself still with a precision that felt agonizing, as if every muscle in her body were locked in place by sheer force of will. Agatha saw the faint tremor in her fingers, the way they twitched at her side, desperate for motion yet refusing to move. Rio was fighting it- fighting the instinct to reach out, to soothe, to comfort her child the way any mother would.

Â 

But fear held Rio captive, a fear that any movement, no matter how small, might send Sage retreating further.

Â 

Agatha could see it, could feel it as if the thought had passed through her own mind.

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t see the woman who had raised her, who had loved her. She had seen Death for what it truly was, not the quiet, inevitable force Rio had surely once tried to teach her to understand, but something far more merciless. Sage had seen its cruelty, its indifference, its capacity for devastation. And now, standing frozen in the threshold of their living room, Rio was no longer a mother wanting to reach for her child. She was Lady Death, a figure to be feared.

Â 

Rioâ€™s own daughter, afraid ofÂ Death.

Â 

The same child Rio had once cradled in her arms, so impossibly small, trusting without question. Rio had looked down at her baby and wondered whyÂ something as innocent as thisÂ had chosen Death, a monster, to be her mother.

Â 

Instead, Sage had onlyÂ reached up with chubby fingers, giggling, touching the face of Death without fear.Â It had been love at first sight.

Â 

And now?

Â 

That same child stood before Rio and Agatha, fully grown, andÂ terrified of the very thing she had once embraced without hesitation.

Â 

Agatha could feel it in the air, thick and suffocating, the weight of Rioâ€™s worst nightmare crashing down around her. Knowing Rio had most likely always been afraid of this moment. Afraid that the thing she was, the thing she had no choice but to be, would one day eclipse everything else. That it would take her daughter from her- not in the way Death usually took, but in a way far crueler. A mother rejected, not because of what she had done, but because of what she was.

Â 

It was unbearable. Agatha wished, more than anything, that this had never happened- that Rio had never found that godforsaken journal, that she had stepped in before Rio had torn Sage apart with nothing but words.

Â 

And that was the worst part. They were just words.

Â 

It shouldnâ€™t have come to this. It shouldnâ€™t have left Sage looking at her own mother like she was something to be feared. Agatha couldnâ€™t make sense of it, couldnâ€™t reconcile the gravity of Sageâ€™s fright with the reality of what had happened. It didnâ€™t warrant this. It didnâ€™t warrant any of this.

Â 

Nothing compared to watching Rio, the woman she loves beyond reason, stand paralyzed in their own home, too afraid to move, too afraid to breathe, because their daughter was looking at her like she was a monster.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s fingers curled into the couch, nails biting deep into the fabric as she forced herself to stay still. But in her chest, she felt it, a flicker where chaos threatened to catch and burn. Suddenly, she wanted to wage war. To carve a path of destruction through the world with nothing but rage and ruin, to slaughter every witch who had ever dared to cross her, to burn entire cities to ash until there was nothing left but silence. Whatever it took to undo this.

Â 

To prove that Rio had never been and would never be something to fear.

Â 

If Sage was afraid of Rio for what she was, for something she had no choice in, then Agatha would be something worse. She would be the thing to fear, the thing to hate. She would drown out Sageâ€™s terror in something greater, something louder. If it meant never having to see Rio like this, standing in the absence of the certainty that her daughter would always be hers, then Agatha would become whatever monster was necessary.

Â 

Agatha turned to Sage, fury still crackling in her veins, ready to strike. But the moment their eyes met, everything inside her stilled.

Â 

Sage wasnâ€™t looking at Rio. She was looking atÂ Agatha.Â Wide eyed, unmoving, clutching the book so tightly to her chest her fingers had gone white. And she was looking at Agatha like she was the only person who could keep her safe.

Â 

Agatha had never been the one people turned to for protection. She had always been the blade, never the shield. But now, Sage was staring at Agatha like she was the only thing tethering their daughter to safety.

Â 

Agatha despised the shift. Not just the fear in Sageâ€™s face, but the certainty behind it, the quiet, terrible belief that Rio was the one to be afraid of, that Agatha was the only one left to trust.

Â 

Sitting rigid on the couch, Agatha felt pulled in two directions. Sage stood trembling before her, while Rio remained in the threshold of the living room, motionless, wearing the terror of a nightmare made real.Â 

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t know where to move, who to reach for, what to say to fix this.

Â 

Rio made the decision for her. Agatha saw it in the way her gaze dropped, not in doubt but in defense, locking it away before anything else could be touched. When Rio looked up again, her eyes were unreadable, her presence held behind an invisible wall. Rio didnâ€™t meet either of their eyes, only gave a slight nod, â€œIâ€™ll go.â€

Â 

Agatha was already moving, barely aware of herself as she scrambled toward Rio. She thought she heard her own voice, a shout ripped from somewhere deep, but she couldnâ€™t be sure. The panic was too loud. Rio couldnâ€™t leave. Not now. Not like this. Agatha had given too much, fought too hard, poured every part of herself into rebuilding into someone better, someone worth holding on to. Rio was her shield, her sanctuary. Without her, everything she had worked for would mean nothing.

Â 

She caught Rioâ€™s wrist before she could reach the door, her grip firm. â€œYouâ€™re coming back.â€ It wasnâ€™t a question. It was a demand. Rio nodded, the gesture small, almost reluctant, but she didnâ€™t look at Agatha.

Â 

â€œHow long?â€ Agatha demanded, the words escaping harsher than she intended, but couldnâ€™t bring herself to soften.

Â 

Rio gave her nothing in return. No answer, no glance, not even a flicker of acknowledgment. She wasnâ€™t going to answer.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s breath hitched, her vision blurring as she fought to keep control. This time, it barely made it past her lips, a fractured whisper forced through clenched teeth as she fought against the sting behind her eyes. Agathaâ€™s fingers dug into Rioâ€™s wrist, holding on with a force that bordered on pleading- to keep her here, to keep her from becoming something Agatha could no longer reach.

Â 

â€œRio.â€

Â 

Agatha wasnâ€™t asking for much, just an answer, just something solid to hold on to. If Rio needed space, fine. Whatever. But Agatha needed to know she was coming back home.

Â 

Rioâ€™s gaze flickered to Agatha before dropping back to the ground. Her tongue pressed into her cheek, not with its usual smugness but with effort, an attempt to keep her guard from slipping. Rio was trying, trying to hold firm, willing herself to stay untouchable.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re my wife,â€ Agatha said, not as a reminder but as a claim. Agatha had finally let herself accept it, finally chosen to hold onto it, and that had to mean something. Rio owed her an answer. She owed her the same damn certainty Agatha had fought to believe in again.

Â 

â€œA few hours,â€ Rio whispered, the words slipping out too fast, like she regretted saying them the moment they left her lips. Her eyes stayed fixed on the floor, unmoving, unwilling. Agatha was beginning to hate that fucking floor, itching to tear it apart if it meant that Rio would just look at her.

Â 

Agatha could see it- the hesitation, the quiet frustration. Rio had told the truth, but she wasnâ€™t ready to stand in it. She wanted to hold onto her armor just a little longer.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s shoulders relaxed slightly, but her grip on Rioâ€™s wrist didnâ€™t falter. It wasnâ€™t enough. Her eyes burned into Rio, demanding more than half spoken words and avoidance. Agatha refused to let go, refused to let Rio slip any further away, until finally, with a quiet surrender, Rio met her eyes.

Â 

When Rio finally met her eyes, something in her wavered. The hardness didnâ€™t break, but it thinned. â€œJust give me a few hours,â€ Rio said, the words sounding like they were already more than she was willing to give.

Â 

Agatha held Rio there, studying every inch of her face, searching for even the smallest trace of a lie. There was nothing. There never was. It had always been that way, even centuries ago. Rio had never known how to be anything but honest, even when the truth was the cruelest thing she could give.

Â 

Before letting go of Rioâ€™s wrist, Agatha asked, â€œWould begging make you stay?â€ She already knew the answer, but she had to ask. Agatha needed to be certain there was nothing left to offer. This was not about holding Rio back. It was about making sure her wife understood that Agatha would give her anything if she only asked.

Â 

Though if Agatha had any say in it, she would rather not be caught in the crossfire between Sage and Rio when the moment came.

Â 

Rio shook her head, understanding exactly what Agatha was asking. And Agatha understood too. Knew that if she swallowed her pride and begged, Rio wouldnâ€™t walk out that door. But then what? They would be stuck in the same mess, suffocating in it together. A few hours wasnâ€™t much. Just a little space, a little air, a chance to hit pause on the emotional demolition derby this afternoon had turned into. Just a few hours.

Â 

â€œOnly a few hours,â€ Agatha whispered, needing Rio to say it again.Â 

Â 

Rio closed her eyes, exhaling like the words were pulling the last of her strength from her. â€œOnly a few hours,â€ she repeated, not just answering, but giving Agatha the only thing she had left to offer.

Â 

Agatha let go. The moment her fingers slipped away, Rio exhaled a slow breath, like she had been holding herself together just long enough to make it this far. She turned, opened the door, and stepped forward. Then Rio stopped.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t need to look. She already knew. The weather. Sunny. Again. Too sunny. Suspicious.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t have the strength to question it. Not now. Later. She would deal with it later.

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t hesitate, didnâ€™t look back. She just kept moving, down the porch steps, across the dirt path, and straight into the portal. Then she was gone. Agatha stared at the empty space she left behind before shutting the door and letting her head fall against it with a dull thud.

Â 

Time to deal with the other one. The arguably bigger pain in her ass.

Â 

Agatha had thought female friendships were insufferable. But mothers and daughters were an entirely different nightmare. There was no distance, no boundaries, no way to keep them from getting under each otherâ€™s skin. A motherâ€™s love could be a sanctuary just as easily as it could be a cage. A daughterâ€™s defiance could be rebellion or self preservation, depending on the day. They knew each other too well, had too much of the other buried inside them to ever be separate, no matter how much they wanted to be.

Â 

It was invasive. It was relentless. And worst of all, it never faded. Even when they tore themselves apart, it stayed. Lurking in their words, in their silences, in the parts of themselves they couldnâ€™t escape. Whether it was love or fury, devotion or resentment, it lived in them forever.

Â 

And unfortunately for Agatha, she couldnâ€™t escape it. Not even after ending her own relationship with her mother in the most permanent way possible. It was immune to murder, defying even the cleanest severance, somehow still leading her right to a daughter of her own.

Â 

And not only did she get the full experience of the mind fuckery that came with having a daughter, but she also had the rare andÂ covetedÂ privilege of watching her wife go through it too- with the daughter that was, undeniably, theirs. A double feature she never bought tickets for, yet somehow, she was the one getting dragged across the stage while the real stars tore the set apart.

Â 

And in the aftermath, standing in the ruins, having lived through every version of it as a daughter, as a mother, as a wife caught between the two, she knew one thing.

Â 

No matter how many times the stage fell apart, no matter how disastrous the performance, the show always went on. And whether she liked it or not, Agatha would be there. Sometimes pulled into the chaos, sometimes stepping into it on her own, but always returning for the next act.

Â 

Â For better or worse, this was her show too.

Â 

So Agatha put on her big girl panties and braced herself for the next act. She pushed off the door and made her way to the living room, where Sage was parked in the armchair like a kid who had put herself in time out just to look responsible. A preemptive strike. An attempt to soften the inevitable. She wanted Agatha toÂ seeÂ it.. to see Sage in the wreckage, just as much a casualty as the one who had stormed out.

Â 

Agatha dropped onto the couch, the same spot where it she had watched it all unfold. The air still felt heavy with it. She could feel Sage watching her, waiting, but she didnâ€™t acknowledge her. Instead, she threw her head back against the cushion and let out a long, frustrated groan.

Â 

Agatha stayed like that for a moment, staring at the ceiling, refusing to look at Sage when she finally spoke, â€œThat was fucking awful.â€

Â 

Sage stayed silent. Agatha looked up, expecting a response, but none came. Just quiet. She let out a slow breath, steadying herself before speaking.Â â€œI told her to love me, and she lived to ruin me.â€Â 

Â 

Sage furrowed her brow, shifting in her seat. â€œWuthering Heights?â€ Her gaze swept over Agatha, deliberate and unimpressed. â€œFitting.â€

Â 

Agatha blinked.Â Ouch.

Â 

The comparison was obvious, even to Agatha- a love so consuming it blurred the line between devotion and destruction, a bond that refused to die no matter how many times it was torn apart.

Â 

She was reducing centuries of agony, longing, and inevitability into a trope. A literary fucking clichÃ©. As if she and Rio were nothing more than another tragic, self destructive love story.

Â 

Not exactly high praise.

Â 

Agatha narrowed her eyes, lips curving into a tight, humorless smile, â€œHilarious.â€ She swallowed her irritation, because if she reacted the way sheÂ wantedÂ to, she might just wring Sageâ€™s neck.

Â 

Agatha hadnâ€™t meant to hand Sage ammunition. She had intended to make a point. To force her to see where this was headed, to make her understand the devastation waiting for her if she didnâ€™t stop.

Â 

In Wuthering Heights, Catherineâ€™s father had spoken those words after realizing, too late, that the daughter he had loved so completely had become someone he no longer recognized. Someone who had taken that love and, knowingly or not, turned it into ruin. Agatha had meant to draw that parallel. To make Sage see that, whether she intended to or not, she had already caused damage in ways she could never take back.

Â 

And Agatha understood. The first wound wasnâ€™t a choice. Hurt happened. Pain changed people. Sage had reacted, had felt it, and that was understandable. But what came next, what she did with it, mattered more.

Â 

One time was forgivable. One time was human.

Â 

But if Sage kept walking this path, if she let fear fester into resentment and allowed it to shape her, it would harden her until forgiveness tasted disgusting on her tongue, until she could no longer stomach the thought of it at all.

Â 

Agatha had already seen it in the way Sage had nearly killed Billy. She had been so consumed by her fury that she couldnâ€™t see anything else. That kind of anger could eat a person alive. Agatha knew because she had been that person. She had let her rage consume her. She had let it make choices for her. She had let it dictate who she became. And by the time she had stopped to look at what she had done, at what she had lost, it had nearly been too late.

Â 

And she knew Rio hadnâ€™t helped. Her words had already taken root in Sage, sinking into the deepest, most vulnerable parts of her, latching onto every fear and unspoken hurt. In her anger, Rio had planted a seed of doubt, and now it was beginning to grow into something that strangled the soul, twisting itself around Sage, tightening until it left no room for anything else.

Â 

Agatha would try not let that happen. Not to Sage.

Â 

Not her daughter.

Â 

Sage was better than Agatha had ever been. She was good. For all the ways she took after Agatha, she was just as much Rioâ€™s daughter. She had Rioâ€™s kindness.She carried Rioâ€™s emotional depth, the ability to read between silences, to understand wounds even when no one spoke of them. She had Rioâ€™s instinct to care, to nurture, to make things grow- whether that was plants, people, or the fragile bonds between them.

Â 

But even good people could lose themselves if they didnâ€™t stop to see what was being lost along the way.

Â 

Agatha let her head fall back against the couch, staring at the ceiling as if the answer might be hidden in the cracks.Â Â She was grasping for anything, any way to bridge the widening gap between her wife and daughter.

Â 

This was new to Agatha- trying to put out a fire instead of stoking it.

Â 

She looked at Sage, who sat motionless, staring blankly at the coffee table. She was too still, too quiet, lost in a place Agatha couldnâ€™t follow.

Â 

â€œCan you justâ€¦â€ Agathaâ€™s voice faltered, the words slipping away before she could catch them. After a beat, she exhaled, quieter this time. â€œWhat can I do to help fix this?â€ It wasnâ€™t a plea, nor a demand. Just defeat.

Â

Â

Chapter Notes

alright if this is where you're starting go back a chapter (i posted twice in the same night hehe)

a little nervous about this chapter, sage gets a temporary villain arch but what else can you expect? she's the child of death and agatha harkness

this chapter imo is a bit heavier than the last (a lot) BUT THERE IS RESOLUTION AT THE END OF THIS CHAPTER

** edit: i made a playlist of all the songs that have inspired certain parts of this story or that just remind me of agathario in general.. if you want to check it out and give it a listen here's the link: https://open.spotify.com/playlist/2TiqTIBOGwPFuvLFEM68LG?si=_u-I83e4SZqrHNcHBD_GSg

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Day 2:

Â 

Rio and Agatha sat on the couch, the quiet of the morning settling around them, the television playing low in the background. At the first creak of Sageâ€™s footsteps descending the stairs, Rio tensed beside her, body going taut like a wire pulled too tight. Agatha didnâ€™t turn to look. Acknowledging it felt intrusive, like stepping into a moment that wasnâ€™t meant for her.

Â 

Sage moved past them toward the study without so much as a glance in their direction.

Â 

Everything had been carefully put away- every book, every scrap of Rioâ€™s restless research, every desperate attempt to understand the growing distance between them. Even Sageâ€™s journal had been hidden, a safeguard against the kind of discovery that would only push her further away.

Â 

And then, Sage stopped.

Â 

Rio nearly gave herself whiplash turning to see her, eyes locking onto where their daughter stood, frozen mid step. Agatha didnâ€™t have to look to know what had caught Sageâ€™s attention.

Â 

The fish tank.

Â 

The soft glow of the saltwater filtered through the morning light, casting slow moving ripples across the walls, mimicking the oceanâ€™s pulse.

Â 

Rio was on her feet in an instant, turning to Sage with barely restrained anticipation. She looked like a child unveiling a masterpiece, like she had built something worth marveling at and was waiting (hoping) for the validation that would make it all worth it.

Â 

Rioâ€™s voice broke the silence, overly casual yet undeniably eager. â€œItâ€™s a fish tank. With fish. Saltwater, like the ocean.â€

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t respond. Her brow furrowed, lips pressing together as if she were trying to understand why Rio was speaking to her at all. There was no curiosity in her expression, no flicker of recognition, just quiet, detached bewilderment. If Agatha had been paying the exchange any real attention, the look alone would have sent her over the edge.

Â 

The light in the living room shifted. The sunlight that had filled the space only moments ago was swallowed by a sudden overcast, clouds stretching thick across the sky.

Â 

Rio stood facing Sage, shoulders still squared with lingering expectation, but the certainty in her stance had already begun to wane. The eager anticipation that had once lit her eyes only moments ago faded, replaced by something subdued, something retreating into itself.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t need to guess why.

Â 

Rioâ€™s voice was softer now, hesitant in a way that made Agathaâ€™s chest tighten. â€œCool, huh?â€ The words wavered, her usual confidence absent.

Â 

Sage barely acknowledged her. She gave a half hearted shrug, muttering a quiet, â€œSure,â€ with little interest. Her tone lacked curiosity, as if Rioâ€™s efforts were nothing more than an afterthought rather than the deliberate gesture they had been, built with the singular hope that Sage would give a shit.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s fingers dug into the couch cushions, her knuckles white with restraint. She willed herself to stay still, to keep her eyes fixed ahead, knowing that if she looked- if she so much as glanced in their direction- she would cross the couch in an instant. She would take Sage by the shoulders, shake her until she understood, until she saw the devastation she was leaving in her wake. Not just in Rio, but in all of them.

Â 

Instead, Agatha stayed still and listened.

Â 

Sageâ€™s footsteps carried her toward the study. Her tone brightened in an instant. â€œTootie,â€ she greeted, voice light and affectionate. The moment she spoke, the clouds outside thinned, sunlight returning as if it had never left.

Â 

Agatha listened as Sage rifled through the bookshelf, the occasional thud of shifting spines filling the quiet. A triumphant, â€œBingo,â€ followed before her footsteps retreated toward the backyard.

Â 

Rio remained in the same spot, staring at the empty space where Sage had been. For a moment, she looked lost.

Â 

Then, with a quiet breath, Rio straightened her shoulders and nodded to herself like she was willing herself to accept whatever scraps Sage was willing to give.

Â 

â€œAt least she spoke to me, right?â€ The words were forced into resembling optimism, but they carried no real warmth. â€œSilver lining.â€

Â 

Rio turned back to the couch, dropping down beside Agatha, pressing as close as she could without asking for comfort outright.

Â 

Agatha said nothing. She leaned in and kissed Rio on the cheek.

Â 

Â

Day 4:

Â 

Agatha was getting dressed for the day, but something felt off. The familiar scent of coffee, the one Rio always made for her, was missing. That alone was unusual.

Â 

Â 

She stepped out of the bedroom and made her way toward the kitchen, only to stop when she spotted Rio sitting on the couch. A book lay open in her lap, her eyes fixed on the pages with an expression caught between offense and outright irritation. Whatever she was reading, she had taken it as a personal insult.

Â 

"Found it in the couch," Rio muttered, her voice flat.

Â 

Rio didn't look up as Agatha approached, her fingers motionless against the open pages. When Agatha reached her, Rio stood abruptly. She shoved the book into Agathaâ€™s hands like holding onto it any longer would burn her.

Â 

Agatha glanced down at the book in her hands. It was a copy of the same one Rio had defaced at the bookstore, Emily Dickinsonâ€™s face printed across the cover. She had caught Sage reading it just the day before. When Agatha gave her a knowing look, Sage had shoved it into the couch cushions with a wide, toothy grin, dismissing the moment entirely. Agatha let it go. She had assumed, perhaps a bit naively, that Sage was softening, drawn to the fragments of life Rio and Agatha had lived before her. Sage devoured their past like a story she had only just discovered, one filled with all the angst she seemed to thrive on.

Â 

Sage had slipped the book into the pile Rio bought for her at the bookstore, which was hardly the problem. That was entirely in character. The problem wasnâ€™t the book itself but the page Rio must have turned to when she pulled it from the couch.

Â 

Agatha's gaze fell to the passage in front of her. There was only one annotation in the entire book, a single mark left by Sageâ€™s hand. The first two lines of the poem in the very first stanza were circled:

Â 

"Because I could not stop for Death,
She kindly stopped for me."

Â 

In the margin beside it, Sage had written in that familiar slanted script:

â€˜Death is not kind. She does not wait. She takes.â€™

Â 

Agatha scoffed. That annotation wasn't just utter bullshit- it was a lie. And she knew for a fact that Sage didnâ€™t believe it. Her daughter had spent weeks destroying that very belief, the one Agatha had held onto for nearly three centuries. The note seemed intentional, purposeful.

Â 

Agatha tore the page from the book with such force, it snapped the spine beyond repair. She let the book fall to the floor, then kicked it under the couch without a second thought. Crumpling the page in her fist, Agatha shoved it into her mouth and swallowed.

Â 

It wasn't Agathaâ€™s proudest moment. Not even close. But it also wasn't the first time she had eaten a piece of paper just to make sure no one ever had to look at it again, including herself.

Â 

Of course, Rio took the blow with ease, brushing it off as if it had never touched her. Agatha had seen it countless times before and had been the cause of it more than she cared to admit. Rio had a way of absorbing hurt without letting it surface, carrying it in silence as if it had never reached her at all. But Agatha knew better. Beneath the indifference, there was that same quiet patience, the same tireless hope that soon enough her daughter would see past her anger and forgive her. Rio had never been one to demand forgiveness. She would wait for it, whether it came or not.

Â 

-

Â 

Day 7:

Â 

On multiple occasions, Sage pulled Agatha away from Rio. Agatha justified it as an opportunity to work on her, to slowly guide her toward forgiveness. Rio, as always, took it without complaint, never letting it come between her and Agatha. But the more their daughter chose Agatha, the more obvious Sage made it. She wanted Agatha, and she made sure Rio knew it.

Â 

This particular morning, Rio had been waiting in the living room for Sage to wake up and come downstairs, ready to try again, ready to fix things. The second she heard footsteps upstairs near Sageâ€™s bedroom door, she sprang up from the armchair and moved to the threshold, attempting to lean casually against its frame. She readjusted a few times, shifting her weight, trying to look casual. Her arms crossed, then uncrossed, then crossed again.

Â 

Agatha, her back pressed against the arm of the couch, legs stretched across the cushions, pretended to read. Without looking at Rio, she mumbled, â€œCrossed.â€

Â 

Rio crossed her arms too tightly, making Agatha groan under her breath. She jerked her book down with both hands, barely keeping her frustration in check over her wife's complete inability to look natural.

Â 

â€œLooser!â€ Agatha hissed. â€œYou look like you have a stick up your ass with how tight youâ€™re clenching.â€

Â 

To Agathaâ€™s relief, Rio actually listened. She adjusted instantly, shifting into a stance that finally looked natural, almost effortless. For once, she managed to pull off the unimpressed, relaxed demeanor she had been failing at all morning. Agatha had to admit, Rio looked good like that.

Â 

Without missing a beat, Rio spoke, her tone casual, almost inviting. " Housewives NYC marathon? Agatha still hasnâ€™t seen all of it. Fresh eyes to witness Dorinda Medley in all her glory. Oh-â€ Rioâ€™s expression brightened slightly, â€œthe episode where Aviva slams her leg prosthesis on the table in the middle of a packed restaurant and yells, â€˜The only thing that is artificial or fake about me is thisâ€™?"

Â 

Rio including Agatha in this was a smart move. Sage was a hopeless romantic in every sense, always wanting her family to be whole. She had once been desperate to know them both as her mothers, pulling them together with a determination that bordered on stubbornness. She had dragged them to the beach, packed matching pajamas they never even got to wear. Agatha had thought, for certain, that this plan would work. That Sage still wanted this, even if she would rather withhold it now than admit it.

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t respond right away. The silence stretched long enough for Rio to try again.

Â 

"Just thought we could all rot on the couch today and watch women in their fifties get blackout drunk on national television. Could be fun." Rio shrugged, arms still crossed, her delivery as casual as if the outcome didnâ€™t matter.

Â 

Sageâ€™s green eyes, a little less vibrant than usual, flicked briefly to Agatha, lounging on the couch. Agatha raised the book in her hands just slightly, pretending to be absorbed in The Sea Around Us by Rachel Carson. It was a deliberate choice. Sageâ€™s favorite. The perfect cherry on top of what should have been an ideal day- family, reality TV, and an excuse to pester Agatha about science and poetry, somehow twisting oceanography into a metaphor for her life. There was no way Sage could say no to that.

Â 

But she did.

Â 

Sage glanced back at Rio and said, â€œWe already have plans. Sorry.â€ She shrugged, unmoving from her spot at the bottom of the stairs.

Â 

"Plans?" Rio questioned flatly, already bracing for the lie. "What plans?

Â 

Sage hesitated for a second too long, â€œUhâ€¦ weâ€™re gonna get the calculus workbooks and see who can solve the problems faster.â€

Â 

What the fuck?

Â 

Rioâ€™s arms dropped to her sides. â€œWhat?â€ The confusion was plain on her face as she tried to make sense of Sageâ€™s excuse. She pointed a lazy thumb toward Agatha before looking at her, utterly bewildered by Sageâ€™s excuse. Sage, on the other hand, looked like she had pulled the answer straight out of her ass.

Â 

â€œAgatha hates math.â€

Â 

Agatha really did hate math. With every fiber of her being.

Â 

Rio, however, continued without missing a beat. â€œI love math.â€

Â 

Agatha had to fight the urge to roll her eyes. Rio had always loved it. Math followed rigid principles, structured logic, and definitive answers. It made sense to Rio in a way the surface and the people on it rarely did.

Â 

All the reasons Rio loved math were the very things as to why Agatha fucking despised it. Itâ€™s strict adherence to rules, the rigid principles, and its absolute answers. It was everything that went against the very nature of how Agatha had always operated. Magic, manipulation, and survival require adaptability, intuition, and reading between the lines, none of which math allows. There is no room for instinct, no way to outthink the equation, no ability to bend the answer to suit the situation.

Â 

But there was an edge to this that made it land harder than it should have. Math wasnâ€™t just a random choice. It was what Rio loved, Sage certainly knew that, which made Agatha wonder if the excuse had been as thoughtless as it seemed.

Â 

â€œWe can do that another time,â€ Rio said, her tone almost even. But Agatha caught the slight falter in her voice, a misstep so brief that Rio covered it almost immediately. A moment later, she sounded effortless again, as if this whole thing wasnâ€™t bothering her the way Agatha knew that it was. â€œIâ€™d be the better competition anyway.â€

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t turn to Agatha for support. Didnâ€™t look at her for agreement. This was between her and Sage, and Agatha appreciated her wifeâ€™s ability to separate the two. As selfless as ever.

Â 

It would have been easy for Rio to drag Agatha into it, to turn this into a united front, to force Sage into facing both of them at once. But she never did. No matter how much Sage pushed her, no matter how many times she turned her back on her, Rio refused to let her hurt bleed into Agatha. Rio never used her as a shield, never sought reassurance, never looked to her for permission to be angry.

Â 

And Agatha knew how much it must have stung. She heard it in the way Rioâ€™s tone faltered, a misstep so brief that she recovered almost immediately. She had seen it in the way Rio paused before speaking, in the way she took each rejection like another step in a never ending test of patience. Still, she held firm, waiting, always waiting, hoping that one day their daughter might turn around and meet her halfway.

Â 

Sage, however, was far less forgiving.Â 

Â 

She turned her head to Agatha, her expression composed, but the tension in her voice betrayed her. â€œWe had plans,â€ Sageâ€™s eyebrows lifted, the plea beneath it intentional rather than desperate. She was cornered and she knew it, but instead of conceding, she shifted the burden onto Agatha with just enough expectation in her voice to make refusal feel like betrayal. This wasnâ€™t just about avoiding Rio. It was a careful action, a test disguised as a simple statement, a silent pull for Agatha to choose without making it seem like a choice at all.

Â 

Agatha saw the moment Rio caught it and shut it down before it could take hold. She wasn't going to let Sage pull Agatha into this. Their relationships with her were too carefully maintained, too deliberately rebuilt to risk breaking now. They had all come too far to let a single misstep pull them backward.

Â 

â€œThatâ€™s fine.â€ Rio shrugged, casual and unbothered. Her mask was back up, smooth and effortless. Honestly, the act was so convincing that even her voice carried an easy warmth, as if she genuinely liked the idea of Sage and Agatha spending more time together. As if she had never been hoping for a different answer.

Â 

Agatha loved her wife all the more for it. Rio had always been her shield, never once making Agatha be hers. She took every blow to the chest without hesitation, absorbing the worst of it so Agatha never had to.

Â 

â€œIâ€™ve got shit to take care of in the garden anyway.â€

Â 

Rio moved toward Sage, her arm lifting slightly like she was about to ruffle her daughterâ€™s hair. It was supposed to be easy, a simple no hard feelings gesture. But then, she hesitated, hand hovering just inches away.

Â 

Agatha saw the exact moment the doubt crept in. Not uncertainty- Rio was never uncertain. This was fear. A ridiculous, fleeting panic that Sage might flinch again.

Â 

Sage didn't flinch. She didnâ€™t move at all. But Agatha immediately noticed the dark clouds outside begin to roll in. Still, Rio had already hesitated, and now her hand was stuck midair like she had forgotten what she was doing. Instead of retreating like a normal person, she made it worse. She gave the air near Sageâ€™s head a few stiff, uncomfortable pats, as if she were blessing her with some unseen magic. As if that was normal.

Â 

Then, realizing how absurd she mustâ€™ve looked, Rio panicked further and dragged her palm down an invisible line in front of Sageâ€™s face, miming some strange, touchless caress like she was performing a blessing at a church neither of them belonged to.

Â 

Rio groaned at herself and stalked off toward the backyard, leaving Sage standing there, watching her go with the same deadpan stare as a teenager who had just witnessed their mother try and fail to use slang.

Â 

At first, it almost seemed funny. But the longer Agatha sat with it, the more it pressed down on her. Rio was still struggling to find her place with Sage, still unsure of where she stood as her mother. They were on opposite sides of something neither of them knew how to bridge. It was not them. It was careful. Strained. Like watching two people who should have known each other inside and out but were stuck pretending otherwise.

Â 

Agatha snapped her book shut and thumped it against her forehead a few times, trying to knock the thought away and failing. If Agatha were still alive, she was certain she wouldâ€™ve rattled her brain into a concussion by now with the number of head banging moments she had been forced to endure.

Â 

She heard Sage step into the living room, catching a glimpse of her moving past the couch on her way to the study.

Â 

â€œIf you bring a math workbook anywhere near me, I will not hesitate to beat you with it,â€ Agatha said, not bothering to look up.

Â 

Sage immediately corrected course, pivoting on her heel and making a sharp U-turn back to the couch.

Â 

Day 9:

Â 

Agatha heard Rio yelling from the kitchen. There was panic in her wifeâ€™s voice, real and unfiltered, which was enough to send Agatha running. She skidded to a stop, taking in the scene.

Â 

Rio was on top of the counter, pressed so far into the corner beneath the floating cabinets it was a wonder she hadnâ€™t phased through the wall. A spatula was clenched in her hand, pointed downward like a weapon. Rio looked genuinely horrified.

Â 

Agatha followed the spatulaâ€™s aim and immediately understood why.

Â 

Brucie had Rio cornered, hissing violently, lunging at her despite the fact that she was well out of reach. Brucie did not seem to care. She was relentless.

Â 

â€œGet back!â€ Rio shouted, jabbing the spatula toward her with the conviction of a knight defending a castle. â€œGet back!â€

Â 

Agatha barked Brucieâ€™s name, snapping at her to fuck off.

Â 

To both womenâ€™s shock, Brucie actually listened. She stilled, turned away from Rio without a second thought, and slithered straight toward Agatha instead. As the snake passed, she brushed against Agathaâ€™s foot in a way that felt almost affectionate before disappearing as if nothing had happened.

Â 

Agatha stood frozen, jaw slack, staring after Brucie like she had just witnessed a miracle.

Â 

Brucie -Sageâ€™s familiar, who despised everything and everyone that was not Sage- not only listened to Agatha but showed her affection.

Â 

Agatha looked up at Rio, still processing what had just happened. Rio, however, looked wrecked. Her expression twisted, her hurt laid bare. Still perched on the counter, she slammed the spatula into the sink with a loud clang and jumped down in the same motion. Without a word, she stormed past Agatha.

Â 

Agatha called after her, but it was useless.

Â 

-

Â 

Day 12:Â 

Â 

It was no longer a question. Whatever illusion of choice Sage had left them was gone, stripped away with the same precision she had used to set the stage. Agatha wasnâ€™t just realizing it. She was standing in the middle of it, seeing the full extent of what their daughter had been constructing all along.

Â 

Sage wasnâ€™t only trying to make Agatha choose her to hurt Rio, to even the score. That was only one move in a much larger, more intricate game. If Agatha sided with Sage, Rio would fracture even further, pushed closer to the breaking point until she finally caved to what Sage was after. If Agatha chose Rio instead, it wouldnâ€™t end the game. It would just give Sage more reason to dig in deeper. She would tell herself she had been abandoned, use it to justify whatever came next.

Â 

This had actually never been about a single decision.

Â 

Sage had been playing the long game before Agatha even realized that there was even a game to be played. Shifting the pieces where she wanted, maneuvering her and Rio into positions where every outcome led back to Sage, and all without them ever questioning how they got there. For a week and some change, Rio had been breaking under the heaviness of it, and Agatha, who had spent centuries perfecting the art of control and seeing every angle before a move was made, had been too caught up in the wreckage to notice.

Â 

This wasnâ€™t about stealing a title. Sage wasnâ€™t forcing Rio to let go. She was breaking her apart piece by piece, wearing her down until keeping her title no longer felt like power. It felt like mercy. A final act of acquiescence that wouldnâ€™t be taken from Rio, but willingly given. Not because her wife wanted to, but because she would believe she had to. It would feel inevitable.Â 

Â 

Their daughter was waiting for the moment where Rio would be desperate enough to beg for forgiveness. Desperate enough to do whatever it took to earn it.

Â 

Desperate enough to surrender Death.

Â 

And Agatha had walked right into it without realizing.

Â 

And it was fucking foolproof. Every move precise, every shift inevitable. If Agatha hadnâ€™t been so goddamn furious, she might have been impressed.

Â 

The realization hit like stepping out of a hex, the kind that lingers even after itâ€™s broken. It clung to her, disorienting and inescapable, leaving Agatha to wade through the aftermath of something she hadnâ€™t even realized she was under. Before she could think better of it, Agatha was already moving. She took the stairs two at a time, each step feeding the anger curling in her gut. By the time she reached Sageâ€™s door, she didnâ€™t bother knocking. She threw it open with enough force to rattle the frame.

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t react. She was at her desk, pencil in hand, twirling it lazily between her fingers. But what made Agathaâ€™s stomach churn was the tune she was whistling. The Ballad of the Witchesâ€™ Road. Low and smooth, like she had all the time in the world. She didnâ€™t turn around immediately, just let the melody drag out before finally spinning her chair to face Agatha.

Â 

If Agatha werenâ€™t on a mission, she might have stopped in her tracks at the color of Sageâ€™s eyes. They were still green, but something about them was off. The vibrance was drained, the life dimmed, and if Agatha looked closely, she could swear there was a ring of gray circling her pupils. Agatha couldnâ€™t tell for sure, and honestly, right now, she didnâ€™t particularly give a fuck.

Â 

Sageâ€™s brows lifted in delight at the rage she found waiting for her.Â 

Â 

Agatha wouldnâ€™t react. Wouldnâ€™t give her the satisfaction.

Â 

This was a game now. A long, premeditated one.

Â 

Sage remained seated at her desk, exuding the kind of practiced indifference that might have been convincing if Agatha didnâ€™t know better. Her daughter didnâ€™t flinch, didnâ€™t even have the courtesy to look surprised. Of course, she didnâ€™t. This was an invitation, not an ambush. A silent acknowledgement that Agatha had finally caught up, that the opening moves were made, and now Sage was preparing for Agatha to take her seat at the players table.

Â 

There was no arrogance in Sageâ€™s posture, no gloating, nothing so clumsy as a smirk. Just patience. The confidence of someone who had invested time in arranging the board and was now waiting to see what Agatha would do with the knowledge she had just gained.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t sit.

Â 

She didnâ€™t lean in, didnâ€™t engage the way Sage wanted. She closed the space between them, stopping just short of touching her. Close enough to remind Sage exactly who she was playing against. Then she lifted a single finger, pointed it at her daughter, and said, â€œStop.â€

Â 

Agatha would not plea. Would not reprimand. She made a move placed with accuracy.

Â 

The pencil kept turning between Sageâ€™s fingers, but her expression shifted just slightly, something almost imperceptible. The faintest flicker of reassessment. Not hesitation. Not doubt. Just even more calculation. The moment when a player registers an opponentâ€™s move and recalibrates, adjusting their strategy to account for an unexpected shift on the board.

Â 

Agatha held her ground, her face impassive, lifting her brow just enough to let Sage know exactly where they stood. I see you. I know exactly what youâ€™re doing.

Â 

And more importantly. I am not playing this game the way you expect me to.

Â 

Then, without another word, Agatha turned and left, slamming the door behind her.

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t call after her.

Â 

Â 

Day 14:Â 

Â 

Two days passed before Agatha spoke a word of it to Rio. It wasnâ€™t hesitation, nor was it uncertainty. She had seen Sageâ€™s design with absolute clarity the moment she stepped out of that room, had understood the shape of it in a way that left no room for doubt. But knowing was one thing. Admitting it was another.

Â 

To say it aloud would be to acknowledge the truth in its entirety- that their daughter had not simply fallen heir to her cunning but had refined it into something far more meticulous. Sage wasnâ€™t just clever. She was methodical, patient in ways that Agatha had never been, tearing away choice under the guise of giving it. She wasnâ€™t forcing Rio to yield; she was leading her there, carefully untwisting her until surrender felt indistinguishable from absolution.

Â 

So Agatha waited, stalling the moment she would have to look Rio in the eye and confirm it. But avoidance wouldnâ€™t change the nature of what was happening, and her wife, of all people, deserved to hear it from Agatha rather than realizing it on her own.

Â 

That night, as Agatha lay beside Rio, staring at the ceiling, she finally spoke. "Itâ€™s a game," Agatha said. The words felt heavier than they should have, like naming it gave it more power than it already had.

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t ask what she meant. She didnâ€™t even turn to look at Agatha. She took a slow breath, one that came not from realization but from something settled, something Rio had already accepted. "I know," Rio said, her voice quiet. "Itâ€™s in your fine print."

Â 

Fucking ouch.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s stomach turned at the simplicity of it.

Â 

Agatha realized that Rio had already seen it, not as a possibility but as a certainty, as inescapable as the roles they had both been playing without ever agreeing to the rules. She had recognized it before Agatha had, understood the rhythm of it in a way that suggested this wasnâ€™t new to her.

Â 

And, of course, it wasnâ€™t.

Â 

Agatha turned her head, studying Rioâ€™s expression in the dim light, searching for anything beneath that patience, some sign of frustration or anger, something to tell her that Rio hadnâ€™t just accepted this without resistance. But there was nothing.

Â 

Agatha's wife had already braced for it, had already made peace with the truth long before was willing to speak it.

Â 

Rio had seen it in the way Sage moved her pieces, in the way she pushed without ever seeming to, in the way she had led them both exactly where she wanted them to be. Every refusal, every moment of resistance, had been another step toward Sageâ€™s grandest scheme.

Â 

And Agatha had been the last one to see it.

Â 

-

Day 17:Â 

Â 

It had been five days since Agatha understood the full extent of what Sage was doing and three since she had admitted it to Rio, though her wife had already seen it for what it was. Yet every morning, Rio woke with the same determination, ready to try again, as if persistence alone could undo what Sage had already set in motion. Rio ignored their daughterâ€™s actions, refusing to acknowledge them, as if putting them into words would only cement them further. It didnâ€™t seem to matter how much it chipped away at her or how it hollowed her out. The hope that Sage would eventually give in was the only thing keeping her going.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s wife and daughter were both chasing mirages, sustained by the illusion that if they just kept moving forward, they would eventually reach something real. But Agatha saw the truth- there was no prize at the end of this. Rio had let herself become a willing piece on a board Sage commanded, every move unfolding exactly as she planned. And yet, the game stretched on, an endless loop with no victor, as if neither of them could see that it was never meant to end, only to keep them playing.

Â 

And all Agatha could do was sit there, biting her tongue and willing her frustration to settle. With each passing day, she felt that familiar chaos smoldering inside her, clawing at her ribs, creeping closer to a way out. It was getting stronger. She could almost smell the embers catching, threatening to ignite.

Â 

But the fire never had a chance to spread.

Â 

Rio had always been there. When the ghosts of chaos banged on the doors of Agathaâ€™s chest, clawing to turn her ribs into ruins, when she no longer had the strength to hold them shut- Rio was there. Not just a shield, not just salvation. She was the ocean that surged through those haunted halls, sweeping away the darkness before it could consume Agatha whole.

Â 

Though Rio would never confront the situation head on, she had her own way of pulling Agatha free, sweeping her up in distraction and drowning out the havoc before it could take hold. Sometimes that meant losing themselves in each other like a pair of horny teenagers, tangled up in stolen moments behind closed doors. Other times it was the thrill of sneaking around the house, exchanging teasing glances and whispered flirtations as if they werenâ€™t already bound together. And sometimes it was just talking, about nothing in particular, letting one thought tumble into the next. The types of conversations that started with an offhand remark about the garden and somehow ended up unraveling the entire history of a forgotten spell or debating whether the moon ever got tired of watching over the world. Anything to pull Agatha away, to remind her that not everything had to be a battle.

Â 

It was always just enough. Enough to wake up the next day, enough to let herself be pulled into whatever ridiculous scheme Sage had concocted, enough to keep moving forward. It gave Agatha a reason to hold back, to stay on the sidelines instead of diving headfirst into the mess Sage was making. Getting involved would only make things worse for Rio.

Â 

Agatha refused to play Sageâ€™s game. So she feigned ignorance with the confidence that only came from lifetimes of deception. She pretended she had never pieced it together, never seen the pattern, never recognized the same ruthless deviousness in her daughter's eyes that once lived in her own. As if she wasnâ€™t staring into a mirror of the past. As if she didnâ€™t see Sage tearing them apart, tearing Rio apart bit by bit with every passing day.

Â 

But Agatha had never been as patient as Rio, and now, apparently, Sage. Her patience was thinning, stretched to its limits. Agatha was restless, ready to act, to say something, to bring it all out into the open. More than anything, she wanted to talk to her wife, to hear Rio say she was okay after enduring Sageâ€™s relentless attacks, one after another.

Â 

Agatha could see the strain pressing into Rioâ€™s posture, the subtle shifts in her demeanor. It was affecting her, no matter how unshaken she tried to appear. And yet Rio stood firm, treating it like it was just another bump in the never ending road of Sageâ€™s bullshit.

Â 

Agatha had tried. She had given Rio every opportunity to talk, to work through it together, to find some kind of solution before this shitshow spiraled any further. She had approached it carefully at first, then more directly when Rio brushed her off, but no matter how Agatha framed it, Rio refused to engage. Her wife deflected, changed the subject, acted as if there was nothing to discuss. Until tonight, in what could only be described as sheer, childish behavior, Rio stormed out of their bedroom and threw herself onto the couch dramatically, draping an arm over her face as if the weight of the world had forced her there.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t entertain Rioâ€™s tomfoolery for a fucking second.

Â 

She followed, grabbed Rio by the front of her shirt, and hauled her up with enough force to send her staggering. Before Rio could collect herself, Agatha shoved her right back toward their bedroom, shut the door behind them, and let her temper take over.Â 

Â 

Agathaâ€™s words cut through whatever ridiculous pretense Rio had been clinging to. This wasnâ€™t a game they played anymore. This wasnâ€™t a battle of wills she was going to entertain. If Rio ever pulled this stunt again, Agatha would personally build her a doghouse, board by board, and she could sleep in it indefinitely. Maybe forever, if Rio was foolish enough to test it twice.

Â 

Rio never tested it again.

Â 

Day 19:

Â 

Today, Rio had stormed into the living room, an open laptop in one hand, and without a word, snatched the remote from Agatha before switching the input on the TV. Neither Sage nor Agatha reacted, only watching in silence as Rio connected a cable from the laptop to the screen. A manila folder sat on top of the keyboard, its contents unknown.

Â 

Outside, the sunlight that had flooded the room only moments ago disappeared, swallowed by a sudden blanket of clouds. It was always like this- clear skies until Rio came within five feet of Sage, and then, without fail, the light vanished. Another unspoken message. A reminder. The endless sunshine only proved that Sage wasnâ€™t suffering the way Agatha knew Rio was, that she was untouched by the damage she was causing.

Â 

It was fucking mean. It was so ugly. And Agatha wasnâ€™t sure how much more of this she could take.

Â 

They watched as Rio navigated through her files with ease, opening a PowerPoint presentation without so much as a glance in their direction. A moment later, the first slide filled the screen, its title bold making it impossible to ignore:

Â 

"The 25 Greatest Moments of Agnes Oâ€™Connorâ€™s Reign of Terror: A Deep Dive into Westviewâ€™s Local Reddit and Neighborhood Watch Facebook Page- Ranked from Mildly Amusing to Absolutely Legendary."

Â 

Agatha blinked. Twenty five seemedâ€¦ excessive. Ten, maybe fifteen instances would have been reasonable, but twenty five? That felt like overkill. Then again, if Rio had taken the time to make a whole PowerPoint about it, Agatha had the sinking feeling this was only the highlight reel.

Â 

Rio had even included footnotes and an aggressive color coded rating system in the presentation.

Â 

Sage let out a snort, barely stifled, and Agatha nearly wrenched her own neck trying not to turn and confirm it had actually happened.Â  Instead, she forced herself to keep her gaze on the ridiculous, infuriatingly gorgeous woman in front of her.

Â 

Agatha saw the moment it registered. Rio didnâ€™t whip her head up or let her expression crack with shock. But she did glance up, a quiet shift pulled by instinct alone. Her eyes flicked to Sage, and for the briefest moment, a smile ghosted across her lips. Small, fleeting, but it was there.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t giddy, wasnâ€™t triumphant. Justâ€¦ relief.Â Like hearing that single, unguarded sound had filled Rio in some quiet way, had given her just enough fuel to keep moving forward. As if it had reminded her that something was still there, no matter how buried, no matter how brief.

Â 

Rio let the moment slip away without a word, turning back to the screen like it had never happened. But Agatha felt it linger, warm and aching in her chest. It melted through every part of her, leaving only the love that had never once let go.

Â 

Rio grabbed the manila folder and strolled toward Agatha, holding it out with a smirk. â€œI took the liberty of printing a physical copy for the lovely lady who struggles to read words on any type of screen.â€

Â

Â 

Rio, unfazed, dropped into the armchair, laptop settling onto her lap as she clicked to begin. She read the title slide aloud, then giggled to herself- clearly amused by her own cleverness. Agatha, on the other hand, thought it was less clever and more idiotic.

Â 

Still, she didnâ€™t protest. Because, despite herself, she was curious. And she was absolutely staying for the show.

Â 

Rio tapped the trackpad, and the next slide appeared- a hilariously blurry, poorly cropped profile picture of Agnes Oâ€™Connor, taken from the least flattering angle possible. Â

Â 

Okay. Not a bad start.

Â 

Rio clicked to the next slide, barely getting through the first word before Sage cut her off.

Â 

â€œI donâ€™t want to do this,â€ Sage said flatly, arms crossed tight over her chest, her entire posture suddenly radiating irritation.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha felt her upper lip curled, one side lifting in disbelief. Her brows pulled in, her expression stuck frozen between offended and annoyed.

Â

Â

Â 

Sage exhaled sharply through her nose, her arms still crossed. Her expression was carefully cool, but Agatha caught the telltale signs of a potential losing battle- the twitch in her jaw, the way her gaze flickered downward for just a second too long.

Â

Â 

â€œThatâ€™s not funny,â€ she mumbled, her voice flat, but there was the slightest shake to it, just enough to betray her.

Â

Â 

Sageâ€™s entire posture stiffened. Her fingers curled against her arms, nails digging in just enough to make her knuckles go white. The shift cracked, like a wire snapping under too much tension. Â

Â 

She was angry.

Â 

Agatha looked over to Rio. Rio, completely unfazed, flicked her gaze toward Agatha before shifting back to Sage. Then, with an exaggerated roll of her eyes, she leaned back into the armchair and tossed a lazy hand in the air, an unimpressed invitation. Rio was silently telling Sage to Go ahead. Â

Â 

â€œI donâ€™t want to hang out with you!â€

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Sage pressed forward, voice shaking with pure unadulterated fury. â€œI donâ€™t want to be around you. Youâ€™re acting like this is normal, like youâ€™re normal.â€ Her breath hitched, her mouth twisting like the words tasted bitter.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re not fucking normal, youâ€™re-â€

Â

Â 

Sage did not.

Â 

Since all of this started, hesitation flickered across Sageâ€™s face. Agatha recognized it immediately, the slightest shift in the color of her eyes, the briefest crack in the performance. Finally. Beneath all the anger, beneath the instinct to wound before she could be wounded, was their Sage.

Â 

Her shoulders sagged, just slightly. Her breath wavered for half a second. The rage had been carrying her, keeping her upright, pushing her forward, but now it was slipping. She looked like she had been waiting for someone to stop her, to pull her back before she went too far, before she said something she could never take back.

Â 

Over the course of weeks, they had allowed Sage to throw her tantrum, to hone her words into weapons and wield them recklessly. They let her manipulate, let her test the limits of how much destruction she could cause, let her believe that if she burned everything down, she would somehow emerge victorious. Instead, all she was left with was the aftermath, the ruins of something never built to withstand time.

Â 

It hadnâ€™t. It never would, and it seemed like Sage was struggling to come to terms with that.

Â 

And now, standing there, fists clenched, breathing uneven, their daughter was left with exactly what she had created. Nothing.

Â 

To Agatha, this small victory tasted like honey.

Â 

And then, just like that, Sage pulled herself back together. The hesitation vanished, the brief moment of vulnerability buried beneath the carefully crafted mask she wore so well.

Â 

It was practiced. It was effortless.

Â 

It reminded Agatha of Rio.

Â

Â 

â€œSage,â€ Agatha said with a defeated sigh. â€œWalk away. Now.â€

Â

Â 

Agatha watched her go, listened to the heavy slam of it behind her, then exhaled slowly through her nose.

Â 

Rio leaned back in the chair, blew out air through her teeth. She tilted her head toward Agatha, voice deceptively casual.

Â 

â€œWell. That could have gone better.â€

Â

Â

Â 

Great. Classic Rio deflection. A distraction, carefully wrapped and handed to Agatha like a peace offering, meant to make everything feel a little less suffocating. And right now, Agatha didnâ€™t hate the idea of taking it.

Â 

Agatha let out a long groan before dropping back onto the couch, â€œWell, get on with it.â€

Â 

For a little while, they forgot. Agatha laughed. Rio did too. The sounds were real, even if the silence of the empty space in the room still was unmistakably loud. It didn't go away. It didnâ€™t lessen.

Â 

But for now, they let themselves pretend.

Day 20:

Â 

Another night passed, dragging behind it the remnants of another day that had chipped away at what little patience Agatha had left. Rio lay beside her, flat on her back, unmoving, staring at the ceiling as if she could will herself into another reality. Rio didnâ€™t sigh, didnâ€™t fidget, didnâ€™t even shift, but Agatha could tell. Â 

Then, so softly it almost slipped past Agatha, Rio spoke.

Â 

â€œWhen we were on ourâ€¦ two century break,â€ Rio mumbled, each word slow, pulling them from somewhere distant. â€œThe worst part was thinking I was forgetting the sound of your voice. Wishing, desperately, to hear it again, even if it was cruel.â€

Â 

Agatha said nothing. The words pressed against her heart, tightening around something she had, until now, thought was impenetrable.

Â 

Rio continued, â€œI would have done anything just to have you be angry at me. To my face. Just to hear you say something, because even that was better than silence. Â 

Rio took another breath, deeper this time. Then, after a long stretch of silence, she admitted, â€œBut if this is anything like what that would have beenâ€¦ Iâ€™d like to think I wouldnâ€™t have begged a god I know isnâ€™t real for it.â€

Â 

Rio had never believed in gods. Agatha knew this. The green witch had no use for them, no illusions about what lay beyond. Rio was Death herself, the final certainty, the one who answered when prayers went unheard.Â 

Â 

And yet, Death had still prayed. Every single day.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s heart didnâ€™t just break- it shattered, splintering apart so violently that she could feel every jagged piece tearing through her. The pain was excruciating, something she was sure that was beyond what the body was meant to endure. It felt like glass grinding into bone. It clawed up her throat, a scream so blood curdling that Agatha had to choke it back before it escaped, had to force herself to stay still when every part of her wanted to collapse beneath the agony of it.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t know what to say. What could she say? That she was sorry? That she had suffered too? That she wished she had done it differently? None of it would have mattered.

Â 

So Agatha reached for her instead, pulling Rio close, pressing a hand into her hair as quiet tears slipped down her wifeâ€™s cheeks.

Â 

And beneath all of it- the sorrow, the regret, the things neither of them could change- Agatha felt something else begin to build.

Â 

A cold, merciless wrath, deeper than anger, sharper than fury. This time, it did not burn, it hollowed. It coiled low in Agathaâ€™s chest, not wild or reckless, but forbearing, twiddling its thumbs, shrewd. This was worse than frustration, worse than grief, worse even than the kind of rage that lashed out blindly.

Â 

Because, at this point, Sage wasnâ€™t just punishing Rio. She was taking a blade to an already open wound, carving into a past that had long since scarred over, rewriting it in real time with her own hands. She was forcing Rio to live it all over again, but this time, Agatha was here to see every second of it unfold. And what had once been regret, once been longing, once been pain, twisted into something far uglier.

Â 

Agatha released a breath, but the feeling didnâ€™t pass. It stayed, tightening its grip, feeding on the knowledge that this seemed like something she couldnâ€™t fix with silence or feigned ignorance.

Â

Â 

There would be nothing left standing in its wake.

Â 

Day 23:

Â 

Very little in this world truly scared Agatha Harkness. She could count on one hand the things that had ever managed it.

Â 

And yet, this. This state of the realm, the hushed and slow moving ruin creeping through it, unnerved Agatha in a way she couldnâ€™t ignore. It was more than the physical decay, more than the way the air itself that was starting to stink. It was what this place had become, it reflected what it was doing to the two most important women in her life. The two who had settled the hunger and chaos- the insatiable Agatha Harkness, the grieving mother, the vengeful ex-wife, the scorned daughter of an abusive mother. The two who had given her something that no amount of knowledge, no branch of science or psychology, no so called professional could have ever provided. Stability. Purpose. A reason to stay.

Â 

And now, Agatha was watching the very foundations of that stability collapse. The very foundations of herself. Her wife and her daughter. Crumbling before her eyes. Losing the parts of themselves that was only made possible by the other.

Â 

This made the list. The short, exclusive list of things that scared Agatha Harkness absolutely shitless.

Â 

But it had. From the very moment she opened her eyes this morning, the fear had already settled in.

Â 

Agatha had felt the familiar tap against her ribs, that voiceless invitation from chaos, always lurking, always ready to swallow Agathaâ€™s fear whole and turn it into pure devastation. Chaos was hungry. It was always hungry. It could make things feel smaller, easier to manage, easier to bear.

Â 

Fuck chaos. Agatha would let it starve.

Â 

Even if it meant sitting in this fear, letting it press against her lungs, letting it take up space she had wanted so desperately to clear.

Â 

-

Â 

Â 

Neither Agatha nor Rio saw Sage for days. The sun still rose, bright and unbothered, stretching across an empty sky. But there was something artificial about it, something that felt just a shade off. If Agatha looked too long, she could swear the light carried the faintest green hue, a subtle stain over everything it touched. It bled into the walls, settled over the furniture, crept through the air like an infection. Even inside, the world seemed slightly wrong, like it had been painted over with colors that did not quite belong.

Â 

Agatha could smell it too. Faint, but growing. Something sour, something rancid. It wove itself into the air, threading beneath it was something festering, like fruit left too long on the branch, its sweetness turned sickly as it decayed from the inside out.

Â 

Agatha was beginning to worry about her wife. Three weeks had passed since Sage set herself on this warpath, dismantling Rio with surgical precision. Each day, Sage found new ways to pull her mother apart, to sever her at the seams. And Agatha could see the toll it was taking. Rioâ€™s face had thinned, her cheeks beginning to hollow. Dark circles gathered beneath her eyes, her hair falling longer, darker, untouched by the sun even though it constantly gleamed brightly. Rio was beginning to look like Death after a job well done.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t like it one fucking bit.

Â 

Agatha remembered the way Rio had once described it- imposter syndrome. The way she had struggled to separate herself from her title, to remember that she was more than what Death demanded of her. That she was still Rio, still a green witch, still a mother, still a wife. Still a person with the right to have thoughts and feelings beyond the role she had been given. But Lady Death didnâ€™t come with room for humanity. Eternity threatened to swallow everything she was until there was nothing left but the burden of what she was meant to be.

Â 

Rio seemed to be forgetting where she belonged in all of this.

Â 

And Agatha, for one, couldnâ€™t stomach it anymore. She was sick and fucking tired of watching her wife serve as their daughterâ€™s personal punching bag. Sick of Sage waiting for Rio to break when it was never going to happen. Sick of Rio sitting there, taking it, because she believed she had to. Because proving she could endure it, proving she could take whatever Sage threw at her, was the only response she seemed willing to give.

Â 

Agatha turned away from the back patio, leaving behind the garden where her wife had buried herself in quiet labor.

Â 

This wasnâ€™t her Rio in the garden, though. Not the one Agatha knew. Rio was steady, a force that endured, that weathered, that refused to be swept away. She could be soft, could be kind, but she was never helpless. She gave, but never without reason, never to those who only sought to take. And yet here she was, pouring herself into the earth as if she could plant something inside of it to make up for what was being stripped from her. As if keeping her hands in the dirt could keep her from slipping away entirely.

Â 

Agatha knew where Sage was. The girl had been in the front yard all morning, stretched out in the grass, unmoving, as if she had nothing better to do than exist in their periphery. Agatha had seen her there the moment she and Rio had stepped out of the bedroom, lingering.

Â 

And for the first time in weeks, Agatha was done letting it fester.

Â 

Agatha walked straight up to Sage, her shadow falling over her daughter's face. Sageâ€™s eyes fluttered open at the sudden darkness, but there was nothing behind them. Those green eyes, once alight with mischief and boundless excitement, always carrying the glimmer of a thought just waiting to be spoken, were empty. Agatha had never seen anything like it before. It was unfamiliar. Jarring.

Â 

They didnâ€™t even look green anymore. In the dim light, they seemed washed out, as if something had drained the color from them, leaving only a dull, lifeless gray.

Â 

Without a word, Agatha lowered herself onto the grass beside her daughter. The ground was cold beneath her palms. She tried not to let it scare her. She couldnâ€™t let it swallow her whole, so she redirected. Focused only on Sageâ€™s shit behavior that Rio and Agatha had been subjected to for the last three weeks.

Â 

So Agatha let the silence settle between herself and her daughter, stretching long enough that it could be mistaken for peace. She gave them both that moment, a single breath of stillness, before she politely tore Sage apart.

Â 

Agatha tipped her head back, eyes tracing the sky like maybe it could ground her. She hardly felt the warmth of the it against her skin. It only reminded her how much time she had wasted beneath different skies, always moving, always running, always convincing herself that she could outrun what was inevitable.

Â 

â€œYou know,â€ Agatha mumbled, almost to herself, â€œI wasted three hundred years running from her. Hiding from her. To lose time on such a massive scale and have nothing to show for it?â€ She turned her head to look down at Sage.

Â 

Sage had no reaction, not even bothering to open her eyes after they had fallen shut when Agatha sat beside her.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s fingers dug into the grass, grounding herself against the slow frustration curling in her chest.

Â 

â€œWell, I do. And Rio certainly does,â€ Agatha said, she was barely holding back the anger simmering beneath it. â€œAnd here you are, playing the stupidest fucking game in the history of ever. For what? To help?â€ Agathaâ€™s words came out dripping in sarcasm, the mockery as much for herself as it was for her daughter. â€œBecause this? This isnâ€™t helping.. Actually, itâ€™s making everything so much worse. Youâ€™re wasting time we donâ€™t have, pushing her, pushing me, forcing something that will never happen.â€ The anger built in her voice, but Agatha wasnâ€™t shouting. â€œNot only that, you are acting like the biggest asshole on the planet while youâ€™re doing it.â€ Agatha was almost impressed by how neutral she sounded, considering how fucking furious she is.

Â 

â€œI get it. You had a plan. A big, brilliant plan where we could all live happily ever after and play make believe. Whatever. You canâ€™t beat a dead horse and drag it to water, expecting it to drink. And you sure as hell canâ€™t torture your mother into changing her mind. Thatâ€™s not how this works."

Â 

Still nothing from Sage. No scoff. No eye roll. No biting remark telling Agatha to shut up and mind her own business. Just silence.

Â 

Agatha stole a glance at her daughter.

Â 

Sageâ€™s now dull gray eyes stared unblinking at the sky, narrowed like she was trying to will the sun to burn hotter, to swallow the faint green haze clinging to the air. But magic wouldnâ€™t fix this. Power couldnâ€™t rebuild what Sage had destroyed on purpose. The rage that made her feel invincible, that made her believe she could control the outcome of this mess, had crumbled in the face of time. Three weeks was nothing compared to Agathaâ€™s record of three centuries.

Â 

For all the ways Sage had tried to wield power like a weapon, she had never truly been raised for it. Rio had given Sage everything- every ounce of love, every sliver of warmth, every lesson wrapped in patience and care. Her wife had cradled their girl in gentleness, even when the world wasnâ€™t gentle.

Â 

It was easy to mistake Death for a cold, unfeeling force- something that only took, that had no capacity for love. A cosmic inevitability, an entity as indifferent as the void itself. Something to be feared, whispered about in cautionary tales, the kind that made children hide under their covers and sent grown men to their knees in prayer.

Â 

What a fucking joke.

Â 

Death was soft in ways she had no business being, fragile in ways that made Agathaâ€™s chest ache, a bleeding heart in a role that was never meant to have one. And for all her power, for all the things she was capable of, Rio had never been ruthless. Never been cruel. Never sought dominion over anything. She wasnâ€™t made for war, and she sure as hell hadnâ€™t raised their daughter to be.

Â 

And now, watching Sage falter beneath the pressure of her own performance, Agatha felt an overwhelming amount of relief settle in her chest. Because for all the mistakes Sage had made, for all the damage she had done, Rioâ€™s nature -achingly kind, stubbornly human in all the ways that mattered- had kept their daughter from being consumed by it.

Â 

Agatha had to look away from Sage. Her heart, now nothing more than useless mush, felt too easily swayed, too detached against the way Sage's face tightened, her jaw clenching like it was the only thing holding her together. Her daughterâ€™s eyes fluttered closed as she took a long, slow breath, like she was fighting to protect herself, grasping for the mask she so desperately needed to keep from feeling any of it.

Â 

â€œWhat youâ€™re doing is killing her, Sage.â€ Agathaâ€™s voice was softer now, gentler. She wasnâ€™t speaking in a literal sense, but it was killing Rio all the same, stripping away pieces of her humanity, making her question if any of this had ever been real. Or if this was some cruel punishment thrust upon Death by Fate, a reckoning for the sin of caring too much.

Â 

â€œAnd itâ€™s killing me,â€ Agatha admitted, even quieter now. â€œI canâ€™t sit here and watch her lose herself and be okay with it. And you, of all people, shouldnâ€™t be either.

Â 

Agatha brought herself to look at Sage again. Her eyes were still closed, her face red and splotchy around her eyes and the corners of her top lip. Her brows were furrowed, and her teeth were digging into her bottom lip so hard it had split.

Â 

â€œSage.â€ Agatha said gently, trying to get her daughter to look at her. Sage only squeezed her eyes tighter.

Â 

It reminded Agatha of Rio, and seeing so much of her wife in their daughter at this moment felt like standing against an advancing navy fleet, outgunned and overpowered, with nowhere to run. Any anger or frustration she had left melted away completely.

Â

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re my daughter, and I love you, Sage,â€ Agatha murmured, her voice steady despite the weight behind it. â€œEven when you act like this. Even when you make it impossible. Â 

â€œAnd I will choose a side.â€

Â 

Her eyes remained on Sageâ€™s, her thumb gliding over the scar with the tenderness of a mother comforting her child, shielding her from a potential blow she could not predict. Agatha hesitated, the next words catching in her throat, â€œBut itâ€™ll only make me the villain in your story, Sage.â€

Â 

Agatha would play, but she wouldnâ€™t play against her wife.

Â 

And if that made her the villain in her daughterâ€™s story, then so be it. She had been feared before. She had been hated, cursed, and called things far worse. And if the cost of protecting Rio was becoming the monster in Sageâ€™s eyes, then it was a price Agatha was willing to pay.

Â 

And of course, Rio would probably try to pull some noble, self sacrificing bullshit. God, Agatha hated those fucking speeches. They were like door to door salesmen- persistent, exhausting, and completely unwelcome.
