It didnâ€™t matter how noble the cause or how tragic the discount- she wasnâ€™t fucking buying. She had slammed that door centuries ago.

Â 

Agatha had expected anger from her daughter. She had braced for disappointment, for pain, for something to break between them that could never be repaired. But Sage only looked at her, her face half buried in the grass, her expression neither wounded nor surprised. She tilted her head up slightly, considering, and then the smallest smirk curled at the corner of her mouth.

Â 

"I told you," Sage said, her voice edged with something almost proud. "I always prefer the villains."

Â 

Agatha should have felt sick at that. It should have been proof of her own failures, of all the ways she had just ruined her daughter. But it wasnâ€™t. It wasnâ€™t mockery or resentment or some bitter acceptance of the mother Sage had been given. It was just the truth. A fact that had never needed to be spoken because Sage had never expected anything else.

Â 

Sage had always known the history that dripped from Agathaâ€™s name, had understood the blood she carried on her hands. And it had never changed anything. She had never asked Agatha to atone for it, had never flinched away from the person she was, had never wished for a version of her that was easier to love.

Â 

She had always known Agatha had the potential to hurt her, had always known there was a world in which she might not be chosen, and she had loved her anyway. Fully, without fear, without limits.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t unconditional love. It was knowing exactly what Agatha was capable of and never once looking away.Â 

Â 

Just like Rio.

Â 

Sage lay back in the grass, gray eyes on the sky, picking at the skin around her nails like she couldnâ€™t stop. The gray had settled like a fog, and Agatha couldnâ€™t tell where her daughter had gone inside of it.

Â

Â

Â 

Sage stilled, her fingers finally going still against her skin. She looked at Agatha, just for a second, her gray eyes as dull and distant as they had been for weeks.

Â 

But something shifted. Not enough to name. Not enough to see if you werenâ€™t looking for it.

Â

Â 

â€œWhen did you stop fighting for her?â€ Agatha asks.Â 

Â 

From the moment she met Sage, that was all the girl had done. Every word, every plan, every impossible idea had been for them. For Rio. Â

Â 

â€œI am fighting for her,â€ Sage said, though it sounded thinner than it should have, more like a reminder than a fact. â€œThatâ€™s what all of this is.â€ She gave a lazy wave of her hand, a vague gesture toward everything, as if the mess sheâ€™d made was supposed to explain itself. Â 

And maybe Sage had believed that once. But Agatha wasnâ€™t sure she believed it anymore.

Â

Â 

â€œYou canâ€™t call it mercy if sheâ€™s the one paying for it,â€ Agatha said, and it almost hurt to say the truth out loud.

Â 

Sage glanced at Agatha briefly, her eyes hard, but she didnâ€™t say anything. Her focus quickly shifted back to her fingers, picking relentlessly at her cuticles.

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t help but watch the way Sageâ€™s hands trembled as they dug into the already raw skin. The nails pressed deeper, pulling at the torn edges repeatedly, as if that was the only thing Sage could control anymore.

Â 

The shaking didnâ€™t stop. It only grew worse, the tremors turning from nervous fidgeting into frantic, desperate picking.

Â

Â 

Sageâ€™s breath hitched in, sharp and tight. She was holding herself back, trying to breathe through it, but the tension was so thick that Agatha could see it clearly- Sage was suffocating under the weight of everything she was trying not to feel.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™ve been holding your breath for so long,â€ Agatha couldnâ€™t hide the sadness in her voice, the heaviness in the words.

Â 

Sage inhaled sharply, a raw, wet gasp that seemed to tear through her from the inside. Agatha watched, helpless, as the breath seemed to shatter something in her daughter. Â 

â€œFuck!â€ The cry came out with a guttural rasp, cracking in the air, the sound of a dam finally collapsing under its own pressure. Â 

Agatha could feel it, too- the way Sage was breaking apart and there was nothing she could do to stop it. Agatha couldnâ€™t reach out, couldnâ€™t offer comfort. Â 

Agatha turned away, unable to look at the devastation in her daughterâ€™s eyes, the rawness of the pain cutting deeper than any words could say. The sound of Sageâ€™s wail echoed through her, and Agatha flinched at the ache it caused.

Â 

Then, it began to rain- not the heavy deluge, but a steady, unrelenting fall. Agatha tilted her head up, allowing the cold drops to touch her skin, letting the skyâ€™s sorrow mingle with her own. The rain tasted of loss, of mourning, of the grief that came from loving Death, knowing that Death was eternal while they would eventually fade. That was the way of things. She and Sage would end, but Death would always remain. And that was the most tragic truth neither of them could bear.

Â 

Agatha understood then why her daughterâ€™s eyes had changed, why the vibrant green had faded into gray. It had settled in her eyes instead, silent but inescapable, a storm caged behind glass.

Â 

Sage had pulled everything into herself, and the sky had reflected the loss. Her emotions had never known privacy; they had always lived in the open, stitched into the wind, painted across the clouds, carried in every shift of the air. The sun had burned with her joy, the storms had raged with her anger, the rain had wept with her sorrow. She had never been able to hide from it, had never needed to- until then.

Â 

If she let her emotions reach the sky, if she let them shape the air the way they always had, then Rio would have seen the truth. She would have seen that Sage wasnâ€™t just playing a game, wasnâ€™t just pushing her away out of cruelty. She would have seen that every word, every action, every calculated wound had been cutting into Sage just as deeply.

Â 

And Sage couldnâ€™t let her know that.

Â 

So she had buried it, forced it down, pulled it inside herself where no one could reach. The sky had been her greatest betrayer, so she had silenced it, left it empty, stripped it of the emotions it had always carried for her. It was the only way she could keep up the lie that none of this hurt. That she wasnâ€™t breaking too.

Â 

But the sky had never been meant to keep Sage's secrets.

Â 

It had resented the silence, the emptiness Sage had forced upon it. The air had been rancid, thick with something stagnant and wrong. The sun had shined, but it had carried no warmth. The faint green hue had bled into everything it touched, an unnatural stain in a world that had always breathed with her. The atmosphere had once been an extension of her, a reflection of everything she had felt, and now she had abandoned it. She had taken everything and left it hollow.

Â 

The sky had been hers, and it had been grieving.

Â 

The hue had faded, and the air felt unburdened. The sky had finally released what it had carried in silence.

Â

Â 

Day 24:

Â 

Rio felt her daughterâ€™s tug deep in her heart, as if Sageâ€™s hand was physically reaching inside, pulling at her most tender strings. Â 

Rio stepped into the corridor, surrounded by the darkness of the aquarium after hours. Dim overhead lights cast a soft glow on the towering kelp forest exhibit, where strands of kelp swayed gently in the manufactured currents. The exhibit, designed to replicate the natural kelp forests of the ocean, was serene and mysterious in the quiet night. Fish of various sizes darted between the kelp fronds, their movements swift and silent, adding life to the shadowy green columns.Â 

Â 

The kelp forest exhibit had been the first place Sage set foot on the surface. Back then, Sage couldnâ€™t get enough of the ocean. She found ways to tie it to everything, like if she could understand the sea, she might make sense of the rest of her life too. Rio hadnâ€™t argued. They both needed the distraction. Â

Â 

Rio thought it would be awkward, watching her daughter take those first steps into a world sheâ€™d never been allowed to touch. Â 

Rio spotted Sage sitting on a bench in the middle of the exhibit. She walked over and sat down, leaving a careful gap between them. Unsure if too close would be pushing it. Unsure if anything would.

Â

Â

Â 

Sage closed the distance, scooting in against Rioâ€™s side like sheâ€™d done a thousand times before. Â

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re real chatty tonight,â€ Sage said quietly.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Once, a long time ago, she wouldâ€™ve given anything to be part of the cycle sheâ€™d spent forever watching. She wanted to live and die like everything else did. Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œIâ€™ve learned to live with it, Sage,â€ Rio said, her voice low. She meant it. It wasnâ€™t some bitter admission. It was the truth. Living with it was all she had left. Â

Â 

When Sage looked over at Rio, there wasnâ€™t just frustration behind her eyes. The words werenâ€™t just thrown out in passing. It was a deliberate dig, meant to hit exactly where it did.

Â 

Rio, of all people, worshipper of the cycle, keeper of the balance. Always the first to talk about the way things were meant to end. And here she was, still sitting at the center of it all, hoarding the one thing that was never supposed to last.

Â

â€œI canâ€™t outrun you forever,â€ Sage said. The words werenâ€™t loud, but they didnâ€™t need to be. They cut clean, like theyâ€™d been waiting on her tongue for years.

Â 

Rio felt it everywhere. In her chest. In her stomach. Somewhere deep behind her ribs, where sheâ€™d already been bruised heavily by this same thought more times than she could count.

Â

Â

Â 

Rio reached out without thinking, brushing her thumbs across Sageâ€™s cheeks like she had when she was little. Back when there were problems Rio could actually fix, hurts she could take away.Â 

Â

Â

â€œYouâ€™re going to forget,â€ Sage whispered. â€œYou already have. Whoever you had before us... whatever family you loved before Agatha, before Nicky.. Before me... theyâ€™re gone. You donâ€™t even remember them anymore.â€

Â 

And the worst part was, Sage was rightâ€¦ again.

Â 

Rio felt it sometimes, just out of reach. A name she couldnâ€™t hold onto. A laugh she thought she once knew. The shape of someoneâ€™s face in a dream that disappeared as soon as she opened her eyes. And whatever pieces of them were left, Rio had already lost.

â€œI donâ€™t want that for you,â€ Sage said. â€œI donâ€™t want you to forget. I donâ€™t want you to be the only one left. We wonâ€™t forget you. I wonâ€™t. And thinking about you staying here, after all of us are gone, carrying this alone... it makes me sick.â€

Â 

Rio listened. Really listened. She heard every word, felt every bit of it lodge deeper than she cared to admit.

Â

Â 

This was hers to carry.

Â

Â 

Rio kept her eyes on the glass, watching the fish weave through the kelp, giving herself a minute before she spoke. It felt too big to rush.

â€œYou know,â€ she said quietly, â€œI still remember the first time you cried. Really cried. Not because you were hungry or tired, but because you knew something hurt. Â 

Rio shook her head and gave a small, humorless laugh.

Â 

â€œAnd I thought that was the worst of it. That moment. That tiny little heartbreak. I didnâ€™t know how much bigger the hurt could get. How much worse it would feel to watch you grow up and keep hurting anyway. And Iâ€™ve spent every day since trying to figure out how to keep the sharpest parts away from you. Even knowing I can't.â€

Â 

She paused and looked at Sage, making sure she was really listening.

Â 

â€œAnd now youâ€™re sitting here worried about me,â€ Rio said. â€œWorried about what itâ€™s going to do to me when you're gone. Like youâ€™re some burden Iâ€™m going to have to carry.â€

Â 

She leaned in slightly, her voice dropping low.

Â 

â€œBut Petal, thatâ€™s never what this was. Youâ€™re not something Iâ€™m stuck with. Youâ€™re the reason any of this means anything at all. And yeah, Iâ€™ll still be here when itâ€™s over. Thatâ€™s how this works. But donâ€™t you dare think that means Iâ€™m left with nothing. Youâ€™ve already given me everything worth holding onto. And I donâ€™t care how much time passes. That doesnâ€™t leave me. You donâ€™t leave me. Youâ€™re part of me now. In ways nothing can wear down, not even this.â€

Â 

Rio sat back, looking up at the shifting lights above them.

Â 

â€œSo no, I donâ€™t want to trade places. I donâ€™t want out. I want to be here. I want to see it all. The whole mess of it. Every version of you. Every day youâ€™re here. Itâ€™s not some tragedy for me, getting to watch the people I love live their lives. Itâ€™s the whole reason I stay. I stay so you donâ€™t have to. Thatâ€™s my job. Thatâ€™s always been my job.â€

Â 

Rio let the words hang there, not needing to push them any further.

Â 

For once, Sage didnâ€™t argue.

Â 

-

Â 

By the time they made it home, the sun was climbing, casting soft golden light across the garden. The air was fresh, still damp from the night, like the whole world had taken a deep breath. Agatha sat on the patio with a cup of coffee, watching them move through the morning like it was any other day, like it had always been this easy.

Â 

Sage was already out in the dirt, wearing green coveralls with VIDAL stitched across the front, one of Rioâ€™s old sets sheâ€™d stolen years ago and refused to give back. It was practically falling off her shoulders, her boots caked in mud, hair a mess, a streak of soil across her cheek like a badge of honor.

Â 

Rio was crouched a few feet away, weeding near the pond, and Agatha could hear the sigh from across the garden before Rio even spoke.

Â 

â€œIâ€™m serious, Petal. The koi are too fat.â€

Â 

Sage looked up like Rio had just personally insulted her entire bloodline.

Â 

â€œExcuse me? Donâ€™t say that about them! Theyâ€™re perfect.â€

Â 

Rio snorted. â€œPerfectly fat.â€

Â 

â€œTheyâ€™re robust.â€

Â 

â€œThey are the size of toddlers.â€

Â 

Sage dropped her clippers into the dirt, â€œMaybe theyâ€™re bulking. Maybe they have goals.â€

Â 

Rio pointed accusingly toward the water, â€œYouâ€™ve been sneaking them extra food. Donâ€™t lie to me.â€

Â 

â€œI havenâ€™t!â€ Sage said, absolutely lying. â€œTheyâ€™re just... thriving under my care.â€

Â 

Rio sat back on her heels, wiping sweat from her forehead. â€œThriving? Sage, one of them got stuck under a lily pad yesterday. Had to reverse out like a car in a tight parking lot.â€

Â 

â€œThey have big personalities. And you know what? I hope they get bigger.â€

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re trying to kill them with kindness.â€

Â 

â€œBetter than starving them with your negativity.â€

Â 

Agatha couldnâ€™t hold back the laugh this time, sipping her coffee as the two of them kept going, voices overlapping with nonsense and love and something that finally felt light.

Â 

And for the first time in longer than she could remember, Agatha let herself believe it was real.

Â 

They were home. They were whole. And they were going to be just fine.

Â 

-

Â 

For as long as there have been endings, there has been Rio Vidal. Before the first tide reached the shore, before the mountains settled into their shapes, before the sky remembered its name, she was already waiting. It is by her hands that the last light is dimmed. It is by her will that the door is closed. She is not a story told by those who fear the dark. She is the dark itself, patient and certain, carrying the quiet knowledge that all things end, and all things return.

Â 

Empires crumble. Rivers dry. Names are forgotten. Time leans forward and takes what it is owed. Through all of it, Rio endures.

Â 

And yet, endurance has never been the same as immunity.

Â 

There are roots older than the earth that grip without mercy. There are bonds formed so completely they leave no part untouched. Love, in its oldest form, does not ask permission before it takes hold. It does not concern itself with what should or should not bend. Even the endless must answer to what has been woven into their keeping. There is no logic to it. No rule written to account for the weight of love pressed into the spaces meant to hold only silence.

Â 

It is easy to believe that Death does not yield. Easier still to believe she was never meant to. But there are quiet shifts, small and certain, that begin long before they are noticed.

Â 

And already, beneath the surface, something has started to give.

Â

anyway the song Sage referenced in this is Eastwick by Julia Jacklin it's fucking amazing give it a listen

thank you again for the kindness i literally love writing every second of this story and every kudos, like, whatever else... it's all so special

hesitation

Chapter Notes

the dress rio wears in this chapter is the pink dress aubrey wore in what, i believe, was the last episode of white lotus.. if that, you know, helps with the visuals :)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Sage Vidal had known Agatha Harkness her whole life, or at least as much as anyone could know a mother theyâ€™d never met. Rio made sure of that. The good. The bad. The brilliant, impossible parts that made people stay, and the jagged, selfish parts that made them leave. By the time Sage was old enough to understand what had been taken from her, it didnâ€™t feel like absence. It felt like theft.

Â 

Sage wanted the life she shouldâ€™ve had- the one where Agatha wasnâ€™t just a story passed down in pieces, where her mothers weren't locked in some endless, miserable stalemate, ruining each other from opposite sides of the same grief. She wanted something simpler. A life where knowing Agatha wasnâ€™t a fight, where love wasnâ€™t something both of her mothers seemed determined to lose on principle.

Â 

It was clear Rio wasnâ€™t going to do a fucking thing about it.

Â 

Not when her mother spent her days circling the same loss, carrying around heartbreak like it was part of her uniform. There were centuries of it built up by now, packed into every wordless nook, every unfinished thought, every time she let Agathaâ€™s name sit in the back of her throat like it hurt too much to say. Sage watched her wander through the same pain over and over, like there was still something noble about staying broken. Like if Rio kept bleeding long enough, maybe her wife would come back - just to shut up whatever was still wailing for Agatha Harkness.

Â 

And for what?

Â 

For a woman whoâ€™d found the most dramatic way out imaginable, only to cheat the ending. Agatha couldnâ€™t outrun Death, so she created a loophole. Died on purpose, then hung around anyway, floating just out of reach, haunting the surface. Spending her time with Billy fucking Maximoff, of all people, following him around like some ghostly shadow, as if the whole thing wasnâ€™t batshit insane.

Â 

And maybe Sage had never really known Agatha. Not the way she wanted to. Not the way she should have. But that didnâ€™t change the fact that she loved her anyway. How could she not? She was her mother. That was supposed to mean something. And still, Agatha had left her with nothing but stories and silence, then had the nerve to spend whatever was left of herself playing the sidekick of another womanâ€™s son.

Â 

And Rio just let it happen.Â 

Â 

She sat in the middle of her own suffering and called it peace. Pretended it was enough to mourn someone who hadn't actually left. Kept the grief alive like it was the only part of Agatha she still knew how to hold.

Â 

And honestly? Sage was tired of it.

Â 

Agatha wasnâ€™t coming back to quiet the wailing. She wasnâ€™t the one trying to stop the bleeding. That was Sage. She was the one kneeling over the mess, hands pressed to the wound, trying to stitch her mother back together before she lost her for good.

Â 

No one else was willing to put their hands on it. No one else had the stomach to press down and keep the bleeding from getting worse, to hold the wound together long enough for something to heal. Someone had to keep her mother from tearing in half, and it sure as hell wasnâ€™t going to be the one who sliced her open.

Â 

The sky had been holding the weight of it for weeks. Heavy. Unmoving. Like it was just as fed up as she was, waiting for someone to finally do something about the mess none of them seemed brave enough to touch. And every time Sage looked up, it was staring right back, daring her to stop pretending this was anyone elseâ€™s job.

Â 

She wiped her hands on her pants and looked up to the sky that had turned her every private feeling into a forecast, like it was still owed an explanation for all the trouble she made it carry.

Â 

â€œDonâ€™t worry,â€ Sage muttered. â€œIâ€™ll clean it up.â€

Â 

-

Â 

A year wasnâ€™t much. Not against the centuries theyâ€™d already lost to anger and grief. Just a handful of seasons passing, one folding into the next before any of them thought to hold on tighter. But it was enough to get a taste. Enough to feel what it was like to stay, to want, to wonder what might come next.

Â 

And that was the danger of it- how easily it made you greedy. One spring turned into summer. One summer into fall. And before long, Agatha found herself craving more. More mornings. More arguments that didnâ€™t end in someone leaving. More afternoons spent remembering how to live without waking up bracing for the worst. Without clawing for more power, more chaos just to keep herself upright. For once, she wasnâ€™t trying to outrun the end.

Â 

A year wasnâ€™t much. But it was enough to make Agatha want the next one. And the one after that. And every single one they could steal while they still had the chance.

Â 

-

Â 

Winter:

Â 

Agatha had always hated winter.

Â 

Hated the silence of it. Hated the way everything slowed down and shrank back and died off like that was just the natural order of things. Like surrendering was noble. Like decay was something to be endured politely.

Â 

It made everything harder. The cold. The dark. The endless waiting for something better to come along that never did. Back then, winter wasnâ€™t peaceful. It was just another thing to carry. One more season to survive. Another excuse to remind her how much lighter the world felt when you had less to lose.

Â 

The invention of central heating and air had been the only real improvement. A modern mercy. But even that wasnâ€™t enough to make Agatha like the season.

Â 

The only thing enjoyable about winter was the part where everything green finally gave up. The plants, the vines, the creeping, stubborn things that always fought too hard to hold on.

Â 

And maybe that wasnâ€™t just about the plants.

Â 

-

Â 

If winter werenâ€™t already miserable on its own, there was Christmas. Agatha loathed Christmas. The noise, the clutter, the forced cheerfulness of it all. An entire holiday built around pretending the darkest part of the year was worth celebrating. It was exhausting.

Â 

And, of course, Sage loved it.

Â 

â€œYou hate Christmas?â€ Sage asked incredulously.

Â 

Agatha shrugged, tugging the blanket tighter around her shoulders. â€œItâ€™s colder than a witchâ€™s tit in a brass bra. Donâ€™t you control the weather? Make it warm.â€

Â 

â€œBrass bra, you say?â€ Rio piped up from the armchair, wiggling her eyebrows like it was the highlight of her day.

Â 

Sage whipped around, stared at Rio, and slowly lifted a finger. â€œThatâ€™s fucking disgusting,â€ she said, drawing out each word.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s a valid visual.â€

Â 

She turned right back to Agatha like Rio didnâ€™t exist. â€œAnd thatâ€™s not how it works,â€ waving Agathaâ€™s request off without a second thought. â€œHow can you hate Christmas?â€

Â 

Agatha sighed, wrapped the blanket tighter around herself, and gave Sage a look like sheâ€™d just asked why water was wet. â€œBecause itâ€™s awful,â€ she said flatly. The answer felt so obvious she couldnâ€™t imagine why they were still talking.

Â 

â€œThatâ€™s not an answer.â€

Â 

â€œItâ€™s the only one youâ€™re getting.â€

Â 

Sage squinted at her, looking her up and down like she was assessing the situation, or worse, calculating. Then she leaned back into the couch, arms crossed over her chest, and said, â€œOkay,â€ with the kind of confidence that made Agatha immediately regret every choice that led to this conversation.

Â 

Oh no. No, no, no, no, no.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t have to ask what came next. She already knew. Nothing good ever came out of Sageâ€™s scheming. The girl had a long, painful history of turning mild inconveniences into full scale productions, and Agatha had no doubt she was about to become an unwilling participant of whatever terrible idea had just taken shape.

Â 

Well. That wasnâ€™t entirely true. There had been one exception. Sageâ€™s scheming had, on one occasion, managed to accomplish something worthwhile, and Agatha supposed being dragged to this realm was technically a point in her favor. But even that was debatable on certain days, and today was quickly becoming one of them.

Â 

Agatha pulled the blanket tighter around her shoulders, tucking it under her chin hoping the extra layer might somehow shield her from whatever holiday nightmare Sage was quietly constructing.

Â 

-

Â 

Agatha was trapped in the kind of nightmare that left emotional scars. Somewhere, in the middle of a blizzard that smelled suspiciously like peppermint, she was being chased through an endless maze of tinsel by a choir of carolers wearing matching reindeer sweaters. No matter how fast she walked, they followed- smiling. Waving. Harmonizing. And from above, blaring through invisible speakers mounted in the sky itself, was the worst song mankind had ever produced.

Â 

â€œLast Christmasâ€ by Wham!

Â 

On repeat.

Â 

Indefinitely.

Â 

By the third loop, she was sprinting. By the fifth, she was begging for death. By the seventh, Rio appeared out of nowhere, tossing fake snow into the air and mouthing the lyrics directly at her like this was some kind of flash mob.

Â 

Agatha startled awake with a gasp, heart racing, blanket tangled around her ankles. For a few brief, glorious seconds, she thought it was over.

Â 

But it wasnâ€™t.

Â 

The song was still playing.

Â 

Faint at first, but definitely real. Definitely happening. And growing louder by the second, until there was no denying it was blasting from the living room like Sage had hired a DJ and decided to throw a holiday rave.

Â 

Agatha whipped her head to the left, ready to bark at Rio to go shut it off, but the bed was empty.

Â 

Agatha threw the blanket off, stomped to the door, and yanked it open- only to find Rio standing right there, frozen mid step in the hallway.

Â 

Rio wasnâ€™t even pretending to notice the music rattling the walls. No, Rio was simply standing there, entirely deadpan, dragging a full sized Christmas tree behind her like it was the most reasonable thing in the world.

Â 

Agatha blinked once. Then twice.

Â 

She actually considered slamming the door closed and going back to sleep, in the hope that reality would sort itself out without her involvement.

Â 

Instead, she pointed at the tree. â€œWhat. Is that.â€

Â 

Rio glanced back over her shoulder, utterly unbothered. â€œSage made me do it.â€

Â 

And as â€œLast Christmasâ€ hit its chorus for what had to be the twelfth time, Agatha came to the deeply unsettling conclusion that she might still be dreaming.

Â 

Except this time, she wasnâ€™t sure she'd ever wake up.

Â 

-

Â 

â€œNo! Itâ€™s crooked!â€ Sage yelled, pointing toward the roof like Rio had committed an unforgivable crime.

Â 

Agatha stood beside her, freezing, regretting that she had come outside at all. Sage hadnâ€™t stopped shouting directions since Rio climbed up there, and Agatha was starting to lose feeling in her fingers.

Â 

Rio shifted the section of lights without complaint. This was the sixth adjustment Sage had demanded, and somehow Rio still looked perfectly calm. If anything, she looked focused, like Sageâ€™s opinion was the only one that mattered.

Â 

â€œJesus Christ,â€ Agatha mumbled.

Â 

Sage glanced over at her, grinning. â€œThatâ€™s the spirit.â€

Â 

Agatha pulled the blanket tighter around her shoulders. â€œI hope the roof collapses.â€

Â 

Sage pointed back up without missing a beat. â€œTell her the left side still looks weird.â€

Â 

Begrudgingly, Agatha did.

Â 

-

Â 

Agatha had barely stepped into the bedroom when Rio shot up from the end of the bed, holding a hand out like she was stopping traffic.

Â 

â€œStop!â€

Â 

Agatha startled, â€œWhat? What? Whatâ€™s on me?â€

Â 

Rio only pointed above her head, wearing that smug grin that always makes Agatha immediately suspicious.

Â 

She frowned, glancing up. And there it was. Hanging in all its ridiculous glory.Â 

Â 

A mistletoe.

Â 

Agatha hated Christmas. She hated the decorations. She hated the nonstop music Sage refused to turn down.Â  But she didnâ€™t hate Rio when she got like this. All pleased with herself, looking like sheâ€™d just pulled off the worldâ€™s greatest romantic ambush. Maybe, against her better judgment, the smallest smile found its way to Agathaâ€™s lips.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s a parasite, you know,â€ Agatha said, still staring up at it. â€œYouâ€™d think that would go against your whole thing. Donâ€™t you speak for the trees?â€

Â 

Rio was already sliding off the bed, grin growing wider as she made her way over. â€œGod, thatâ€™s sexy. Tell me more plant facts.â€ Her arm slipped around Agathaâ€™s waist like it belonged there.

Â 

Agatha kissed her.

Â 

When she pulled back, she gave Rio a narrow look. â€œYou love it just as much as she does, donâ€™t you?â€

Â 

Not once during this entire miserable holiday had Rio looked half as irritated as Agatha felt. She hadnâ€™t complained once. She hadnâ€™t rolled her eyes or muttered under her breath. If anything, she seemed like she was barely holding back from joining Sage in making it worse.

Â 

Rio shrugged, â€œI love it because she does. And watching someone else suffer through it with me is kind of nice.â€

Â 

Agatha scoffed, but it didnâ€™t stop her from kissing Rio again.

Â 

-

Â 

Today was the dreaded day. Sageâ€™s second favorite holiday, right behind the ever glorious Groundhog Day. Almost as ridiculous as Rioâ€™s favorite, which, somehow, was Arbor Dayâ€¦ Arbor Day. Agatha was married to the fucking Lorax, she was convinced.

Â 

But that was beside the point.

Â 

What really mattered was the discovery sheâ€™d made about Sageâ€™s obsession with Groundhog Day. It wasnâ€™t about the groundhog itself- no, that would have been almost tolerable. Sage loved it specifically because it was, as she put it, â€™the dumbest, most pointless thing the United States had ever collectively agreed to take seriously, and no one questions it.â€™

Â 

And she didnâ€™t just make fun of it in passing. According to Rio, Sage treated it like an annual event. She had charts. She had commentary. She set alarms. She followed the groundhog's career like it was a competitive sport.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s hilarious, actually,â€ Rio said, laughing. â€œShe makes me sit with her every year to watch the results like itâ€™s an election. Then spends the whole day making passive aggressive remarks about how weâ€™ve built an entire system of seasonal weather predictions on the instincts of a large rodent and humanity has clearly reached its peak.â€

Â 

Agatha, upon learning all this, had immediately made a mental note to ruin Sageâ€™s life by believing in the groundhog completely. Fully, unironically, deeply invested.

Â 

Six more weeks of winter? Say no more. She would nod gravely and take to the couch like a grieving widow. Early spring? Sheâ€™d congratulate the groundhog on his hard work and faithfulness to his craft.

Â 

And she wouldnâ€™t break. Not once.

Â 

But that was for February.

Â 

For now, it was Christmas fucking day.

Â 

And that was worse.

Â 

The house was already decked out in its ridiculous holiday best. Every surface was covered in garland. Candles flickered in the windows. The stockings were stuffed and crooked, which Rio kept adjusting like the world would end if they werenâ€™t perfectly lined up. The tree had been finished for days, an over decorated monstrosity in the corner, twinkling like it had something to prove.

Â 

By the time Agatha made it to the kitchen, Sage was already narrating the day like some over caffeinated cruise director. There was an itinerary. Breakfast first. Gifts after. Then a movie Sage claimed was a mandatory viewing, insisting that Home Alone was â€œa profound meditation on self reliance.â€

Â 

Rio, the traitor that she was, had the nerve to nod along like this made any sense.

Â 

Agatha stayed wrapped in her blanket, parked in the corner of the couch, and sighed through most of it. She made snide remarks about Sageâ€™s breakfast spread, complained that the hot chocolate was too sweet, rolled her eyes every time someone used the phrase â€œholiday spirit.â€ But no one paid her any mind.

Â 

And somehow, that was fine.

Â 

Because even with the awful music and Sage insisting they all wear matching pajamas for â€œthe aesthetic,â€ Agatha couldnâ€™t bring herself to leave. Maybe it was Rio, pressed up against her side, stealing sips from her cup. Maybe it was Sage, sitting forward on the couch, reciting half the movieâ€™s lines from memory while making deeply serious observations about home security. Maybe it was the way neither of them seemed to care that Agatha had grumbled through the whole morning.

Â 

They just let her complain.

Â 

And she did. But she also stayed exactly where she was, warm under her blanket, watching the two of them laugh over some ridiculous scene theyâ€™d already seen a hundred times.

Â 

Later, when Sage finally passed out on the floor, surrounded by torn wrapping paper and half a dozen empty mugs, Agatha leaned over to Rio and whispered, â€œYour daughter is out of control.â€

Â 

But Agatha didnâ€™t move. Not even when Rio laughed, and not even when Sage, half asleep, muttered that she loved them both.

Â 

She stayed right where she was, pulled the blanket higher, and decided it was only mildly concerning how she would absolutely sit through another one of these holidays.

Â 

-

Â 

It was January, and the house was quiet. The only sounds were the ticking of the clock and the soft clink of chess pieces against the wooden board. Agatha was focused, eyes narrowed as she considered her next move, while Sage sat across from her, slouched in her chair, idly spinning a captured pawn between her fingers.

Â 

Sage had been rambling for a while now. Agatha had tuned most of it out, letting the words fade into background noise while she debated the best way to trap Sageâ€™s king. It wasnâ€™t until she slid her rook forward that she caught the tail end of what Sage had just said.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s fingers stilled against the rook. Her head lifted, eyes narrowing as the words she had almost ignored registered.

Â 

"Wait- " She blinked. "Slow down. You hacked S.W.O.R.D.?"

Â 

Sage met her gaze, unimpressed. "Uhh, yeah?" Her eyes flickered to the side and back, like she couldn't believe Agatha thought this was worth questioning, as if hacking a government agency was just a normal Tuesday activity.



Agatha leaned back in her chair and exhaled slowly, pinching the bridge of her nose, already regretting her own question. "And why, pray tell, would you do that?"



Sage shrugged, tossing one of her knights into the air. â€œGot bored one day. Saw they were investigating some â€˜Westview Anomalyâ€™ and poked around. Turns out they picked up a broadcast signal and started recording it.â€ She caught the knight with ease, then swung it down, knocking Agathaâ€™s rook off the board like it was an afterthought. â€œYou were funny.â€ She planted the piece in its place with a decisive thunk.



Agatha wasnâ€™t looking at the game anymore.Â 



Sage kept fucking talking.

Â 

â€œHooked it up to the TV. We watched every single episode.â€ Her daughter paused, then corrected herself. â€œWell, I did. She couldnâ€™t see you, you know, because of the whole Darkhold situation.â€

Â 

Sageâ€™s hand lifted as she leaned forward, shielding the side of her mouth as if conspiring against someone unseen. With her other hand, she pointed toward the study, where Rio was no doubt deep in another internet rabbit hole, obsessively researching whatever absurd question had hijacked her thoughts that day.

Â 

Lowering her voice to a whisper, Sage added, â€œBut donâ€™t worry, I never told her you were flirting with Wanda.â€ She dropped her hands and leaned back, expression blank for a beat before she raised a brow. â€œWhich, by the way, was fucked up. Not that I was exactly subtle. Iâ€™m pretty sure she figured it out just by the shade of green I turned every time you did.â€ To drive the point home, she jabbed a finger in front of her open mouth and made a mock gag, the mere thought of it was enough to make her sick.

Â 

Sage was saying too many words, doing too many ridiculous -if admittedly funny- things. Agatha couldn't process it all. The only thing that cut through the noise was the sudden flare of anger she felt. Her fingers pressed against the edge of the kitchen chair she currently occupied, grip tightening as she forced her voice to stay even.

Â 

"You both knew I was in Westview?" The words left her through clenched teeth, her patience hanging by a thread.

Â 

â€œWait,â€ Sage frowned, her brows pulling together. â€œYou didnâ€™t know?â€

Â 

Agathaâ€™s hands gripped the table as she leaned forward, â€œNo, I didnâ€™t fucking know.â€ The words came out fast, mocking her daughterâ€™s innocent question. Her gaze flicked toward the study where her wife was, then snapped right back to the pain in her ass.

Â 

Sage stared at Agatha, mouth slightly open, eyes wide with something that looked suspiciously like excitement at seeing her mother get worked up. â€œOkay, you canâ€™t seriously be mad about this,â€ she said, amusement and sincerity mixing in her voice. â€œYou were hidden by the Darkhold. She couldnâ€™t do anything about that, and I was stuck here. Itâ€™s not like she just left you to fend for yourself.â€

Â 

"WHAT- " Agatha caught herself. She needed to calm down. Her hand pressed against her chest as she took a quick, determined breath, then she slapped it down on the table. "What the fuck does that mean?"

Â 

It wasnâ€™t any less aggressive, but it was quieter, and for now, Agatha considered that a win.

Â 

â€œHerb and Sharon- â€

Â 

â€œWho the fuck is Sharon?â€

Â 

Sage looked at Agatha like she had just said something profoundly stupid. "Mrs. Hart..." Sage let the name hang, lifting a brow. Her gaze lingered on Agatha, expectant, waiting for the realization to finally click.

Â 

Agatha blinked at Sage, the name meaning nothing to her at firstâ€¦ then it clicked. Â 

Â 

Ahhh.. Mrs. Hart. Right. Right.

Â 

She pressed a hand to her chest, inhaling a long, theatrical breath. "Of course, yes..." She made the sign of the cross, "R.I.P. Mrs. Hart." A belated show of respect for the woman she had only just remembered existed.

Â 

Sage stared at her, a mix of mild horror and confusion settling on her face. Her eyes flicked to the side, then back to Agatha, trying to decide whether to question it or just let it go.

Â 

"Umâ€¦ okay," her daughter said slowly, clearly deciding to move past whatever that was. "Mom brought you groceries every day."

Â 

Agathaâ€™s blood went cold.

Â 

"She had the neighbors deliver them. Made sure Herb or Sharon" -and there was no missing the pointed emphasis on the name- "got them to you."

Â 

Every day.

Â 

The spell had trapped her in that house, her body moving, her mind slipping between realities she had no control over. One day she was a detective solving a case. Most days she was just Agnes, the nosy neighbor with a coffee cup in hand and nothing better to do than post about suspicious activity on neighborhood watch forums. Some days she was nothing at all.

Â 

But Rio had been there.

Â 

Every day.

Â 

Agatha tried to speak, tried to say something, anything, but her voice didnâ€™t come.

Â 

She didnâ€™t move.

Â 

Didnâ€™t blink.

Â 

Didnâ€™t breathe.

Â 

-

Â 

Sage had left her to deal with it on her own. That was fine. Agatha preferred it that way.

Â

Summer:

Â 

Agatha had always hated summer.

Â 

Spring was relentless, but summer was smothering. It took. It swallowed everything whole, draping itself over the world with an insufferable heat, with air too thick to breathe, with skies so bright it left nowhere to hide.

Â 

There was no silence in summer, no reprieve, no space left untouched. It was inescapable, lingering on skin, clinging to breath, pressing in from all sides. It stretched the days too long, made the nights too short, left no corner of the world untouched by its presence.

Â

Â 

Agatha folded her arms, watching them, but her mind kept drifting.

Â

Â 

Agatha never brought it up again. She didnâ€™t want to. There was nothing left to question. Rio sure as shit hadnâ€™t either, and life had settled into its usual shape. Â 

For now, that was enough.Â 

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

This was fine.

Â

Â 

Hope.

Â

Rio exhaled, gaze flickering downward for a moment, but Agatha could tell her wife was listening.

Â 

â€œSage isnâ€™t going to let this go,â€ Agatha pressed. â€œIf you donâ€™t intend to do anything about it, then I suggest you stop now before she gets the wrong idea.â€

Â 

Agatha was very much speaking for herself too.

Â 

Agatha tilted her head slightly, studying Rioâ€™s face before adding, â€œBecause youâ€™re going to give her hope. And we both know thatâ€™s not fair.â€

Â 

It was advice because whether Rio realized it or not, Sage was watching. And when their daughter finally decided she wanted answers, she wasnâ€™t going to be gentle about getting them.

Â 

And when Rio looked back up at her, Agatha watched as the mask slipped back on effortlessly- the same one Rio had always worn. The one that pissed Agatha off to no end. It was smooth, practiced, impenetrable, the kind of armor that came from an eternity of knowing how to hide and pull herself together even when she was breaking apart.

Â 

Rio only held Agatha's gaze, her thoughts locked behind that familiar wall of logic and restraint.

Â 

Then, with a small nod, Rio turned and walked out of the study, leaving Agatha alone with everything that had just been said.

Â 

-

Â 

They hadnâ€™t talked about it again.

Â 

In fact, they both acted as if the conversation had never happened at all. There were no lingering glances, no unfinished sentences waiting to be spoken, no tension pressing at their interactions. It wasnâ€™t forced, not really. It was justâ€¦ understood.

Â 

Everything went back to normal. Life carried on.

Â 

Rio still called Sage to the garden each morning. Agatha still pretended not to notice. Sage hadnâ€™t brought it up again, though Agatha could see the wheels turning in their daughterâ€™s head, the way she lingered a little too long sometimes, like she was waiting for someone to slip. But neither of them did.

Â 

There were mornings with coffee, conversations that held no weight, Rioâ€™s familiar presence at her side. And though there was still something unspoken beneath it all, neither of them reached for it. They didnâ€™t want to.

Â 

Because this -this ease, this understanding, this space where they could simply exist together- was enough. Maybe not forever. Maybe not even for long.

Â 

But for now, it was.

Â 

And right now, Agatha couldnâ€™t think of anything except the way Rioâ€™s tongue was in her mouth, stealing the breath from her lungs.

Â 

It had started simply enough- Rioâ€™s hand resting on her thigh, light and absentminded. Innocent. Or at least, it had seemed that way at first. But then her fingers had started tracing slow, infuriating patterns against her skin, creeping higher with each pass. Agatha had let it happen, let Rio push the boundaries, let herself enjoy the anticipation curling low in her stomach. Her breath had turned uneven, betraying her far too quickly.

Â 

She turned her head, one brow arched in question, but Rio was already watching her, eyes dark, pupils blown, lips parted like she had been waiting for Agatha to finally look at her.

Â 

And those lipsâ€¦

Â 

Well, they had been begging to be kissed.

Â 

The next thing she knew, they were tangled together on the couch, making out like a couple of horny teenagers, all frantic hands and desperate mouths. It was rushed and messy, and they were trying to be quiet but failingâ€¦ Spectacularly, at that.

Â 

And, shockingly, it was Rioâ€™s fault.

Â 

Whatever door Agatha had unlocked that Spring day hadnâ€™t just opened- it had flown off its fucking hinges. Death had once been a quiet lover, always swallowing her sounds, keeping her pleasure locked behind clenched teeth and controlled breaths. Only ever giving Agatha small glimpses at the sounds Rio was capable of making.

Â 

But not anymore.

Â 

Rio was loud.

Â 

She gasped against Agathaâ€™s lips, moaned when their bodies shifted, let out these broken, desperate sounds that she wasnâ€™t even trying to contain. She whined when Agatha pulled away, whimpered when Agatha kissed her again, sighing like she had spent lifetimes holding back, only to finally let go, and God, was her wife making up for lost time.

Â 

Agatha, for one, sure as fuck was not complaining.

Â 

Agatha pulled back just enough to catch her breath, lips tingling, pulse pounding in her ears. â€œYou suck at being quiet,â€ she muttered, voice slightly ragged.

Â 

Rio, utterly unapologetic, let out a breathless laugh. â€œI wasnâ€™t trying to be quiet.â€

Â 

Agatha rolled her eyes, but any exasperation she might have felt was completely undercut by the way Rio was already chasing after her mouth again, hands still gripping at her like she had no plans to let go anytime soon.

Â 

â€œYou used to be,â€ Agatha pointed out, arching a brow.

Â 

Rio hummed, pressing an open mouthed kiss to her throat. â€œI used to be a lot of things.â€

Â 

Agatha let out a breath, gripping Rioâ€™s chin and tilting her head back. â€œOh? And what exactly are you now?â€

Â 

Rio grinned, eyes dark with want. â€œDown bad for my very hot wife.â€

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t even have time to draw breath for a response before a blood curdling scream tore through the house, it echoed down from their daughterâ€™s bedroom upstairs.

Â 

Instinct took over. Whatever tension had been in the room vanished in an instant as both of them scrambled into motion. Agatha nearly tripped over the edge of the couch in her haste, Rio vaulting over it with the kind of reckless urgency that left no room for grace. They collided with furniture, knocked over a lamp- neither stopping to see where it landed.

Â 

By the time they reached the stairs, they were a tangle of limbs, jostling and pushing past each other in their desperate climb. Rio was faster. She always was. She reached Sageâ€™s door first and didnâ€™t hesitate, slamming through it with enough force to send it flying open, nearly off its hinges. Agatha was right behind her but didnâ€™t have time to stop, crashing straight into Rioâ€™s back with a startled grunt.

Â 

None of it was graceful. It was messy, frantic, driven by nothing but sheer, unfiltered panic. And beyond the wreckage of their entrance, Sageâ€™s scream still lingered in the air.

Â 

Then-Â 

Â 

â€œYOU WHORE!â€

Â 

The betrayal in Sageâ€™s voice was staggering, a bolt of lighting struck, shaking the entire house.

Â 

Agatha barely had time to process the words before her eyes found Sage, kneeling in front of Brucieâ€™s enclosure. Her hands were braced against the glass, fingers digging in like she needed something to hold on to. Her shoulders shook, her breath came in gasps, but she didnâ€™t move. Didnâ€™t turn. Didnâ€™t acknowledge them.

Â 

There was no blood. No intruder. No sign of danger. Nothing that warranted a scream like that.

Â 

Rio, still braced, ready to fight something, was the first to break the silence. She exhaled, the adrenaline crashing just as fast as it had spiked. Then, voice hesitant, like she wasnâ€™t sure she wanted the answer, she asked, â€œSageâ€¦ why are you calling the snake a whore?â€

Â 

Sageâ€™s head snapped toward them so fast it was a miracle she didnâ€™t hurt herself. Her eyes burned with an unadulterated fury, her chest still heaving as she fought to catch her breath.

Â 

â€œTake a look for yourselves!â€ she snarled, pushing herself up from the floor in one violent motion.

Â 

Before either of them could react, she turned back to Brucieâ€™s enclosure, hands clenched into trembling fists at her sides. â€œI canâ€™t even look at you!â€ she yelled.

Â 

And then, as if the very act of acknowledging Brucie was too much to bear, she spun on her heel and threw herself face first against the nearest wall. Arms splayed wide, forehead pressed dramatically against the wall.

Â 

Agatha and Rio just stared at their daughter, utterly bewildered.

Â 

The room was thick with silence, broken only by Sageâ€™s ragged breathing as she remained plastered against the wall, arms stretched out like she was waiting to be crucified.

Â 

Agathaâ€™s heart was still racing from the panic that had sent them barreling up the stairs, but now, faced with this, she could feel the first tendrils of a headache creeping in. She flicked a glance at Rio, expecting (hoping) for some kind of reaction, but Rio looked just as lost, her eyes darting between Sage and Brucieâ€™s enclosure as if staring hard enough would make things make sense.

Â 

Seconds stretched. No one moved. No one spoke.

Â 

"Would you like to go first?" Agatha asked, jutting her chin toward the snakeâ€™s enclosure.

Â 

Rio was still staring at it, eyes wide, looking very much like she wanted to be anywhere else.

Â 

â€œNope. Iâ€™m good.â€ She tore her gaze away just long enough to glance at Agatha. â€œLadies first.â€

Â 

Agatha scoffed, rolling her eyes. â€œCoward,â€ she mumbled, but even so, she hesitated before moving.

Â 

Sage still hadnâ€™t turned around, still hadnâ€™t so much as twitched, which only made Agatha warier.

Â 

With deliberate slowness, she inched her way toward Brucieâ€™s enclosure. The closer she got, the more she could feel Rio at her back, hovering. She didnâ€™t even have to turn around to confirm it- Rioâ€™s fingers had already latched onto the back of her shirt, gripping it like a lifeline as she followed.

Â

Â 

â€œIâ€™m providing emotional support,â€ Rio whispered, which was a bold way to describe hiding behind her wife.

Â 

Ignoring her, Agatha took another cautious step forward, steeling herself for whatever horror Sage had witnessed.

Â 

Agatha took a steadying breath and peered into the enclosure.

Â 

The moment she did, Sage whipped herself around, arms crossed, a fist pressed against her mouth, worry written all over her face. Agatha could feel Rio peeking over her shoulder, practically breathing down her neck.

Â 

And there it was.

Â 

Brucie, coiled tight, her neon green scales gleaming under the soft enclosure light- wrapped protectively around eggs.

Â 

Lots of fucking eggs.

Â 

Agatha blinked. Her mouth opened, closed, then finally managed to breathe out, "Oh my god."

Â 

â€œNO!â€ Rio yelled.

Â 

Sage snapped her head between them, desperate, waiting for them to provide some grand wisdom beyond the sheer shock that was currently seeping out of both of them.

Â 

Brucie remained coiled around her absurd, absolutely unholy amount of eggs, acting like nothing at all was amiss.

Â 

â€œHow many are there?â€ Agatha asked, eyes never leaving Sageâ€™s familiar.

Â 

â€œThirty,â€ Sage deadpanned beside her.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t even get the chance to react before Rio gasped behind them, voice trembling with horror. â€œThirty more Brucies?â€ her wife whispered, like the words alone might kill her. She staggered back a step, then another, visibly paling. â€œI think Iâ€™m gonna be sick.â€

Â 

Then there was a thud.

Â 

Agatha whipped around just in time to see Rio sprawled out on the floor, completely unconscious.

Â 

She stared. For a long time.

Â 

Death herself, literal Death, had just fainted at the idea of too many snakes.

Â 

Then slowly Agatha turned her head back to Sage, who (despite the absurdity of what had just happened) looked far more concerned about her own predicament.

Â 

â€œI mean, Iâ€™m too young to be a grandmother, right?â€ Sage asked, wide eyed, wanting Agatha to offer her some kind of comfort.

Â 

Agatha turned fully, irritation surely written all over her face. Between Rioâ€™s absolute disgrace of a reaction and Sageâ€™s impending existential crisis, she was fast approaching the limits of what she was willing to deal with today.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re nearly three hundred years old,â€ Agatha shot back.

Â 

Sage visibly recoiled, "Oh my god!â€Â  Her hands flying to the sides of her head in pure horror. â€œAnd youâ€™re too old to be a great grandmother!â€ She shouted the last part, pointing at Agatha like she had just discovered a crime against nature.

Â 

Agatha gasped, hand flying to her chest. â€œPardon?â€ She barely had time to process her own offense before Sageâ€™s eyes rolled back, her body tilting-Â 

Â 

â€œOh, for the love of- â€ Agatha lunged forward, but Sage collapsed like a sack of bricks, slamming into the floor with a dramatic thud.

Â 

For several long seconds, Agatha just stood there, staring at her two unconscious idiots on the floor.

Â 

Then, very slowly, she inhaled, held it, and exhaled.

Â 

"Not the first time Iâ€™ve said it and surely not the lastâ€¦ I shouldâ€™ve stayed fucking dead," Agatha mumbled.

Agatha whipped back to Brucie, bent down, and pointed. â€œAnd Sage is right. You are a whore.â€

Â 

Then she stepped over Rioâ€™s unconscious body, not sparing her so much as a glance, and marched straight out of the bedroom. She slammed the door behind her and for good measure, she bellowed down the hall-

Â 

â€œFucking morons!â€

Â 

-

Â 

Agatha wasnâ€™t so sure she hated summer anymore.

Â 

It still filled every inch of the world, still wrapped itself around everything in its path, but maybe it wasnâ€™t stifling. Maybe it was simply constant, refusing to slip away unnoticed. The heat still settled on her skin, still lingered longer than it should, but she no longer felt the need to fight it.

Â 

The air was still thick, but it carried something more than just the weight of the season. The brightness still left no place to hide, but there was no urge to pull away from it.

Â 

Agatha realized maybe it had never been trying to take anything from her at all. Maybe it had only ever been trying to hold on a little longer, knowing it would have to leave when its time was up, knowing it could never stay, but still lingering, burning itself into the world so it wouldnâ€™t be forgotten.

Fall:

Â 

Agatha hated fall.

Â 

It was a season of retreat. The world pulled back, hollowed itself out, and made everything smaller. The days shrank, the light faded earlier, and the air turned brittle. It was a season of endings, of quiet resignations, of knowing what was coming and having no power to stop it.

Â 

People spoke of change as though it was something beautiful, but Agatha had never found much comfort in the slow unraveling of things. Fall was not the fire of summer or the bloom of spring. It did not take boldly or give recklessly. It simply withered. It let go, piece by piece, leaving nothing behind but bare branches and cold wind.

Â 

There was nothing dramatic about fall. No fight, no lingering presence, no last desperate attempt to hold on. It was a season that knew how to leave.

Â 

-

Â 

Rio had gotten an early start in the garden that morning, already hard at work by the time Agatha stepped outside with her coffee. She took to her usual spot on the patio, stretching out in the cool morning air, the warmth of her mug pressing against her palms. Rio hadnâ€™t looked up, too focused on whatever task had her attention.

Â 

The morning carried that sharp bite of fall, crisp enough to make her consider grabbing a blanket but not quite enough to push her inside. It was the kind of quiet Agatha enjoyed. It wasnâ€™t heavy or stifling, just a pause before the day really began. She sipped her coffee, glancing toward the house. It wouldnâ€™t be long before Sage appeared, half dressed and mid thought, ready to disrupt the morning with whatever had taken root in her mind overnight.

Â 

Agatha smirked. The peace wouldnâ€™t last, but she didnâ€™t mind.

Â 

As if summoned by the thought alone, the back door swung open with the kind of force only Sage could manage.Â  Agatha looked up, expecting her usual whirlwind entrance, but instead, Sage stumbled out looking like she had barely survived the night.

Â 

Her coveralls were on in the loosest sense of the word. One strap hung unbuckled, the fabric bunched awkwardly over a black hoodie that looked like it had been slept in. Her hair was pulled into what might've once been a ponytail, but at some point had clearly lost its structural integrity. One pant leg was shoved into her sock while the other dragged, and she carried her boots in one hand like just the thought of putting them on was simply too much.

Â 

Mumbling to herself, she stomped across the patio and threw herself into a chair and chunked her boots at the ground with the kind of theatrical misery that wouldâ€™ve made a poet proud.

Â 

Agatha sipped her coffee, unimpressed, watching as Sage groaned, shifted, flailed an arm over her face, groaned again, and then sighed so loudly it could have been mistaken for a death rattle.

Â 

â€œRough morning?â€ Agatha finally asked, not out of concern, but because her daughterâ€™s performance demanded acknowledgment.

Â 

Sage shot Agatha a glare before flopping back into the chair with another groan. She wiggled around trying to physically escape the exhaustion clinging to her, kicked one leg out, then suddenly shot up again, gripping the armrests with both hands.

Â 

â€œIâ€™m tired,â€ she groaned, dragging the last word out so long it might never end. She shook the chair in frustration, then let out another dramatic sigh and collapsed forward, burying her face in her arms on the table.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t blink. â€œYouâ€™re very brave,â€ she said dryly.

Â 

From the depths of her folded arms, Sage let out another long, drawn out groan, muffled but still dripping with misery.

Â 

â€œYou donâ€™t get it,â€ she mumbled. â€œIâ€™m, like, universally tired. Cosmic level exhaustion. My bones are asleep. My soul is limping.â€ She pushed herself up and clambered onto the table. She stretched out across it, sprawled flat like a Victorian woman on her deathbed, limbs hanging dramatically over the sides.

Â 

Agatha took another sip of coffee, â€œSounds serious. Maybe you should lie down,â€ she said, nodding toward the table Sage was already sprawled across.

Â 

Sage lifted her head just enough to squint at her, â€œI am lying down.â€ She groaned again, flopping one arm out like she was reaching for salvation. â€œTell Mom I fought courageously,â€ she murmured, her voice growing weaker. â€œAnd that I-â€ She let out a dramatic sigh and went limp, playing dead.

Â 

Agatha stared at her, then reached out and flicked her forehead.

Â

Â 

Agatha only shrugged, â€œYou can go back to bed, you know.â€

Â 

â€œYoU cAn Go BaCk To BeD, YoU kNoW,â€ Sage mimicked in a mocking, nasally voice

Â 

Agatha cracked a smile at the ridiculousness of it.

Â 

Still sprawled across the table, Sage suddenly clambered up onto her knees, her movements clumsy. â€œYou donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve tried that?â€ she hissed, eyes wild with the desperation of a woman pushed to her limits.

Â 

Before Agatha could react, Sage lunged forward, grabbing fistfuls of her shirt and yanking her closer.

Â 

â€œShe is killing me!â€ Sage hissed, jerking her head toward the garden, where Rio was hunched over, humming to herself as she plucked dead leaves off a plant. â€œCalling me out here every morning at the ass crack of dawn! Â

Â

Â

Â 

Fuck.

Â

â€œI donâ€™t know shit,â€ Agatha snapped.

Â

Â 

It was exactly something Rio would do. And that only pissed Agatha off more.

Â 

She had told Rio to cut it out. If she didnâ€™t want Sage asking questions no one could answer -or ones Rio refused to- then she needed to stop handing their daughter the ammunition. Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha needed to accept that it would never happen, she had to make peace with the fact that this was the life they had. But some days, it was impossible to ignore. Some days, it pressed down on her so hard she felt like she might suffocate under it.

Â 

And on those days, she wanted desperately, violently, to talk about it. To say it out loud. To ask someone if there was a way. And because she was Agatha, because her mind never let things rest, she had even considered bringing it up to Sage.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

"Would you stop looking at me? It's pissing me off," Agatha snapped.

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t even blink. If anything, she looked more interested, a bloodhound catching the scent of something worth chasing. Her fingers drummed against the table, her gaze narrowing in a way that made Agathaâ€™s skin itch.

Â 

Sage leaned back in her chair, arms crossing over her chest, tongue pressing into her cheek again as she flicked a glance toward the garden. She squinted at Rio, eyes narrowing.

Â 

Then, with an exaggerated sigh, she looked back at Agatha. â€œYou know what? Why donâ€™t I just go ask her myself? Get my answer straight from the source, huh?â€ Sage pushed up from her chair.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t think. Her body moved before her mind caught up, her hand shooting out to grip Sageâ€™s wrist, fingers tightening instinctively. â€œDonâ€™t.â€ The panic in her own voice was obvious.

Â 

Sage stilled. Her gaze dropped to Agathaâ€™s hand, then back to her face, eyebrows raising.

Â 

Agatha could feel the way Sage was already turning it over in her head, analyzing, digging, getting ready to pounce. Irritation burned hot in her chest, rising fast, because it was too early for this. Too early for Sageâ€™s mind games, too early for Rioâ€™s mess, too early for the thoughts she had been forcing herself not to think about for months. Agathaâ€™s grip tightened, her teeth clenched, and she forced the words out, â€œSit. Down. Now.â€

Â 

Sage didnâ€™t hesitate. She dropped right back into her chair, grin stretching wide across her face. â€œTouched a nerve, did I?â€ she mused, voice syrupy sweet.

Â 

Agatha let go of her wrist and picked up her coffee instead, taking a sip, hoping it might drown out the overwhelming urge to strangle her own child.

Â 

She set her coffee down, very slowly, careful not to slam it onto the table and risk shattering it. She closed her eyes, inhaled deeply, and tried (tried) to gather the last scraps of her patience. Then she looked at Sage.

Â 

And immediately closed her eyes again.

Â 

The urge to strangle her had not passed. If anything, it had gotten worse.

Â 

She took another breath, peeked one eye open, and found Sage sitting perfectly still, hands folded, expression neutral. Too neutral.

Â 

Her daughterâ€™s face had settled into something almost saintly, like she had reached an enlightened state of patience. Which only meant one thing- she knew she was being obnoxious, knew she had pushed too far, and was now waiting. Not out of remorse, but because she understood, in her own infuriating way, that Agatha needed a moment to process the absolute audacity of her existence.

Â 

â€œI donâ€™t know why sheâ€™s been calling you out to the garden. Iâ€™m being honest about that.â€

Â 

Sage mustâ€™ve heard the truth in Agathaâ€™s voice, because her face softened right away. Her shoulders eased, and her gaze flicked to Rio for a moment before settling on Agatha again.

Â 

â€œIâ€™m sorry,â€ Sage said quietly. â€œI justâ€¦ I feel like Iâ€™m missing something. Like you both know something I donâ€™t, and itâ€™s driving me crazy. My mind wonâ€™t let it go and Iâ€™m justâ€¦ Iâ€™m sorry. We donâ€™t have to talk about it.â€

Â 

Agatha wanted to bang her head against the table. She understood Sage, maybe more than she wanted to. The girl was hers and Rioâ€™s, through and through. Both of them were the kind of people who could feel when something was being kept from them, and neither ever let it go. It wasnâ€™t about trust- it was instinct. A refusal to sit still when answers were missing.

Â 

So yeah, Sage was prying. She was playing games, pushing buttons to get a reaction. But Agatha couldnâ€™t entirely blame her. That itch for the truth ran deep. And unfortunately, it was inherited.

Â 

That honestly made it worse because now it wasnâ€™t just Agatha pacing in circles. Sage was too.Â 

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t even have any real answers. All she knew was that Rio had been off. Her wife had been acting weird in a way that wasnâ€™t just mood or timing, but like something had broken open in her. Sheâ€™d said things Agatha never thought sheâ€™d hear. Admitted things Agatha thought were impossible. The kind of impossible that sat right next to hell freezing over.

Â 

It was eating at Agatha.

Â 

Not knowing what it meant. Not knowing what to do with it. Like a piece of glass buried deep beneath her skin, impossible to ignore, and she couldnâ€™t tell if pulling it out would bring relief or leave everyone bleeding.

Â 

Agatha already felt like she was bleeding herself dry. And Sage seemed like she wasnâ€™t far behind.

Â 

She wasnâ€™t about to spell out everything Rio had said or done, but she could nudge Sageâ€™s suspicions in the right direction. â€œYou said it yourself. Sheâ€™s been acting strange.â€ She shrugged, trying to sound casual, though it didnâ€™t quite land.

Â 

Agatha saw the tension behind Sageâ€™s eyes, the way she was holding her tongue, clearly resisting the urge to press until the full truth was dragged out of her mother.

Chapter Notes

if this is where you're starting, go back a chapter. i updated twice today.

now, i'm gonna hold your hand while you read this and we're gonna say it together, "this fic will have a happy ending and i will not freak out"

She collapsed onto the couch, limbs sprawled, her heart still caught somewhere in the threshold where Rio had stood. It felt like waiting for someone to return from war. Rioâ€™s hair was still damp, and even through the wet strands, Agatha could see it had already started to change. The black was fading, softening at her roots, and it was shorter now than when she arrived. Her cheeks looked a little fuller. The dark circles beneath her eyes had vanished.

Â 

It always struck Agatha how easily Rio slipped into the shape of Life here. In this place where Death had once given to Life, and Life had given something back. The exchange lingered in the walls, in the air. It was quiet, sacred, and impossible to explain.

Â 

It was breathtaking.

Â 

Rio walked toward the couch, and Agatha sat up to make room for her. Before she sat, Rio held something out- a worn leather bound journal. It wasnâ€™t Sageâ€™s. That one was too new, too modern. This one was different. Older.

Â 

Agatha took it without hesitation. â€œWhatâ€™s this?â€ she asked, her fingers already brushing the worn cover.

Â 

Rio sank down beside her, leaving almost no space between them.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s a journal Iâ€™ve kept. For after you and Sageâ€¦â€

Â 

Rioâ€™s voice faded. Her eyes shifted away, as if even now, the words were too much. She swallowed, then looked back at Agatha.

Â 

â€œSo you donâ€™t forget?â€ Agatha asked quietly.

Â 

Rio nodded, barely. The smile she gave was small, practiced. It didnâ€™t touch her eyes.

Â 

Agatha looked down at the book.

Â 

It was easier to put the blame on Death, to point at something with a face and a name. But Death does not take. Time does. And Eternity is the hungriest of them all.Â 

Â 

Eternity is patient. It wonâ€™t break Rio all at once. That would be mercy. Instead, it erodes her slowly, taking the best of her in pieces so small she barely notices whatâ€™s gone until itâ€™s too late.

Â 

That was the punishment. Not the burden of Death itself, not the solitude of centuries, not even the endless procession of loss.

Â 

Love was the crime.

Â 

Love was Rioâ€™s defiance and Eternity made sure it became her sentence.

Â 

Every person Rio should hold close would be taken twice- first by death, then by time.

Â 

The journal wasn't sentiment. It was preservation, survival. A desperate attempt to hold onto the parts of herself that time keeps trying to take. A way to carve permanence into a world that promised her none, save for her own existence.

Â 

Agatha opened the journal to the first page.

Â 

Today, I choose a name.

A name that does not belong. A name that does not fit.

Rio Vidal.

Let it be the lie I live inside.

Let it be the closest I ever come to wanting more.

Â 

The next page was a portrait of her own face- drawn with delicate precision. It was from long ago. Centuries. Agatha could tell by the way her eyes were shaped, the way her mouth hadnâ€™t yet learned to hide what she felt. If she had to guess, it was from the day she and Rio first met.

Â 

Beneath the portrait, written in black ink:

Â 

Agatha Harkness - Your wife

Â 

Her birthday. Her birthplace. A brief note in the margin about the color of her magic.

Â 

Purple.

Â 

Agatha glanced at Rio, her brow furrowed. Rio only gave her a soft, silent nod toward the next page.

Â 

She turned the page.

Â

Â 

Nicholas Scratch - Your son

Â 

His portrait showed him as a baby: round cheeks, arms full of softness, and a gummy smile that seemed far too big for his face. His hair was already a mess, wild and charming, and his eyes sparkled with contagious joy. He looked like Rio- so much it ached.

Â 

His date of birth and the day of his death. His birthplace.Â 

Â 

A tiny note in the margin about the day he took his first steps.

Â 

Very wobbly. Legs like a foal, pride like a king. Â 

Â 

Another page.

Â 

Sage Vidal-HarknessÂ  -Â  Your daughter

Â 

The portrait was of her as a baby- small, but with a presence that felt like sheâ€™d already lived a hundred lifetimes. Her expression was calm, serious, but the tiniest hint of a smile curled the corner of her lips, as though she held a secret.

Â 

She was beautiful.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œRio,â€ she said, barely a whisper- half question, half ache.

Â 

Rioâ€™s reply was quiet, careful, â€œKeep going, Agatha.â€

Â 

Agatha did.

1693:

You had learned to live without fire.

At some point, centuries ago, maybe longer, you knew warmth. You do not remember what it was, or who gave it to you. You only remember the echo of it. The way it used to feel. And then, nothing.Â 

You moved through time untouched, untouched by time.

That is who you became.

Until her.

You saw her locked behind glass, staring back at you like sheâ€™d been waiting.

Something in you stuttered. You forgot how to move. For a moment, you forgot yourself.

She was beautiful. Piercing blue eyes, all sharp edges and hunger. The kind of beauty that came with fire beneath it. The kind you wanted to watch just to see what sheâ€™d set ablaze next.

You who have walked beside kings and storms and plagues- You who have been Death longer than all things have had names- Waited at a womanâ€™s window like it was your only job.

And she didn't run.

She leaned into you. Teased you. Dared you to keep looking.

So you did.

That night, when she stood amongst dead bodies, locket swinging between her fingers, she looked at you like she had summoned you. Not by chance. On purpose.

You should have laughed. You should have vanished.

You didnâ€™t.

You let her touch you. You touched her.

You felt a spark in your chest.

Warmth.

And you burned.

Agatha turned through page after page, some filled with portraits of herself looking older, changed by time. Between them were journal entries from years she had always tried not to remember. Years before Nicky. Before Sage. Just the two of them.

1751-1756:

You never believed it could happen.

And yet, she came to you one night with trembling hands and wide eyes and told you she was pregnant.

Your wife, Agatha.

Your son, Nicholas Scratch.

She carried him. Months of aching and nausea and laughter so bright it cracked your ribs from the inside. She glowed. She swore at you constantly. She hated the smell of herbs, cried over bees, demanded soup at midnight and wanted your hands on her belly always.

You loved her more in those months than you had ever loved anything.

The day came. His little heart, once so strong, had started to falter. You had known before she did. You had felt it. And when you told her, she looked at you like you had murdered something in her.

"I told you not to come.â€ â€œPlease, my love.â€ â€œIf you do this,â€ your wife said, voice shaking, â€œI will hate you forever.â€

Six years.

He was beautiful. You loved him.

The night came, his heart stopped.

You took him like a thief in the night and you hated what you had to do.

When you returned to your realm, where all things end, there was not silence.

A baby girl.Â 

She reached for the face of Death and giggled.

Purple and green. Here with a purpose. To save what could be saved. To heal what had been broken.

Sage.

Your wife had locked herself behind the Darkhold, too broken to see. Too far gone to feel the new soul that bloomed in the soil of your world.

You were never meant to create.

But she is yours. And you love her.

And for a moment, you forget what you are. You forget who you are.

1786:

Youâ€™ve tried to find her. She doesnâ€™t want to be found.

Â

Rio stood in front of her, voice unsteady, hands open, eyes locked onto hers like she didnâ€™t trust herself to look anywhere else. Agatha saw it. All of it. Â 

They had both made the same kind of choices. Both justified the damage. Both called it love. And maybe it was. Maybe it still is.

Â 

She wanted to turn away, to pretend she didnâ€™t care. But she couldnâ€™t. She couldnâ€™t lie to herself, not here. Not with Rio still standing in front of her, still asking to be seen.

Â 

Agatha had always seen her.

Â 

Agatha was quiet for a moment.
