Rio was shielding Agatha. Sparing her. Or trying to.

Â 

It was immediate, visceral. Pain ripped through their daughterâ€™s voice, utterly and completely raw, and with each cry came words Agatha never wanted to hear like that again.

Â 

â€œMom- it hurts.â€

Â 

Agatha slammed her hands over her ears. Shut her eyes so tightly they burned. Her whole body locked in place, caught in the impossible war between instinct and understanding. Every part of her wanted to run forward, to pull her daughter away from what hurt.

Â 

She was a mother. She wasnâ€™t built to listen to her daughter suffer and sit still.

Â 

Rio had warned her. That it might hurt. That Agatha might not want to see it. Agatha, too proud for her own good, had scoffed. Said she could handle it.

Â 

Maybe she should have listened to her wife.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s okay, Petal. Iâ€™m here. Youâ€™re not alone.â€ Her wife was holding Sage through it. Bearing the pain alongside her.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t open her eyes until the screaming stopped.

Â 

What she saw made no sense. Not magically. Not emotionally. Not in any way that comforted.

Â 

Sage was floating.

Â 

Not hovering gracefully, not glowing, not bathed in light like a scene from a storybook. Her arms hung slightly out, her fingers loose, her head tipped back, hair cascading in all directions. The air around her shimmered like reality was bending to make room. It was holy, yes. But wrong, too. Too strange to be safe. Sacred in a way Agatha didnâ€™t know how to comprehend. Sacred in the way of doorways, and blood, and things you never get back.

Â 

Rio knelt below her, one hand pressed to the ground, the other hanging at her side, limp. Her face tilted upward, but all Agatha could see was the back of her wifeâ€™s head.

Â 

Agatha had only blinked.

Â 

Rio was gone.

Â 

Where her wife had been kneeling only a second before, there was a grave- fresh and buried beneath an impossible flood of flowers.

Â 

The earth, in recognizing its Original Green Witch was gone, wept in bloom for the hands that had once taught it how to grow.

Â 

Sage was still fucking floating. Still suspended in that terrible grace and then she wasnâ€™t.

Â 

Her daughterâ€™s body dropped.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t gentle. One moment Sage hung in the air like she belonged to something higher, and the next, she was plummeting toward the earth at a speed Agatha couldnâ€™t even process. She shouted her daughterâ€™s name, but the sound barely caught up before Sage hit the ground with an such impact that it shook beneath Agathaâ€™s feet.Â 

Â 

She landed just feet from Rioâ€™s grave.

Â 

For the second time, Agatha looked upon that impossible mound of flowers, and it wasnâ€™t her breath that left her. It was a feeling deep inside her ribcage that wrenched forward like it had recognized what had been taken. Not grief. Not shock. But a pulling. A summoning. Existential and precise, as if someone had placed a hand on her spine and asked her to take one last look.

Â 

And then-

Â 

â€œMama!â€

Â 

His voice struck like lightning.

Â 

Agatha whipped around. â€œNicky!â€ she cried, instinctively.Â  But there was no one there. Just the sound echoing through the air. She turned back, eyes wide, and saw Sage stumbling up from the ground, legs shaking beneath her, tripping as she tried to run. Not away.

Â 

Toward Agatha.

Â 

Fuck .

Â 

Theyâ€™d misunderstood everything.

Â 

It wasnâ€™t her connection to Sage that had kept her here- not the bond, not the unfinished love between mother and daughter. That had been a comfort. A tether, maybe. But not the anchor.

Â 

Agatha felt it now with terrifying clarity, the way her soul rattled inside this temporary body, no longer content to pretend it belonged to the living. It was spiritual.

Â 

It was Rio. It had always been Rio.

Â 

Her unfinished business was Rio fucking Vidal.

Â 

The oblivion hadnâ€™t taken her because it couldnâ€™t. As long as Rio had been trapped in her duty, Agatha had been trapped too.

Â 

It was love so absolute that it rewrote the laws of what was allowed to move on.Â 

Â 

Peace hadnâ€™t been possible.

Â 

Not until now.

Â 

The last thing Agatha saw was Sage barreling toward her, eyes wide with panic, hand outstretched like she could stop it. Like she could reach her mother in time.

Â 

The last thing she heard was her daughter screaming-Â 

Â 

â€œMOM!â€

Â 

And then, like all tragedies written by gods and witnessed by no one, the curtains fell. The lights died.

Â 

The world went dark.

Â 

-

Â 

Sage hit the ground hard for a second time. This time, she rolled, landing on her hands and knees, the breath knocked clean from her lungs. Her fingers dug into the wet grass, frantic, like she could dig her mother out from beneath it if she just tried hard enough.

Â 

The clawing turned to fists. Fury came. She struck the earth with both hands, again and again, until a guttural scream tore free from her throat.

Â 

Thunder cracked. Lightning tore the sky open. And the rain came down in sheets.Â 

Â 

She leaned back on her calves, breath catching in her throat, rain sputtering from her lips with every heavy breath. She stared at the space where her mother had just been standing. Then she turned, squinting through the downpour toward the otherâ€™s grave. The earth had made it special. Final.

Â 

She swallowed hard and looked up at the sky, the only thing left that still knew her name, the only thing still listening.

Â 

â€œIâ€™ll clean it up,â€ Sage said. Her voice broke. â€œI swear Iâ€™ll clean it upâ€¦â€

Â 

She had to. She fucking better.

Â 

Because for the first time in her life, Sage Vidal-Harkness was truly alone. Not lost, not abandoned- just alone. Left in the aftermath of choices she had made, sitting in the center of the storm that her emotions had summoned. This was what she asked for. This was what she built with her own hands. And now, there was no one left to save her from it.

Â 

-

Â 

If Agatha Harkness were still around, she would tell you that she used to hate fall.

Â 

Maybe itâ€™s because she finally learned that fall isnâ€™t about endings. Itâ€™s about returning, like every other fucking season is. About letting go of what canâ€™t be carried into winter. Itâ€™s about the world shedding its leaves so something else can grow.

Â 

Sheâ€™d tell you that fall taught her what she never let herself believe in life- that leaving is not always a failure. That surrender can be sacred. That sometimes the most powerful thing you can do is stop holding on.

Â 

And maybe sheâ€™d laugh and say the season was never the problem.

Â 

Because she would know that fall doesnâ€™t wither to disappear. It withers to make room.

Â 

But if Agatha Harkness were still around to tell you the truth, sheâ€™d admit she doesnâ€™t hate it so much anymore.

Chapter Notes

this is quite a monster of a chapter.. and while you're reading it, remember that there's a happy ending.

important info to know going into this chapter: it's in Rio's pov..

good luck :)

â€œThen plug your ears.â€ Rio mumbles.Â

Â 

Rio purses her lips, lifting just enough to peek over the curve blocking her view.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

â€œI have gone.â€ Rio gritted the words out between breaths, willing the pain to pass. â€œYou were there. They ran every test. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong.â€

Â 

â€œThen find someone who actually knows what the fuck theyâ€™re doing!â€ Agatha snapped, eyes wide and scared.

Â 

The pain eased, but the pull didnâ€™t. It was now a strange, familiar tug in her chest like someone had hooked a thread through her heart and was gently, insistently pulling.

Â 

It had been happening for months. At first it was barely there, just a warm feeling Rio could ignore. But lately it had started to hurt. It felt desperate now. The more she ignored it, the worse it got, pressing harder each time, waiting for her to understand something she didnâ€™t. It never lasted too long, always stopping on its own.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œYeah, no problem! Same time next week?â€ Rio handed off a brown paper bag to one of their regulars.

Â 

The market stretched in a patchwork of color and noise, nestled a few blocks from the sea. Canvas tents flapped in the breeze, their signs hand painted and sun faded. A man down the row shouted about fresh plums; somewhere farther, a guitar strummed a song no one was really listening to. Salt clung to the air. It always did this close to the coast.

Â 

â€œDefinitely,â€ the woman said with a smile. â€œHave a good one, Rio! You too, Agatha!â€

Â

â€œThat ring on your finger invisible or something?â€ Still, Agatha didnâ€™t look up. â€œDoesnâ€™t take a rocket scientist, Rio.â€

Â 

â€œRio!â€ Agathaâ€™s chair scraped back. Her voice was low, teeth clenched, panic tucked beneath every syllable.

Â 

â€œItâ€™s fine,â€ Rio rasped. â€œIâ€™m fine.â€

Â 

Across the aisle, a girl was staring.

Â 

She stood too still for the market. Early twenties, maybe. Something unreadable behind her eyes. Not startled. Not curious. Just... watching.

Â 

Rioâ€™s gaze narrowed, but the pain in her chest flared again, forcing her to turn away.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

â€œNo, sit down. Please.â€ Rioâ€™s voice softened without effort. â€œDonâ€™t push yourself. Iâ€™m fine.â€ That last part was a lie, but it didnâ€™t matter. Agathaâ€™s comfort always came first. She pressed a hand to her wifeâ€™s side, trying to guide her back down into the chair.Â 

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

The girl cleared her throat. "Yeah. You got any sage?"Â 

Â 

She was watching Rio closely, like she expected something to click.

Â 

Rio gave her a puzzled look, then glanced down the booth. The sage was at the far end, past the rosemary and chamomile. Not far, just inconvenient. She looked at Agatha, then back at the sage. The space felt larger than it was. It was barely a few steps, but it felt like a choice.

Â 

When Rio looked again, the girl had her eyebrows raised, waiting.

Â 

Rio was being ridiculous. There was no threat. It was just sage. Just a girl. That was it.Â 

Â 

Rio nodded toward the end of the table and walked over. The girl followed.

Â 

Rio reached for one of the bags, ran her thumb over the label to smooth it down. She adjusted a few others, more to busy her hands than anything else.

Â 

â€œSage likes dry soil. Hates having wet roots. Kind of fussy for a plant that looks half dead most of the time,â€ the girl said.

Â

â€œThat supposed to mean something?â€ Rio asked, not looking up.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œWhen I was kid, I dropped a bowl of soup on the floor,â€ the girl said. â€œIt spilled everywhere. My mom said leave it, she'd take care of it, but I didnâ€™t listen. I actually scrubbed it until the floors paneling was all discolored.â€

Â 

Rio had no idea what the point of the story was or why the girl bothered telling it. It didnâ€™t go anywhere. Didnâ€™t explain anything. She struck Rio as the type of person who rambled for attention, who built up meaningless interactions to make herself feel special.

Â 

When Rio didnâ€™t respond, the girl looked at her and shrugged. â€œI cleaned it up.â€

Â 

The tone of her voice hinted at sadness. She waited, maybe hoping Rio would say it was enough.

Â 

Rio wasnâ€™t here to interpret vague little stories from strangers who made her uneasy. This one talked like she was testing her, handing Rio some unspoken invitation.

Â

Â 

â€œYou cleaned it up too much,â€™ Rio offered, more to end the conversation than to make a point. She even tossed in a shrug hoping to make it obvious that she didnâ€™t care either way.

Â

Â 

The girl pressed her tongue into her cheek, looked down at the table, then back at her. â€œYeah. A little too much,â€ she muttered. â€œThatâ€™ll be it. Â 

Rio stared after her.

Â 

â€œWell that was fucking bizarre,â€ Agatha said flatly.

Â 

Rio turned to look at her wife, and for the first time since the girl showed up, let out a short, breathy laugh. â€œYeah,â€ she said, eyes still on Agatha. â€œIt was.â€

Â 

Somehow, just seeing Agatha made everything feel okay again.

Â 

Rio walked over to the metal box where they kept the cash, tossed the twenty inside, closed it, and turned back to her wife. She crouched beside her, reaching up to touch Agathaâ€™s cheek, and leaned in to press their mouths together in a slow kiss. Her other hand settled on Agathaâ€™s belly, the curve of it warm beneath her palm.

Â 

Agatha kissed her back, and when she pulled away, her smile was soft and a little dazed. â€œWhat was that for?â€

Â 

The sun disappeared behind the clouds. Rio hadnâ€™t noticed it happen, but the light had gone soft and gray around them, the warmth shifting with it. She glanced up once, only briefly, then looked back at Agatha and let it go.

Â 

The way her wife looked at her made Rio feel light. Safe. Completely caught in the moment. â€œI love you,â€ Rio said.

Â 

Agatha gave her a look that was half confused, half completely in love, like she was still trying to catch up to the moment. â€œI love you too.â€

Â 

The rest of the day passed like any other. Rioâ€™s chest didnâ€™t hurt again. No strange girls appeared at the booth. Everything felt normal. And she wasnâ€™t about to let her mind wander back to that interaction, not when this- her wife, their little market stall, the sound of people laughing down the street- felt so much more real.

Â

Â 

Rio had gotten almost everything loaded into the car. All that was left was her wife, the chair she was sitting in, and the empty crate beside her. As Rio turned back toward the booth space, she noticed a journal on the ground where her tables had been. It wasnâ€™t one she recognized.

Â 

She walked over, picked it up, and dropped it into the crate next to Agatha without giving it much thought. Someone must have left it behind.

Â 

Rio stepped in front of her wife and held out both hands. Agatha took them, and Rio gently helped her to her feet, careful with the shift in weight. Â 

â€œYou ready?â€ she asked.

Â 

â€œYup.â€

Â

Â

Â 

â€œNo clue. Someone mustâ€™ve dropped it. Iâ€™ll bring it back tomorrow in case they come looking.â€

Â 

Agatha hummed in response, and that was the end of it. For now.

Â

Â 

Agatha and Rio were tucked into bed, sitting in the quiet that only came when the world had finally gone still. Rio held her close, a hand resting gently over the curve of Agathaâ€™s belly.

Â 

Rio couldnâ€™t recall the life theyâ€™d lived before, literally an enormous chasm of memories had been wiped away. And yet, that loss mattered little compared to this. Rio wouldnâ€™t trade the life they had now to fill in the blanks, she knew that much for sure.

Â 

Sheâ€™d admit- what struck her most wasnâ€™t that the past was missing. It was that her wife wasnâ€™t the one digging for it. Agatha had let it go without a second thought. Anyone with half a brain cell wouldâ€™ve bet on Agatha Harkness to drag every lost moment into the light, demanding answers, demanding truth. But she didnâ€™t. She hadnâ€™t.

Â 

For whatever reason, and in complete defiance of everything that had ever defined them, it was Rio. And honestly? That was fucking laughable.

Â 

Because Rio was the one waking up in the middle of the night with questions she didnâ€™t know how to ask. The one clinging to half formed instincts and invisible red strings, chasing after things she literally could not name.



Most days, Rio carried it like a scar, closed and quiet. There was peace in that. In knowing she didnâ€™t have to chase ghosts just to love what was real and already right in front of her. She didnâ€™t need every page to trust the story. Not when the part she was living in had her wife beside her, and a future waiting to be held.Â Â 

Â 

But there were days it nearly devoured her.

Â 

Nearly nine months. For nearly nine months, they had woken up in the same bed, in a sun drenched house tucked along the coast. Two stories. Pale walls. Big windows. A garden that spanned the entire backyard and a greenhouse that had become Rioâ€™s sanctuary. Agatha worked with words now, writing scathing reviews for a small press that published her critiques like gospel. Rio sold herbs and vegetables at the farmers market, trading produce for cash and whatever gossip people felt like giving.

Â 

It was quiet. It was beautiful. It was theirs.

Â 

That first morning nearly nine months ago, Rio had woken with the startling sense that it was the first time she had ever truly taken a breath. She knew the room. Knew the house. Knew the curve of the coastline in the far distance outside their window and the way the sun fell in long gold ribbons across the floorboards. But still, it felt new. Like oxygen hitting the lungs of someone who hadnâ€™t realized theyâ€™d been drowning.

Â 

And beside her, Agatha slept- peacefully, as if sheâ€™d only ever lived a life built on love.

Â 

Rio couldnâ€™t bear it.

Â 

The stillness. The beauty. The fact that she had it. That this life, somehow, was hers. She hadnâ€™t earned it. She didnâ€™t remember fighting for it. But it was here. And Agatha was here.

Â 

She reached for her wife with homage. Pressed gentle kisses to her lips, her cheeks, the bridge of her nose, unable to keep still, unable to let the moment pass without marking it.

Â 

Agatha stirred slowly, blinking herself into the morning, and when her eyes met Rioâ€™s, the first thing that bloomed across her face wasnâ€™t confusion or sleep or surprise. It was peace. That same overwhelming peace that Rio felt flooding her own chest.

Â 

Rio kissed her again, deeper this time. Like she had won something. Like she had been given a life she didnâ€™t even know was possible to experience. She kissed Agathaâ€™s body with a devotion that wasnâ€™t rushed, that didnâ€™t need to be urgent to be consuming. Her hands moved over familiar skin like this body had been crafted to hold Agatha Harkness through eternity.

Â 

And when they made love, it was glorifying. Celebration. A communion between souls who had been burned down and rebuilt more than once, and somehow still found their way back to one another. Each touch was a thank you. Each breath a vow.

Â 

They had only felt this exquisite knowing: they were exactly where they were meant to be.

Â 

And when it was over, when the morning had stretched fully into day and they lay tangled in each other, Rio couldnâ€™t stop the tears from slipping down her cheeks just from knowing that love this real could exist. That she was even here to feel i t.

Â 

Later, Rio would look back and know this was when it happened. This was when they made him.

Â 

It happened three days later, casually, like most terrifying things do.

Â 

They were at the store, working through a modest grocery list. Automatic. Heâ€™d probably already asked it five times that hour and expected zero resistance.

Â

Â 

He shrugged, bored. â€œI have to card anyone who doesnâ€™t look forty. Store policy.â€

Â 

Rio opened her mouth to answer without thinking-Â 

Â 

But nothing came out.Â 

Â 

Her mouth went dry. Her mind stalled. She scanned every corner of her brain, flipped through the mental files where that sort of thing should live. But there was nothing. No number. No date.

Â 

Next to her, Agatha was already rummaging through her purse, pulling out one of their wallets to hand over an ID. She knew, without having to ask, that Agatha didnâ€™t know either.

Â 

They walked to the car in silence. Rio slid behind the wheel, Agatha in the passenger seat. The keys were in the ignition, but the engine hadnâ€™t been turned on.

Â 

Rio kept her hands on the wheel, fingers lightly curled in case she mightâ€™ve forgotten what they were for. She didnâ€™t look at her wife when she spoke. â€œI donâ€™t know how old I am,â€ she said softly. â€œI donâ€™t even know my birthday.â€

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t respond at first. She reached down, opened her purse again, and pulled out Rioâ€™s wallet. She found the ID, read it, then held it up just long enough for Rio to see.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re thirty-eight,â€ Agatha said gently. â€œApril twenty-fifth.â€

Â 

â€œArbor Day.â€ There was no humor in it, but she said it anyway, hoping that putting a label on the date would make it easier to hold. She blinked once. Then again, slower. â€œSweet,â€ she whispered.

Â 

When she finally looked over, Agatha was staring out the windshield.

Â 

â€œHow old are you?â€ Rio asked in a voice that made the question feel smaller than it was.

Â 

â€œThirty-four,â€ Agatha answered after a beat. Her lips barely moved. â€œCougar.â€

Â 

Rio let out a breath that might have been a laugh if she couldâ€™ve managed to put a little more strength in it. â€œHardly.â€

Â 

The silence that followed was a guest that had overstayed its welcome.

Â 

Agatha turned toward her slowly, like sheâ€™d been working up to it.

Â 

â€œYou know my birthday.â€

Â 

It wasnâ€™t a question. It wasnâ€™t bait. Her wife was reaching. Hoping. Needed reassurance.

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha was nodding, the confirmation seemed to allow her wifeâ€™s lungs to work again.

Â

Â 

She didnâ€™t know where the date had come from. Couldnâ€™t trace it to a single birthday cake or passing of years. Â

Â

Â

Â 

â€œWeâ€™re here. Weâ€™re safe. Thatâ€™s enough for today.â€ Her wifeâ€™s thumb moved in slow, absent circles over Rioâ€™s knuckles.

Â 

Rio nodded, because pretending not to be afraid was something she remembered how to do. She had always been good at that. And for now, her wifeâ€™s hand in hers made it easier to breathe.Â 

Â 

They only talked about it a handful of times. Maybe twice that many, if Rio was being generous with what counted as talking. Agatha never wanted to, but it wasnâ€™t avoidance. She just didnâ€™t see the point in picking at a wound that would likely cause them both to bleed out. Still, she never left Rio to spiral alone. When it got too much, her wife was always there. Always the one to pull Rio back down to earth and remind her which way was upâ€¦ or down. Who knows.

Â 

The fear of forgetting had lived in Rio long before this. It wasnâ€™t new. No. No, this fear felt familiar. It felt trapped in her, like dust in old floorboards, fucking impossible clean out. Even now, when so much was already lost, it wasnâ€™t the gaps that haunted her. It was the knowing she might forget again. That one morning she might not remember how Agathaâ€™s voice dipped when she was tired, or how she laughed, or the exact way her hair smelled when she leaned in too close.

Â 

That fucking fear made a home out of every bone in her body.

Â 

Agatha knew how to keep her from slipping. Sheâ€™d take Rioâ€™s hands and set them on her stomach, fingers splayed. Just skin, and breath, and the reminder that not everything was lost.

Â 

And then Agatha would speak. Low, careful truths like they were spells.

Â 

Her name. Her birthday. The way the garden bloomed for her even when the soil was wrong. That she loved green. That Agatha loved purple. That they both leaned toward the smell of sage in the early morning.

Â 

They were small things. Easy to forget, maybe. But somehow, they always stayed. And it didnâ€™t make the fear go away. But it gave it somewhere to rest.

Â 

Rio could feel it in her body- that none of it was random. That whatever had been lost had been heavy enough to split her clean down the middle. Whatever they had lived through, whatever had been taken had probably been something awful. Probably something she wasnâ€™t built to remember.

Â 

So maybe this was her bodyâ€™s way of surviving it. Dropping the memory and keeping only the part that mattered. The part that looked like Agatha, the swell beneath Rioâ€™s palms, and soft whispers telling her she was real.

Â 

â€œYouâ€™re thinking too much again,â€ Agatha said, her voice loose with sleep but certain in that way she always was when she spoke into the quiet.

Â 

Rio flinched because she hadnâ€™t realized she was anywhere but inside her own head. â€œWhat?â€ she asked, blinking toward the TV.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t open her eyes. â€œThat girl. Is that what this is about?â€

Â 

Rio exhaled through her nose. â€œNo. Fuck no,â€ she said, and she meant it, though the reminder of the girl set her teeth on edge. The one who had just shown up like she belonged at their booth. A stranger with no reason to be familiar. Rio pressed her palm into Agathaâ€™s belly without thinking, grounding herself in the two things that made sense. He kicked back and Agatha let out a low groan.

Â 

The tension in Rio dissolved almost instantly.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Agatha stretched a little under the blanket. â€œBecause it is. You donâ€™t talk, but it fills the room anyway.â€

Â 

Rio shook her head. â€œThatâ€™s not a real answer.â€

Â 

â€œIt doesnâ€™t have to be,â€ Agatha said, her voice still soft. â€œI know what I mean.â€

Â

Â 

â€œNo,â€ Agatha said, and then she shifted a little more, hand moving over her stomach. â€œBut the second she was there, Nicky started acting like he was trying to punch his way out.â€

Â 

Rioâ€™s eyes stayed on the ceiling and her breath was held tight. â€œLike a warning?

Â

Â 

The show played on in the background, but neither of them were watching. Rio kept her eyes open for a while, but her thoughts blurred, softening in the way they did when her body got ahead of her mind.

Â

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t stir.

Â 

And Rio, eyes shut, brain fogged, had no idea sheâ€™d said anything at all.

Â

Â 

Rio woke at the witching hour, like she always did. Three a.m. on the dot. Some nights sheâ€™d wake with her heart already racing, like sheâ€™d been dreaming of something important and forgot it the second her eyes opened. Other nights, it was quieter. Just the pull of her body toward the dark, like the earth was calling out to her.

Â 

Sheâ€™d heard of the witching hour. A time stitched between days, when logic thinned and strange things slipped through. Supposedly, it was when spirits wandered and spells took place, when the living and the dead were closest. Folklore. Superstition. It was harmless, dramatic. Still, there was something about the timing. The precision. It didnâ€™t feel superstitious. It felt personal.

Â 

Rio never tried to sneak out. There was no need. Agatha never stirred when she left their bed, never rolled over or asked where she was going. But Rio knew it wasnâ€™t ignorance. Her wife noticed everything. If Rio tried to keep secrets from her, even small ones, sheâ€™d be met with an attitude sharp enough to flay her. And if she really tried to lie -if she woke every night at the same time and walked the halls like it meant nothing- Agatha wouldnâ€™t argue. She would simply serve Rio her own head on a platter with a folded napkin.

Â 

Most nights, Rio found herself in the greenhouse. Sometimes in the garden. Always surrounded by things that grew. There was something grounding in it, the way the soil clung to her fingertips.

Â 

Only once, had Rio tried to speak to a plant in a language she didnâ€™t know. It felt familiar in her mouth. The syllables rang in her bones with memory. She watched the plant, half expecting it to rise, to glow, to bloom, but nothing happened. The leaf stayed curled, the stem bent.

Â 

She didnâ€™t try again.

Â 

Still, the idea lingered. She found herself wondering, when the nights stretched too long, whether they had been witches before this life. It sounded absurd. But how else did two women create life without intervention, without science, without even knowing how?

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t believe in magic. She didnâ€™t believe in ghosts or spells or anything that bent the rules of what was natural. But Agatha was carrying a child. Their child. And there was no answer for that. No simple explanation.

Â 

Sometimes she thought Agatha knew more than she let on. Not in a secretive way, but in a quiet, careful one. Agatha never dismissed her questions. Never scoffed at her when Rio mentioned waking at the same time every night or the strange comfort she found in speaking to plants. She would just listen, then reach for Rioâ€™s hand. Or change the subject. Or smile in that way that wasnâ€™t snide, just sad.

Â 

Agatha never chased the past. She didnâ€™t dig. And Rio got the sense it wasnâ€™t because she didnâ€™t care, but because she did. Too much.Â  Maybe her wife already suspected enough and had chosen this version of their lives over the one that might break it.

Â 

Rio could never let it go.

Â 

It had nothing to do with wanting the life theyâ€™d left behind. She wasnâ€™t trying to get back to anything. She didnâ€™t even know what was back there. It was probably bitter, cruel, cold in a way their home here wasnâ€™t. And even if it hadnâ€™t been, even if there had been joy in it, it didnâ€™t matter now.

Â 

What got under Rioâ€™s skin was how she couldnâ€™t shake the feeling that a piece of herself had been left behind.

Â 

It would happen randomly, sheâ€™d be tending to the plants or walking back through the hall and it would hit her. A pause in her breath. A stillness that didnâ€™t belong.

Â 

She always caught herself listening for footsteps that never came.

Â 

And it wasnâ€™t just her.

Â 

Rio noticed it in Agatha too. Not in anything she said, but in the pauses. In the way her wife's hand would settle low on her belly without thought, fingers tracing slow, absent circles. Sheâ€™d stand in a room and go still for a moment too long, her attention drifting toward nothing. Just... listening for something.

Â 

Agatha never mentioned it. Neither of them did. But it was there.

Â 

And Rio wasnâ€™t the only one listening for footsteps.

Â 

Rio shook her head, trying to clear the haze of whatever had been circling her thoughts. Tonight, her feet hadnâ€™t led her to the garden or the greenhouse. Without really meaning to, sheâ€™d ended in the doorway of their sonâ€™s room.

Â 

She stepped inside, eyes scanning the space incase it might change. But it never did. Every time she looked, it was exactly the same. Familiar. Calming. Real.

Â 

Moonlight spilled in through the window, catching on the curve of the crib, the soft colors of the walls, the little details theyâ€™d picked out over months. Everything was in place. The furniture. The clothes. The folded blankets that Agatha kept refolding no matter how neatly Rio had done it the first time.

Â 

The room was done.

Â 

And standing in it, for a long breath, it made it easier to pretend they were just listening for him. That any minute now, she and Agatha would hear the soft patter of footsteps across the floor.

Â 

Rio thought about the morning it all started.

Â 

Agatha had gotten sick without warning- woken up, mumbled something about â€˜being fucking nauseousâ€™, and disappeared into the bathroom with no other explanation. Rio followed close behind, already worried, brushing the hair from her wife's face, asking if she was okay. When Agatha waved her off and shuffled back to bed, Rio tucked her in without a word, pressed her palm lightly to her forehead, and said sheâ€™d be back soon.

Â 

Agatha didnâ€™t even ask where she was going.

Â 

Rio hadnâ€™t known what she was looking for. Sheâ€™d wandered the aisles in a daze until her hand reached for a pregnancy test, and only after it was in her basket did she pause to ask herself why. No plan theyâ€™d made, no moment where any of it had seemed possible.

Â 

But her body had known. She bought six pregnancy tests.

Â 

When Rio stepped into the bedroom, Agatha was still under the blanket, propped against the headboard with a glass of water and the ghost of a smirk on her face. She didnâ€™t look sick anymore, just vaguely smug in that way that made Rio deeply nervous.

Â 

Agatha had taken the box with the same certainty that Rio had felt when she picked it up.

Â 

But before her wife could even make a move to open it, Rio reached forward and snatched it right back.

Â 

â€œI just want to read the instructions,â€ Rio said, flipping the box over.

Â 

Agatha held out her hand, palm open and waiting. â€œI know how to pee in a cup, Rio.â€

Â 

â€œI believe you. I just also believe in thoroughness.â€

Â 

Rio stood beside the bed and read the instructions once through. Then again. And again. Her eyes moved across the page, her lips pressing tighter the longer she read. Once she was satisfied she had absorbed every word, she cleared her throat and started reading them out loud.

Â 

â€œOkay. Pee in the cup first. Then dip each test in for five seconds. One at a time. Make sure the strip is fully covered, then lay it flat- flat is important, apparently. Wait five minutes. No tilting, no peeking early, and definitely no reusing.â€

Â 

Agatha huffed, amused but trying not to show it. â€œGive me the test, Rio.â€

Â 

Rio glanced up. â€œI just need you to do it right.â€Â 

Â 

There was something soft behind Agathaâ€™s smile now. â€œI know.â€

Â 

Rio pulled five more boxes from the bag and stacked them neatly on Agathaâ€™s lap.

Â 

Agatha stared at her, then looked down at the pile of tests in her lap. â€œAre you kidding?â€

Â 

â€œWe need to be absolutely sure.â€

Â 

â€œSure about what? That youâ€™re insane?â€

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t flinch. â€œYes. And that weâ€™re not imagining this.â€

Â 

Agatha sighed through her nose but didnâ€™t protest. She gathered the boxes and stood, brushing the blanket off her legs. â€œYouâ€™re lucky I love you.â€

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t say anything. She just watched her wife walk to the bathroom with the door half open, every step feeling both too long and not long enough.



Rio sat at the edge of the bed, chewing the inside of her cheek, clutching the crinkled instructions and rereading the part about the wait time again and again hoping time would move faster if she just understood it hard enough.

Â 

Then Agathaâ€™s voice floated out from the bathroom, â€œYour science experiment is complete.â€

Â 

Rio stood up so fast the bed creaked in protest, but her feet didnâ€™t carry her forward. â€œAll of them?â€ she called out, not quite daring to cross the room.

Â

Â 

She heard the faucet shut off. Then Agatha stepped out of the bathroom, calm and barefoot, one pregnancy test held delicately between two fingers.

Â

Rio stared. Clear, unmistakable letters. PREGNANT.

Â

Â 

Agatha lowered the test. â€œI double checked,â€ she said gently, stepping closer, â€œthen I triple checked because I know who Iâ€™m married to.â€

Â 

Rioâ€™s vision tunneled, white creeping. Her knees werenâ€™t exactly weak- justâ€¦ rebellious. The world tilted.

Â 

â€œOh, for fuckâ€™s sa-â€ was the last thing Rio heard before it all went dark.

Â 

She came to lying flat on her back, her wife kneeling beside her, smiling like she'd just won a bet she never planned on losing.

Â 

â€œYou fainted,â€ Agatha said, too pleased.

Â 

â€œNo,â€ Rio croaked, blinking up at the ceiling. â€œI justâ€¦ very suddenly and enthusiastically chose to lie down on the floor.â€

Â 

â€œMhm.â€ Agatha smoothed a hand through her hair, her fingers gentle. â€œYou okay?â€

Â 

â€œAmazing,â€ Rio deadpanned. â€œI love you so much I forgot how to stand.â€

Â 

Agatha laughed softly and leaned in. â€œWeâ€™re having a baby,â€ she whispered.

Â 

Rioâ€™s eyes widened, then softened. â€œWeâ€™re having a baby,â€ she repeated, voice catching.

Â 

Agatha touched her cheek, nodding.

Â 

And Rio- well, she broke out in a laugh, a sob, whatever it was, it tore through her like light through stained glass, every color of feeling flooding in at once. There was no separating awe from disbelief, no sense trying to hold anything back. She reached for Agatha, her wife. The kiss she pulled her into wasnâ€™t neat or gentle. It was trembling and full of stunned gratitude, messy with wonder and all the words she didnâ€™t know how to say. Agatha kissed her back without doubt, meeting her in that chaos. And on the floor, Rio loved her- fully, reverently, like it was the first time and the last time and every lifetime in between.

Â 

Later, completely naked, Rio stood in the bathroom, staring down at all six sticks. She read the directions again, just in case. Behind her, Agatha -also completely naked, perched on the toilet lid like it was a throne- walked her through each step she took, explaining how she followed the instructions to the letter.

Â 

Rio blinked away the memory, a quiet laugh slipping past her lips. She turned and stepped out of her son's room, padding down the stairs with that dazed, post reminiscing haze still clinging to her. But the moment her foot hit the last step, chaos arrived on four legs.

Â 

SeÃ±or Scratchy shot across the floor like heâ€™d been launched from a cannon, his tiny feet skidding wildly on the floor. He banked off the wall with a dull thunk, vanished into the kitchen like a furry missile, and something definitely fell.

Â 

Rio paused, stared blankly after him, and muttered, â€œOkay.â€

Â 

She wandered into the study.

Â 

Technically, it was Agathaâ€™s office- lined with towering bookshelves, a desktop humming softly in the middle of the room atop a desk, and whatever papers Agatha had left scattered across it.

Â 

Rio mostly used the computer to google things and doom scroll Reddit when her existential dread got too loud.

Â 

Her tarantulaâ€™s enclosure sat in front of the window, pristine and climate controlled, like a little throne room for her eight legged buddy- who, unlike SeÃ±or Scratchy, never caused a single kitchen disaster.

Â 

She walked over and opened the enclosure, holding her hand out, palm up. Petunia hesitated only a second before crawling into it, legs brushing lightly against her skin.

Â 

â€œHi, Tootie,â€ Rio whispered absently, the nickname felt belonged to someone else and had just passed through.

Â 

She crossed the room, switched on the desk lamp, and sank into the chair. The book sheâ€™d left behind was still on the desk, spine cracked open, pages marked by half finished thoughts. She placed Petunia gently on the surface, and the spider immediately scurried onto the keyboard.

Â 

It was a parenting book. The woman at the bookstore had said it was a favorite among â€˜nervous first timers,â€™ and Rio had nodded because that meant her.

Â 

She was supposed to be one of those. A first timer. Totally new to all of this.

Â 

The book was practical. No frills. It broke things down into neat categories: emotional regulation, developmental milestones, discipline styles. The tone was clinical in a way that usually comforted her. It was structured. Predictable. Safe.

Â 

This shouldâ€™ve been her thing.

Â 

But it wasnâ€™t landing right.Â 

Â 

The number three showed up constantly. Three developmental phases. Three types of correction. Three core needs. The more Rio noticed it, the more it pissed her off. She couldnâ€™t explain why.

Â 

Three had always followed her. She woke at three every morning, without fail. She checked things three times, said things in three, sometimes without realizing she was doing it. Three ruled her life here.Â 

Â 

It wasn't a ritual. It was compulsion, and it made her skin itch.

Â 

People liked to call the number balanced, even symbolic. For Rio, it felt incomplete. Like someone had stopped counting just before the world made sense. Like expected footsteps that never came.

Â 

She had always preferred four. Four felt grounded. Whole. A shape you could stand in. But no matter how she tried, something always pulled her back to three- over and over. And it never felt right.

Â 

Her eyes skimmed a section on feeding schedules and routines and she rolled them before she could stop herself. Whoever wrote it had never actually been in the room with a child who wouldnâ€™t eat. Who screamed for no reason. Who needed more than a schedule.

Â 

The book, with its clinical tone and carefully ordered rules, leaned on that same balance. It told her how to build trust, how to manage meltdowns, how to shape behavior- all in clear sequences, all in threes. It was designed to calm uncertainty. But as she read, something in her pushed back. The advice wasnâ€™t wrong, exactly, but it was too tidy. Too polished to be true.

Â 

She found herself silently rewriting parts of it- shifting emphasis, changing tone, dismissing certain examples entirely. She hadnâ€™t meant to. The corrections rose without thought, as though sheâ€™d lived it, and knew what the book refused to say.

Â 

She paused with her fingers resting on the edge of the page. There was no reason she should be this confident in what the book left out. She hadnâ€™t raised a child. And yet she felt certain about what was missing.

Â 

Rio sat back slightly and closed the book. It wasnâ€™t that the information was useless. It was just too polished to be true. She liked order. Order was supposed to be enough. That was the promise. If you followed the rules, things would work. If you stayed consistent, if you remained calm, the pieces would fall into place. She had built herself around that.

Â 

But children werenâ€™t predictable. Pregnancy wasnâ€™t predictable. And Agatha, most of all, wasnâ€™t predictable. She was contradiction, interruption, and mess.

Â 

Rio had never loved anyone more.

Â 

She had known for certain that loving chaos didnâ€™t mean she had failed order. It meant the system had to stretch to include what didnâ€™t fit.

Â 

And this bookâ€¦ didnâ€™t know how to stretch.

Â 

Petunia paused on the space bar.

Â 

â€œYou think itâ€™s weird too, huh?â€

Â 

Silence.

Â 

Good.

Â 

Rio didnâ€™t want an answer.

Â

Â

Â 

The journal.

Â 

She remembered exactly where sheâ€™d left it. In the crate. In the car.

Â

Â 

Maybe it was nosiness. Maybe it was something else. But every part of her said she needed to read it.

Â 

Yes, opening someone elseâ€™s journal was probably a violation of privacy- technically. But Rioâ€™s moral compass had always been flexible when it came to other people. Strangers didnâ€™t rank high on her ethical scale. Unless the handwriting inside belonged to Agatha, she could live with the guilt.

Â

Â 

And if the universe had dropped it on her desk without explanation, she figured she had permission to look... Or at least a good excuse.

Â 

Rio snatched the journal and flipped it open. A folded piece of paper was tucked into the spine. She didnâ€™t bother unfolding it. It looked ancient, like it might fall apart if she breathed on it wrong.

Â 

A sticky note clung to the inside cover, on the left side. The handwriting pulled at a memory she couldnâ€™t place. Familiar, but not hers. Obviously not her wifeâ€™s.

Â 

If you forget.

Â 

â€œWeird,â€ Rio mumbled, and turned to the first page.

Â 

Rio nearly shit her pants when she saw what was on the first page.

Â

Below the portrait was her wife's full name, date of birth, and place of birth, everything cataloged like a record in a forgotten archive. Next to her name, in a scrawl that made Rioâ€™s chest tighten, were two words: Your wife.

Â 

The handwriting was her own. Not similar to hers, not close- hers.

Â

Â 

Nicholas Scratch- Your sonÂ 

Â

Â 

Sage Vidal-Harkness- Your daughter

Â 

The smile Rio could never remember to miss.

Â 

A gust tore through the room with no warning, sending loose papers flying from the desk. The lamp flickered violently.Â  Her hair blew across her face, but she didn't registered it. The journal was all she could see. Her grip on it tightened, her fingers digging into the binding.

Â 

She flipped faster now. Her eyes scanned, but she wasnâ€™t reading- she was absorbing. Line after line in her own voice rising from the pages like something trying to crawl out from beneath the earth.

Â 

You let her touch you. You touched her.

You have forgotten who you are.

The night came, his heart stopped.

But she is yours. And you love her.

Still, you pray.

You are Death.Â 

She still hates you.

And you have forgotten what you are. Who you are.

For once, you do not wish to remember.

Â 

The words blurred as her eyes skimmed them, but her body remembered. Her blood remembered. Her bones remembered. Everything came flooding back in a rush that felt like drowning.

Â 

Her chest felt entirely too tight. She sucked in a breath that didnâ€™t make it all the way down.

Â 

Rio tried to stand.

Â 

The chair scraped back just an inch before her knees buckled. The journal slipped from her lap as she collapsed to the floor, catching herself on her palms with a jolt that shook her spine. Â 

She barely made it before the nausea took over. The vomit hit hard and sudden, her ribs clenching with each convulsion, her hair sticking to her cheek.Â  Her stomach emptied, but the memories didnâ€™t stop. They kept coming, relentless and whole.

Â 

She rolled onto her back. Cold floor. Spinning ceiling. Her chest heaving violently.

Â

Â

Â

Â 

But somewhere beyond the sobs tearing through her, beyond the ringing in her ears, the tremble in her limbs, and what felt like her heart breaking into pieces, a single thought cut through the noise- clear, blinding, and brutal.

Â

Â 

Her mind stalled there- spinning, stuck, unable to move past the name now roaring through her.

Â 

â€œSage!â€

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Three miles. She didnâ€™t slow.

Â

Â 

Rio stopped well before the shoreline, her body spinning in place. She scanned the beach, desperate, eyes wide and stinging. Nothing. No movement. No figure in the distance. Just the wind and the surf and the harshness of her own breath. Her chest heaved as she lifted her hands to her head, fingers tangling in her hair, as she stared out at the ocean.

Â 

It was too loud, too restless, too much like her.

Â 

She had always believed the earth would be the only thing to remember her name. It held the shape of her hands, the trace of her steps, the quiet of what once grew under her care. It preserved her absence, not her presence.

Â 

Where the earth remembered her gently, the sea would offer no such mercy.

Â 

It remembered Rio fully. It had known her before there was language for what she was. Before Death. Before forgetting. It carried every version of her and offered them back in sound.

Â 

She tried to breathe. To still her hands. To quiet whatever was rising inside her before it swallowed everything else. If she could settle herself, maybe the rest would soften too.

Â 

But the ocean only grew louder.

Â 

The wind turned wild. The waves rose higher. The sea refused to meet her halfway. It reflected what she couldnâ€™t contain, gave design to what she didnâ€™t ask to feel. It knew her in ways nothing else did, and it offered no kindness in return.

Â 

Rio turned away from its roar, breath still ragged. She stayed there, her body unmoving, her back to the water that still reached for her. There was no peace in facing it. No comfort in being seen that completely.

Â 

And maybe that was what hurt most of all. That it still remembered her. That it would keep remembering her long after she could no longer bear to face it.

Â 

The wind circled Rio. It carried the memory of storms, of joy, of heartbreak that could split the heavens. The weather had always held chaos and order in the same breath. She had taught it to rise, to thunder, to calm. She had shaped it, and it had reshaped her in return.

Â 

The ocean had always moved first. It was the beginning. It called out long before the sky was ever born to answer.

Â 

That was what they had been. Sea and sky. Question and reply.

Â 

But what is the ocean without its sky?

Â 

A body waiting for its storm.

Â 

Rio reached for her daughter. There was no spell on her lips. No focus. No formality. Just instinct. Just that deep, familiar pull in her chest. The place that had always responded to Sage before anything else. The part of her that had never forgotten even when everything else had.

Â 

Then the sun broke the horizon. It wasnâ€™t sudden, but it felt like it. A breath taken after holding too much for too long. Light unfurled across the waves, and in its warmth, the world shifted.

Â

Â 

Rioâ€™s body moved before reason could catch up, guided by the knowing that had always lived just beneath her breath.

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â

Â 

Sage hadnâ€™t aged in any way a body might show. Her face held the same softness, the same youth. But there was a difference. A depth in her green eyes that hadnâ€™t been there before. It came from walking beside the dead and never looking away. From witnessing too much and bearing it in silence.

Â

Â 

Sageâ€™s cheeks remained full. No hollows beneath her eyes. No trace of decay or strain. She looked whole. But Rio saw past the surface. She saw the stillness. The calm that had settled where something wilder used to live.

Â 

Her daughter had seen horrors. Not stories. Not shadows. The real thing. And still, she was standing.

Â 

Rio hadnâ€™t expected that to feel like comfort. But it did because survival meant something. Because even if she couldnâ€™t protect her daughter from what sheâ€™d seen, she could still recognize the strength it took to endure it. To still be standing. To still be Sage.

Â

Â

â€œI thought I was trapped because of what I did for you both. That I broke something and that was the punishment. But I wasnâ€™t trapped as a consequence. I was trapped because I refused to understand.

Â 

I didnâ€™t want to understand something that could do that to the people I love. But it didnâ€™t let me go, because it understood me before I ever understood it. And it waited until I saw it clearly.

Â 

It bent for you because it had to. Youâ€™re why it exists in the first place and it didnâ€™t know what to do when you broke away from it. It didnâ€™t understand what moved you. That loved moved you.

Â 

You and Mom rewrote the laws of nature and Iâ€™m the anomaly. I wasnâ€™t supposed to exist but I do. Iâ€™m the result of everything it couldnâ€™t explain.

Â 

So it came down to this- either I understood it, or I stayed stuck. And yeah, I fought it. I was stubborn as hell about it. But I did it anyway.

Â 

So it let me go.

Â 

Now it listens. It bends. Iâ€™ve got the power, and I can do whatever I want with it. And Iâ€™m going to be selfish about it. For you. For her. For him. For everything it took and dared to call necessary.

Â 

It will never fucking touch my family again.â€

Â 

Rio couldnâ€™t breathe.

Â 

She sat frozen, hands curled into the fabric of her sweatshirt, nails biting through the seams. Her throat burned. Pressure built behind her eyes, but she didnâ€™t dare blink. Every part of her felt too full for that.

Â 

Sageâ€™s words echoed through her, louder than they had any right to be.

Â

Â

Â

Rio blinked at that, and for a second, her heart stuttered. It didnâ€™t matter that the baby couldnâ€™t understand. Sage wasnâ€™t talking to him like a stranger. She was talking to someone she already knew.

Â 

Four. A shape you could stand in. Completely whole.

Â 

-

Â 

Once upon a time, Agatha Harkness found herself wishing for another year.

Â 

Not for immortality. Not for eternity. Just a year. One full turn of the earth, one imperfect stretch of months where things grew and changed and died- and maybe, if the universe was kind, came back again.

Â 

She wanted every part of it. The spring rains that softened the ground. The summer heat that made the days feel long and unruly. The crispness of fall, and the silence of winter. She wanted the mundane, the messy, the ordinary magic of waking up and realizing she had made it to another morning.

Â 

And now she had it.

Â 

She wasnâ€™t waiting for the next tragedy.

Â 

She was living the wish.

Â 

Agatha didn't despise the seasons anymore. Because she knew now that spring would come. That summer would follow. That fall would ask her to let go, and winter would ask her to rest. And still, she'd stay. Sheâ€™d wake up. Sheâ€™d laugh. Sheâ€™d curse. Sheâ€™d fight. Sheâ€™d hold on to everything she loved and let the rest slip away.

Â 

Because the point was never to stop the turning.

Â 

The point was that this time, she got to turn with it.

Â 

â€œMOM!â€

Â 

It ripped Agatha from her thoughts. She ran to the living room, heart pounding, ready for anything- except this.

Â 

Nicky, ten months old and giggling like a maniac, sat in the middle of the rug, swinging Brucie over his head in wide, gleeful circles. The snake flailed through the air, occasionally slapping the floor.

Â 

Sage sat frozen on the couch, horrified, eyes wide as she gasped at Agatha, â€œYouâ€™re just gonna let him do this?â€

Â 

Rio walked by with a bag of chips, didnâ€™t even glance at what was unfolding. â€œThe snake deserves it.â€

Â 

Agatha laughed so hard she nearly cried.

Brucie, still airborne, did not.

Chapter End Notes
